DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF THE HONOURABLE SIR ALEXANDER RUSSELL DOWNER, K.B.E.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, it is with deep regret that I have to inform the Senate of the death on 30 March this year of the Honourable Sir Alexander Russell Downer, K.B.E. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death on 30 March 1981 of the Honourable Sir Alexander Russell Downer, Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire, a member of the House of Representatives for the division of Angas from 1949 to 1964, a Minister of the Crown from 1958 to 1963 and Australian High Commissioner in London from 1964 to 1972; and that the Senate places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his widow and family in their bereavement.

Alexander Russell Downer was born in 1910, 10 years after the birth of the Commonwealth of Australia itself. His father, Sir John Downer, was one of the founders of this Commonwealth as well as being a Premier of South Australia. Alec Downer followed with conviction and dedication in the tradition of political life and service to the community. He was educated both in Australia and in England. He took the degrees of Master of Arts and Diploma of Economics and Political Science at Oxford University. He was called to the Bar at the Inner Temple in London in 1934 and was admitted to the South Australian Bar in 1935. In 1940 he enlisted as a gunner in the Australian Imperial Force. He went to Singapore on active service in 1941 and was reported missing. He spent some three and a half years as a prisoner of war at the Changi camp until the recapture of Singapore in 1945. It is greatly to the credit of Alec Downer, and a tribute to his character, that a major effect of his experience from those years was a strengthened belief in the value of closer international co-operation.

He entered this Parliament as member for the division of Angas in 1949 and was returned successfully in the next five elections. He served with distinction on a considerable number of parliamentary committees and was well known, well respected and greatly liked as a member of parliament. He had close friends on both sides of the House and there was widespread appreciation of his work both on the back bench and as a Minister. He became Minister for Immigration in 1958 and served in that portfolio until 1963. He worked devotedly and effectively as Minister for Immigration, travelling to the United Kingdom and Europe and also to the United States of America to discuss various issues concerning immigration. It will doubtless be recorded as a tribute to his work in that portfolio that the late Mr Arthur Calwell took the opportunity to say how pleased he was both with Alec Downer's appointment to it and with the way in which he handled it. Alec Downer resigned from this Parliament on 23 April 1964 in order to take up the position of Australia's High Commissioner in London. On the occasion of his resignation the late Sir Robert Menzies said of him:

He is an extraordinarily popular member of this House and he will take to London with him a great background of tradition. He is a man of high education, of wide information, of great courtesy and with an uncommon capacity for getting on with people and presenting his views . . . without forfeiting friendship.
Sir Robert went on to say how ideal were the qualifications and attributes of Alexander Downer for the post he was shortly to take up in London, and that proved to be right.

He was made a Knight Commander of the British Empire in 1965. His term of office in London was extended three times, and it was he who insisted that the third renewal must be the last. He was a great believer in the link between Australia and Great Britain. His period of office in London was a time during which considerable adjustments were made to some aspects of that link as the United Kingdom moved into the European Economic Community. He had his own views about that move and about its implications. Throughout this whole period he was a great ambassador for Australia. During his entire period of office in the United Kingdom he used his position and his private resources to further as much as he could the interests of Australia. He was, of course, a great lover of both Australia and England, but it was Australia in which he chose to live at the end of his period of office in London. He had had a fine career. Much was promised and much given. He was grateful for his life and for his service.

I first met Alec Downer some 38 years ago when I came to Changi Gaol. He was there as Sergeant Downer in charge of education. At Changi he had developed the job of keeping high the morale and the interests of those who were sick and those who were wounded by the vision he could create, by the information he could disseminate. I knew him over the journey of the 38 years. He was, as I have described, a person of quiet dignity and massive integrity, a very likable man, and very fortunate in his wife and his family. I have been proud to call him a friend. I think that all those on either side of politics who knew Alec would call him friend. They would have respected his views and his outlook, and he himself knew the meaning of friendship. This therefore is a time of particular sadness for his family. To his wife Mary-a magnificent woman, if I may say so, who gave him immense support and dedication, particularly in recent months during his long illness-and to his children Stella, Angela, Una and Alexander, we extend our deep sympathy at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I would like to associate the Opposition with the remarks made by Senator Carrick relating to the late Sir Alexander Downer. He was, by all accounts, a very decent man who was widely respected on both sides of polities. As Senator Carrick has indicated, Sir Alexander followed a long and distinguished career in public life and community service which undoubtedly put him in the category of being a very great and distinguished Australian. Although I did not know him personally, I think it is true to say that, from the observation of my colleagues, he was in politics a man capable of great generosity of spirit and flexibility of ideas. As he grew older he did not necessarily become more rigid in his ideas, as some of us tend to do, but remained very flexible to his approaches to issues as they developed. We share the sentiments expressed by the Leader of the Government in the Senate in a general sense, and join with the Government in extending our sympathy to his wife and family.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party)

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to associate the National Country Party with this condolence motion and offer our very sincere sympathy to the wife and family of Sir Alexander Downer. I did not have the good fortune to know Sir Alexander Downer personally, but he was widely and well known. There can be no shadow of doubt that he was well received and accepted in the community in which he moved. I am absolutely sure that Sir Alexander Downer was a distinguished Australian who served his country fully in peace and war. As the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) noted, Sir Alexander Downer had a distinguished academic career at school and university. Indeed, he knew the privations of three and a half years as a prisoner of war in Changi. Sir Alexander mirrored the concern and the capacity of his father in a long and distinguished political career. When that career came to a close he continued to represent this country very favourably indeed as Australian High Commissioner in London. He served his country well. He died in his home and beloved city of Adelaide. To Sir Alexander's widow and family, on behalf of the NCP I offer our very sincere sympathy.

—On behalf of the Australian Democrats I join in this condolence motion concerning Sir Alexander Downer. I knew him. I served in the Parliament with him. There are very few people-the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator John Carrick, is one-who have suffered being a prisoner of war. Those of us who have not had that experience will never be able to know the effect that has on a man. Only those who suffered will ever know. Notwithstanding that, I found Alec Downer a most generous man-generous of spirit and generous nature. That is to his extra credit. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Davidson Sen G.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to be associated with the motion of condolence in connection with the death of Sir Alexander Downer. I want also to pay tribute to his life and service to his State and to his country. I think I speak this afternoon in the name of my parliamentary colleagues on this side of the chamber. Mr President, in particular I speak on your behalf as your position does not allow you to take part in speeches in this way. Sir, as you were, I think, his neighbour in recent years, you came to know him very well. Along with others I served in this Parliament with Sir Alexander Downer when he was the member for Angas. Indeed, Sir Alexander was the first member for Angas following its re-establishment in 1948.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall with appreciation my association with Sir Alec, as a colleague of the same party and as a parliamentary colleague and, of course, as a fellow South Australian. I also knew him in his capacity as Minister for Immigration in times, we will recall, of somewhat unusual difficulty. He administered the Department of Immigration extremely well and to the lasting benefit not only of this country but also of the people whose lives his Department affected. Later I was to have an involvement in the area of immigration and my association took on a special value when Sir Alec became the Australian High Commissioner in London. So it was from those positions that one was able to observe and to benefit from his quite remarkable talent, his singular forward-thinking and his political ability, together with his very strong national outlook. As he acknowledged, he was an interesting blend of the conservative and the radical. In meetings that we in politics have, meetings on public platforms and in conversation, and meetings in his homes both in South Australia and in England, I had personal and public experiences which I remember today with very great appreciation.

Alec Downer was a man who was richly endowed. His family had been in South Australia since 1838. His was an endowment rich in family tradition and inheritence. He bore a distinguished name and a whole host of distinguished characteristics. He was a man of very wide culture. Australia has benefited from all these things. His own father, Sir John Downer, was a member of the first Senate in 1901 and, indeed, was one of the writers of the Australian Constitution. Later, as years passed, Sir Alec was a member of this Parliament and was part of a parliamentary committee that undertook a major review of the Constitution, which review, as he so often reminded us, has not received very much attention since then.

His quite extraordinary life touched the lives of many other people. It touched the lives, as the Leader of the Government in the Senate has said, of his comrades in the prisoner-of-war camps. It touched the lives of colleagues and friends in the various Commonwealth societies to which he was so devoted and in which he served. It touched the lives of leaders of British life while Sir Alec was Australian High Commissioner in London. It touch the lives of staff members, Commonwealth drivers and others whom we know and who will be remembering him today.

Sir Alec Downer always wanted to make a significant contribution to the public life and to the political life of this country. So, we are grateful today that the years, his experience and opportunity enabled him to do just that. This afternoon we extend our regards and our sympathy to Mary-Lady Downer-their son and their three daughters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Byrne Sen The Hon J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to be associated with the condolence motion before the Senate relating to the late Sir Alexander Downer. Sir Alexander entered this Parliament in 1949 as the member for Angas just three years after I was elected to represent Tasmania in 1946. So, I can claim that we were contemporaries in the early post-war brigade. On every occasion that I made contact with him I found him to be an exceptionally kindly and gentlemanly person. We often reminisced on our common experiences as prisoners of war. Sir Alexander spoke of his experiences in Changi and I spoke of mine in Stalag Luft III. We often spoke particularly of the number of dinners that we went without. We had many more dinner times than dinners. That was one of our standing jokes. Senator Carrick, too, would well have been able to join in these conversations about the way we had to scavenge for food. It was a very great and testing experience.

SPEECH.PARA: Sir Alexander had tasted the bitters and the sweets of life and had scaled the heights and tested the depths. These experiences, I am cetain, were reflected in the mature way that he approached both his parliamentary life and his diplomatic life as Australian High Commissioner in London. In war and peace, Sir Alexander served his country, his State and the people of Australia with great ability, sincerity and dignity. To his wife, Mary, and his family I join other honourable senators in offering my very sincere sympathy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, relates to some recent discussion regarding the Government Information Unit and the use of that Unit. By way of preface I draw the Minister's attention to statements made by Government spokesmen in 1976 that the Government's new media information unit was not like the previous Government's Australian Government Liaison Service. I refer to the statement made in 1976 to the effect that the difference between the two bodies is that the new body will not have a journalistic component and it will not telex information to radio, television and the print media, as did its predecessor. I ask the Minister: Is it not a fact that the Government Information Unit has a journalistic component and that almost all its senior employees are journalists? Does the Government Information Unit telex information directly to the media? Does it not in fact use more sophisticated means of transmitting government information such as audio tapes? Further, does this mean that, on the Government's own standards established in 1976, the Government Information Unit is in fact a propaganda unit as the AGLS was so described?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last part of the question asked whether the Government Information Unit is a propaganda unit. The answer is emphatically no. In 1976 when this Government came to office-indeed, Senator Button mentioned the comparison yesterday-I think it was true that the previous Whitlam Government had for every Minister a Press officer and staff, and indeed it had public relations units in the various States. Some five or six of our 26 or 27 Ministers have Press officers. So we have some 20 Press officers fewer. I do not have a Press officer and I am a senior Minister. The fact of the matter is that there has been a very great reduction in the size of the public relations units. The Government Information Unit does have a government information officer in each State.

—Mr President, it is good to know that one can be helped in this journey. The fact of the matter is that junior Ministers do not have Press officers. The Government Information Unit is designed to assist Ministers in providing information to the public about public services, benefits and programs. This is consistent with the Government's responsibility to inform potential clients of its activities. In the Government's view this is a proper and necessary service to taxpayers. In fact, government has a duty to inform the public of the decisions and actions of government. there is a vast difference between a huge propaganda machine which the Whitlam Government was and the Wran Government is and what is a--

—Mr President, I am terribly grateful for the help. Nothing could emphasise the contrast more than the interjections. The Government Information Unit is also structured to keep the Government informed of developing issues at State level, which is a perfectly appropriate initiative in a federal system. There has been a modest provision of resources to carry out these activities.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the specific situation, yes, the Unit does have persons with journalistic training. There is a telex in the Sydney office of the Government Information Unit. I have no doubt that over the years the Unit has moved toward more sophisticated machinery to carry out its work. The fact is that these people are doing a bona fide job in a modest way, on modest expenditure. There is no competition at all compared with the huge machines of the past and particularly the size of the propaganda machine of the Wran Government or a government similar to it with massive expenditure of public money. By contrast, this Unit is a very modest undertaking.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FEDERAL GOVERNMENT FUNDING FOR LOCAL GOVERNMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware of a letter from the Tasmanian Minister for Public Health requesting special Commonwealth funds for sewerage works similar, the letter says, to those in the national sewerage scheme established by the Whitlam Government in the mid-1970s? Can the Minister inform the chamber of the amount by which the Federal Government funding to local government has increased since the Fraser Government took office?

—I have not seen the letter to which the honourable senator referred, but the question she asked does not depend upon that letter. She asked a question about the contributions by this Government to the local government sector and the extent to which they have increased. I am able to advise the honourable senator that in the last Whitlam Budget local government received just under $80m from the Commonwealth and that in the following year the Fraser Government first introduced a fixed share of personal income tax collections for local government. That year local government received 1.52 per cent of personal income tax collections, which amounted to $140m. This in fact was almost double the previous year's budgetary subvention. In 1979-80, in keeping with an election promise, we increased that percentage of personal income tax collections from 1.52 per cent to 1.75 per cent, which increased funding from $140m to $221m. Of course in the 1980-81 financial year we took the local government share to 2 per cent of all personal income tax collections. In this financial year local government will receive directly from the Commonwealth some $300m. I think the point made by the honourable senator is very clearly understood, that local government has been in receipt of large and increasing amounts from us on a fixed proposition. The Federal Government provides local government in each State with much greater capacity than it has ever had before.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment and the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware and I have been advised by the Australian Film Commission that it considers that the documentary Frontline is indeed one of the finest made in recent years by an Australian producer. —My question is addressed to the Minister representing both the Minister for Industry and Commerce and the Minister for Industrial Relations and is about the 35-hour week dispute. I refer to statements by the Premier of New South Wales that reduction in tariff assistance for ICI Australia Ltd would lead to a substantial loss of jobs. Is it not a fact that recent shorter working-hour sweetheart agreements between some industries and the unions have shown that tariff protection has enabled these industries to be profitable, notwithstanding their inefficiency, as demonstrated by their ability now to absorb a reduction of 12.5 per cent in working hours or an increase of 21 per cent in the cost of their labour? Would not the same reduction in demarcation disputes and improvement in efficiency in a 40-hour week lead to increased competitiveness, more jobs and a reduction in inflation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is a simple and well acknowledged economic fact that if industry is not competitive then jobs will be lost, and increases in the costs of industry, from whatever cause, are likely to cause loss of employment opportunities. I would have thought that what the honourable senator put in his question is self-evident and true, namely, that if a company is able to enter into sweetheart deals with a trade union which ensure considerable improvements in the condition of those workers without any change in productivity, that is an indication that there are profit margins in that company which might belie the need for protection which the company might be publicly claiming that it needs through the tariff system.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator has raised a series of matters which are relevant to the debate which is currently running in the community. It remains a fact that if we are to create further employment in Australia we must have industries which are competitive internationally. As a Government we have managed to prevail over changes in the economy which have made Australian industry more competitive. We are reluctant to see that competitive edge lost with the undoubted effects that that will have on employment, namely, the loss of employment for this country.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CABINET MINISTERS: DISCLOSURE OF PECUNIARY INTERESTS

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Prime Minister to statements of principle which the Prime Minister has made from time to time concerning the pecuniary interests of Cabinet Ministers. I ask: Is it the stated practice of the Cabinet for those with pecuniary interests in policy decisions to inform the Cabinet of this and to abstain from taking part in the making of those decisions? If so, can the Minister tell the Senate whether any Ministers have informed the Prime Minister of their unfitness to participate in decisions which could ultimately affect the interests of television and radio broadcasters? Can he assure the Senate that no one with pecuniary interests in broadcasting has taken part or will take part in such decisions?

—What is known as the Bowen report is being implemented by the Government as it relates to the Ministry. We hope that various steps will soon be taken to extend to all members of parliament the recommendations contained in that report. As to the Ministry, it has been the practice since the Fraser Government came to office in late 1975 for all Ministers to disclose by way of confidential document their pecuniary interests to the Prime Minister. It is a well-accepted universal practice for a Minister, when a discussion is taking place in Cabinet on a particular matter, to indicate to Cabinet any pecuniary interest that he or his family may have. This is done and is accepted as being done. In future, of course, there will be a need for all members of parliament, whether they are Ministers or back benchers, when taking part in a debate to disclose before the debate whether they have an interest in the matter in hand. I am not aware of this principle being confined to any particular subject. Senator Primmer raised the matter of communications. I am not aware of any particular Minister having a pecuniary interest in that area, but I have no doubt in the world that if the Ministers concerned had a particular interest in the matter they would indicate that interest in terms of the Bowen report before debate took place.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, follows the question asked by Senator Lewis. As ICI Australia Ltd has announced the suspension of its proposed expansion plans in reaction to the Government's proposal to refer the question of protection for the chemical industry to the Industries Assistance Commission, will the Government consider referring the matter to the Commission irrespective of the company's response to the demands for a 35-hour week? If an industry can expand only behind the protection of high tariff barriers, should the Commission not be given the opportunity to assess the contribution and the cost of the industry to the Australian economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator has allied his question with a question asked a few minutes ago by Senator Lewis. It contains assertions which are consistent with the assertions put by way of explanation in the earlier question. The question is, however, based on a premise which is now out of date, namely, that ICI will not be proceeding with its development plans. It is my understanding that it is in fact proceeding with those plans; hence the conditions which apparently applied yesterday do not apply today. I understand that a statement has been made by the company-certainly, the Government welcomes that-refuting Press reports that the company had reached agreement on a shorter working week or was willing to do so and indicating also that ICI is strongly opposed to the reduction of working hours because of the effect that this would have on the company's investment plans.

ANSWER.PARA: As I indicated in my earlier answer, there is a whole series of things which can give rise to increased costs to a company or to loss of its income. It might regard the loss of tariff protection as being critical. It might also regard increased labour costs, which shorter working hours certainly will promote, as being something which will make further expansion of its activities uneconomic. But in any event, in the light of the present position, the Government does not propose at this stage to refer the chemical industry to the Industries Assistance Commission. I think the honourable senator would be aware that the matter was considered by the Government some time ago. It was indicated that there would be no such reference to the Commission for a matter of years and, as at the moment, that is still the Government's position.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CONFERENCE OF THE WORLD COUNCIL OF INDIGENOUS PEOPLES

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs: What level of support has been given in the form of administrative assistance for the organisation of and financial assistance for Australian Aborigines to attend the Conference of the World Council of Indigenous Peoples to be held in Canberra from 17 April to 2 May? Have adequate funds been provided to ensure that all facilities will be made available for the conference which will be attracting the attention of the world media? Have any arrangements been made for the Government to recognise officially the importance of this world conference?

—The World Council of Indigenous People is meeting in Canberra at the end of April. I believe the conference will last some five days. It is the third such conference to be held. It is regarded as a very important conference and the Commonwealth Government has already provided $90,000 towards the conference costs.
—Is that all?

—We have provided $90,000. The National Aboriginal Conference has sought funds towards the cost of hosting the conference and has been able to obtain some private contributions. I understand that some State governments also were considering the matter. I repeat that the Government has provided $90,000 and has also provided some other administrative support. I understand that the Governor-General plans to open the conference and I understand also that the Commonwealth is pleased to assist the conference, which will be an important forum. I am hoping that there will be some other functions in which the Commonwealth may be involved. I am sure that I will be present and I hope that other members of the Government will be present to listen to and to take part in the proceedings.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister did not answer my question whether adequate funds have been provided to ensure that all facilities will be made available for the conference, which will be attracting the attention of the world media. In relation to the suggestion that the Governor-General will open the conference, I asked what arrangements had been made for this Government to recognise officially the importance of this world conference. Is the Minister therefore prepared to put forward the suggestion to the Prime Minister that he should give an official reception in King's Hall for the delegates to this conference?

—I believe the support which has been given has been on the basis that it is appropriate and a substantial contribution to the necessary costs of the conference. In relation to the honourable senator's supplementary question, I have already made a suggestion to the Prime Minister along the lines that she has suggested, that it would be appropriate for us to offer hospitality to the delegates here in the Parliament. Mr President, I would have thought that the normal courtesy would be that I would await a response from the Prime Minister before I said anything publicly about this matter. I am only sorry that the honourable senator has asked me the question and I have had to indicate that the letter has gone.

—I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister: Is it a fact that the Premiers Conference this month will discuss only the total amount of income tax reimbursement to the States and not individual allocations to each State? Is the relative distribution between States at present being considered by the Commonwealth Grants Commission with a view to updating the States (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976? Will this report be considered by the Premiers at their June meeting? In considering how much income tax revenue per capita each State should receive, will the Grants Commission take into account the revenue raising capabilities of each State government? Will the Grants Commission consider what could reasonably be raised as well as what is actually raised? Will extra levies put on rail transport for mining facilities be regarded as a source of State government revenue? Is the Bass Strait oil field by far the most important resource development in this country? Of the Government take from this oil, last year did $2,114m go to the Commonwealth Government and only $132m to the Victorian Government, a radically different distribution from any other resource development in the country? Will the Grants Commission in its consideration ignore the direct benefits of tariffs, bounties and Federal Government building projects on the grounds that these are decided by the Federal Government on national interest criteria and have nothing whatever to do with State government revenue, except in the indirect sense that they may increase the capacity of States to raise revenues through measures such as payroll tax? Finally, is it a fact that in the 48 years since the Grants Commission was established its recommendations have invariably been accepted and implemented by the Federal Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question Senator Hamer raised is both interesting and very detailed. I will attempt to tackle it. Firstly, as to the initial discussion by the Premiers, the agreement with the States expires after the current period and, therefore there is a need to look towards what formula for distribution there shall be for the future. So no doubt there will be a discussion at the April meeting as well as later as to the nature of the future formula to be used. The States have met and made some suggestions. The Commonwealth Grants Commission, which was formed in the 1930s and is a very distinguished body, has been asked to undertake a massive task. That task is to review the relativities of all the States. The principle under which the Grants Commission had worked over the years was to try to find what kind of a revenue supplement would be necessary in order for a particular State to provide services equivalent to Victoria. Victoria was a bench-mark and to a lesser extent so was New South Wales. I cannot tell whether the Commission will continue with that bench-mark as other States have now flourished, particularly Queensland and Western Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commission is working and has worked for several years upon its report. That report is due some time in the next three or four months. My understanding is that it is unlikely to be available for the June conference or for the conference of the Premiers. In any case, once it becomes available it will be a document of such comprehensive detail that it will need to be put under study. I cannot speak for the Grants Commissioners but they would, I think, take into account all sources of revenue available to a State including indirect taxes, freight charges and so on. But I do not want to comment on that matter because they will be bringing down their own report. Senator Hamer cited the revenue from the Bass Strait oil fields and compared the revenue the Commonwealth gets-incidentally it spends that revenue on the whole of the nation-with an amount that Victoria gets. I remind Senator Hamer that, in fact, Bass Strait is in Commonwealth waters and is--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity you had not thought of that about 15 months ago.
—It is not the garden State.
—I take it that the interjections of members of the Australian Labor Party mean that they would like to deny Victoria any of the revenues we are talking about.
—It is a pity you had not thought about it earlier. You repudiated your responsibility.

—Otherwise, why would there be an outburst? The fact of the matter is that the revenues from Bass Strait go, largely in a royalty sense, partially to Victoria and substantially to the whole of the people of Australia in terms of the levy. Indeed, in the provisions of the petroleum legislation that was enacted in this Parliament we have a working arrangement with the States. But to sum up, the Grants Commission will bring down its report within the months ahead. It will be a very significant document indeed which will require very great study. The Premiers will discuss their revenue sharing arrangements for the future. The Commonwealth will be inviting the States to undertake a similar responsibility to the Commonwealth in their policies of economic restraint so that we can continue the remarkable economic success we have had with inflation and national growth. The months ahead will be of great significance to Australia.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Is it a fact that Australian sailors serving on HMAS Sydney during its numerous trips to Vietnam during the war conducted there have been denied repatriation benefits for illness or injury traceable to that period of service? Is it also a fact that sailors on destroyer escorts and a commandeered civilian transport ship have likewise been denied access to the benefits of the repatriation system? Is it a fact that HMAS Sydney and its escorts were commonly anchored at a port heavily defoliated to remove the cover given to Vietcong guerrillas by the mangrove swamps? If the answer is yes, why has this Government so callously denied benefits to these many naval personnel?

—I am not aware that persons on the ships mentioned by Senator Tate have been denied benefits. There has been some media discussion about whether some of those persons have been included in the epidemiological study group of recent times. That, I am afraid, is the extent of my knowledge on the matter. If Senator Tate has individual cases which he would like to bring forward I would be only too pleased to consider them.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. My question was only marginally concerned with the fact that some of the sailors may have been exposed to the same chemicals which have caused concern and which are the subject of the epidemiological study. The larger question concerned the denial, as I understand it, of general repatriation benefits and services to the personnel who were engaged in service on HMAS Sydney and its destroyer escorts on the basis that they were never assigned to special service. Despite the fact that they were in dangerous waters and pursuing a task in support of the Australian Government's war effort in Vietnam they have been denied these benefits. In fact these personnel in South Australia have been discouraged, on inquiry to the Department of Veterans' Affairs, from making further requests of the Department.

—I think, now that Senator Tate mentions South Australia, he speaks in particular of a Mr Osman who has made media comment on this matter but mainly in connection with the epidemiological study. Nevertheless, I will undertake to examine the matter more closely and bring back an early reply for Senator Tate.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services aware of allegations that a former Prime Minister visited all the Aboriginal communities in the Macdonnel electorate in the Northern Territory prior to the by-election last Saturday and, through interpreters, told the Aboriginal people not to vote for the Country Liberal Party candidate because the Country Liberal Party Northern Territory Government would take away their land rights which he had given them? Can this be interpreted as misleading information? Will the Minister liaise with his counterpart in the Northern Territory about having this matter taken before the Court of Disputed Returns?

—Of course, land rights for Aboriginal people living in the Northern Territory were secured with the passage of an Act of this Parliament. If anyone asserts that support for a particular candidate for a seat in a Territory House could threaten land rights such a person would be playing upon people's fears in an unnecessary, cynical and cruel way. Aboriginal land rights were established by an Act passed in 1976 by the Fraser Government. These rights have not been threatened. In fact, the Fraser Government has continued to support and endorse them. They are supported today by the Liberal and National Country parties. If anyone asserts otherwise, I think they are on very shaky ground. For anyone to claim otherwise in an election campaign would appear to me to be an act deliberately designed to mislead the electors in that election.

—I have a supplementary question, Mr President. The last part of my question to the Minister has not been answered. It was: Will the Minister liaise with his counterpart in the Northern Territory to have this matter taken before the Court of Disputed Returns?
—I believe the people of the Northern Territory read the Hansard, and I think it would be up to them to take such action if they thought it appropriate.

—I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: Is it true that earlier today at Question Time he denied that he had a Press officer and said that other senior Ministers did not have Press officers? Is it not a fact that the Government Information Unit officer in Sydney is Mr Laurie Power and that he is attached to the Minister's office? Is it also a fact that members of the Government Information Unit are attached to an individual Minister in each State? Is it also true that these officers were directly involved in the Liberal Party's campaign during last October's Federal election? Did these officers meet the Prime Minister's plane, arrange transport for Liberal Party Ministers and their staff, compile monitoring digests of television, radio and newspaper reports and carry out other duties as directed by the Prime Minister's staff, all of which was a charge on the taxpayer and not on the Liberal Party?

—I will take the parts of the question in the order they were asked. I did say, and I repeat, that I did not have a Press officer. I am entitled to one. I have a vacancy for one. I have not employed one. I did say--
—What is Laurie Power then?

—I will come to that without the help of interjectors. I did say that, whereas I believed that all Ministers in the Whitlam Government had Press officers, only five, six or so Ministers in this Government did. I did not say that senior Ministers did not. I said that junior Ministers did not. Mr Laurie Power is a Government Information Unit officer. In each State the Government Information Unit officer functions under the supervision of the senior Government Minister in that State, and in New South Wales that is under me. Mr Power himself would indicate that he does not in fact work for me; nor do I seek his services in day to day public relations. All my media work is done either by me or by my personal staff here in this Parliament. Mr Power is the Government Information Unit officer. He has an office in the suite of rooms that I have in Martin Place, Sydney. I repeat: Mr Laurie Power is not my Press or public relations officer.
—He puts out all your Press releases.

—That is not so. When a Cabinet decision is made and a Cabinet Press release goes out through the Government Information Unit here, from time to time the Government Information Unit offices in the States also put it out. I will be happy to give Senator Grimes, in the interests of information for him, a large cross-section of my Press statements over recent months so that he can see from where they are organised and to where they are distributed. That having been said, my instructions to Mr Power were that he was a government employee, that he was to pursue work for the government of the day and that he was not to be an employee of the Liberal Party as such. As far as I know, those were the duties that he performed.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is it a fact that the Minister for Health gave an undertaking to representatives of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia that he would give them an opportunity to discuss details of the proposed legislation to establish a fees tribunal and its terms of reference before it is introduced into the Parliament? If so, when will these discussions take place? If not, will the Government present the Guild with that opportunity? In view of the importance of deciding on an interim fee increase, the application for which is currently before Mr Justice Ludeke, and in order to establish as soon as possible a mechanism suitable to the profession, will the Minister deal with this legislation as a matter of urgency?

—I am not able to say whether the Minister gave any undertakings to the representatives of the pharmacists. What I can say is that I believe the establishment of a tribunal, as has been proposed by the Government, is a welcome advance and a step which people will want to see come into action as soon as it can. It will be secured by legislation at an appropriate early time. I will have to refer to the Minister whom I represent for detailed answer, the other matters about which the honourable senator asks.

—My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. Is it the case that Australian gun control laws, whilst certainly much tighter than those of the United States, are by no means uniform around the country? In particular, is it the case that in respect of shotguns and rifles, if not hand guns, only two States, Western Australia and South Australia, require both the registration of guns and the licensing of owners and that at the other extreme two States, Tasmania and Queensland, make no attempt to register guns and place no restrictions, except by age, on those who own them? Does he concur with the conclusion of Professor Richard Harding, writing in the Bulletin of 3 March and also in his book Firearms and Violence in Australian Life published just last month, that the consequence of the disparate licensing and registration requirements is that it is impossible to ascertain how many guns of what sort are owned by how many Australian citizens? If he does concur with that, what, if anything, does the Commonwealth propose to do about creating uniform and effective gun laws in this country, including its own Territories?

—I think I can agree with one aspect of the question which Senator Evans raised and that is that the gun control laws throughout Australia are not uniform. However, the question is essentially one for the States. Certainly, the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General has a broad brief from the governments to investigate the question of uniform laws, and it would be open to it to consider the question of uniform gun control laws. It is, however, not a subject which has arisen during the period in which I have been a member of that Standing Committee. I will give consideration to whether it is a subject that should be taken up by the Standing Committee. I am not aware of whether it has even been taken up by it. I have some idea-I am not clear about this-that there was discussion about the matter at an earlier period. However, I will look into the matter and see what has been done and whether there is any possibility of the States being interested in discussing this question. I am not aware of Professor Harding's views on the subject. I do not always agree with Professor Harding's views but in this case I am not in a position to say whether I do.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of the Northern Territory Government's desire to issue new exploration permits in the area adjacent to the 200-mile limit between Australia and Indonesia and that the issue of these permits is being delayed because of negotiations between Australia and Indonesia in regard to a common boundary? Can the Minister give any information as to when this matter will be resolved and when oil exploration permits can be issued in that area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The responsibility for the issue of exploration permits in the Northern Territory adjacent area is, of course, given under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act to our colleague the Minister for National Development and Energy in contact with the Northern Territory Minister for Mines and Energy. Australia and Indonesia concluded agreements in 1971 and 1972 delimiting the sea bed boundary between the two countries in the area of the Arafura Sea as well as the area of the Timor Sea south of West Timor. Accordingly, there is no difficulty in the issuance of permits in these areas. I am informed, however, that negotiations are continuing at official level between Indonesia and Australia with the object of determining the remaining maritime boundaries at the earliest possible date. These negotiations are expected to continue later this year and the Northern Territory Government is being fully consulted in this process.

—I direct my question to Senator Baume in his capacity as the spokesman in this place for the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. By way of preface I remind the Minister that about seven Sundays ago he and I publicly applauded Gael Mulhall, our outstanding field games exponent in the discus and the shotput, for her performance at the Sydney athletic field. I now ask the Minister in his capacity as a member of the Government: How can he justify the lapse of time over the development of the Australian Institute of Sport when our field games exponents are virtually blocked out of Bruce Stadium? In effect, there is no facility for them. As the Minister and I have applauded the performance of Gael Mulhall, are not actions louder than words? What are we doing about providing up to date facilities for our field games people instead of merely having this facade of an Australian Institute of Sport that does not mean very much?

—Not only was I with Senator Mulvihill seven weeks ago at the athletic field in Sydney to see Gael Mulhall perform but also I had the pleasure of watching her on television win the Australian championships a couple of weeks ago in a very creditable performance. The honourable senator is correct in saying that there have been some problems with the conflicting use of facilities such as the demand for the use of the National Indoor Sports Centre and the National Athletics Stadium. The demands on both have been very great. Not all of the problems have yet been resolved but I understand that discussions are continuing among officers of the Department of the Capital Territory, the centre managers, the Department of Home Affairs and Environment and the Institute. There have been special problems with the throwing events because these were causing wear and tear on the main surface of the athletics stadium.
—That is why I suggested an alternative site.

—I pick up the honourable senator's interjection. In the short term the Canberra College of Advanced Education has offered to provide facilities and is in the process of having throwing circles installed for use by Institute athletes. Obviously that is only a temporary solution and longer term arrangements are still being investigated.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TRANSPORT LINKS BETWEEN VICTORIA AND TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister: Is it a fact that the Commonwealth Government accepts an obligation, and has traditionally done so, to provide funding for national highways linking all State capitals? Is it a fact that there is no possible land highway across Bass Strait to link the Victorian and Tasmanian capitals? Is it also a fact that the Commonwealth is thereby relieved of a road contruction cost which in current terms would amount to $600m plus an annual maintenance cost? Is it therefore reasonable for the Commonwealth to repay this saving to Tasmania and Victoria in some way related to other available transport modes?

—If there were ever a need for evidence that the Senate is a States House it comes today. The Commonwealth Government has a Commonwealth-State roads program in which the Commonwealth is the significant financier of national highways. I am aware, as the Premier of Tasmania is-the logo for the bicentenary does not show this-that Tasmania is part of Australia and is not connected to the mainland. I understand that a certain brand of matches went throughout life without showing awareness of this on its cover. I am aware that there is water between Tasmania and Victoria. I have never made the calculation of what would have to happen, save the day, if we were to have a roadway linking the two places and I therefore cannot answer as to whether cost of such a roadway would be $600m or what its annual maintenance would be. As to whether Tasmania and Victoria therefore ought to be recouped because of this phenomenon, I refer to such interesting phenomena as Tasmania's freight subsidy--
—Equalisation, not subsidy.

—Senator Rae's association with qangos has made him highly sensitive. I will give him an up to date dictionary. I am aware of the freight equalisation scheme. I am aware also that the Commonwealth Grants Commission has been recommending for Tasmania something like $500 per capita compared with $250 for New South Wales, for instance. I hope that Senator Rae is praying hard that for the months ahead that will continue. Most of these factors are identifiable. Nevertheless, it is true that an island State separated from the mainland has essential disabilities and, not having a road link, therefore needs special blessings. This Government of ours has been kind in pouring the blessings upon Tasmania.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The Minister may recall that on several occasions I have drawn attention to the need for a consulate or a consular office in Bali. Will she confirm that, despite previous answers she has given me, the decision has now been taken to open such an office later this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not aware of any developments in that matter. I will need to refer it to the Minister for Foreign Affairs to seek information.

—I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister prepared to discuss with Mr MacKellar his letter to the honourable member for Petrie which gives this information? The letter is in the Bulletin this week.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will refer that matter also to the Minister for Foreign Affairs to seek an explanation. I recall the questions that were raised by Senator Robertson, and I will seek the response of the Minister on these matters.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security or, alternatively, to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I draw the Minister's attention to a report dated January 1981, recently released by the Social Welfare Research Centre of the University of New South Wales, which analyses Federal and State government policies for the care of old people who are senile. Will the Minister comment on this report and, in particular, its claim that many of Australia's 57,000 senile elderly are being kept in institutions unnecessarily and that many of them could be cared for more cheaply in the community if doctors and government took some initiatives? Is it correct, as alleged in this report, that the Commonwealth spends on community services less than one-tenth the amount it spends on institutional services for the elderly? Does the Minister agree that strong government support should be given to families so that the special needs of the senile elderly may be catered for by community as opposed to institutional care? If so, will he assure the Senate that consideration will be given by the Government to making home care schemes and special services such as day care or temporary care more universally available?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am familiar with the report to which the honourable senator referred in his question, although I have not read it. I am afraid I have read only some comments on it. The report is primarily concerned with brain failure amongst the elderly, and of course that is only one aspect of aged care with which the Commonwealth is involved. I do not think there is much doubt that many of the confused elderly need institutional care, or care which goes beyond that which can be provided in their own homes. However, for that section of the population, in common with the rest of the population, there is a growing sense in the community and in government and private agencies that, as much as possible, people should have the opportunity to remain in a normal domestic situation.

ANSWER.PARA: About 100,000 people are in institutional care around Australia, and my advice is that about 57,000 of those do have some degree of brain failure. Some of them will need institutional care, and it may be that a number of them could return to a domestic environment. A series of programs around Australia receiving Commonwealth support assist voluntary organisations and State governments to provide services for people who are at home. These services have significantly expanded over recent years. I am not in a position to give the honourable senator a precise figure as to the cost of those domiciliary services as against the cost of the services provided through institutions. It is argued that domiciliary services are a more economical way of providing services for the aged, but to date I have not seen what I would regard as any really hard evidence as to just where the cost advantage lies. All the information I have received has tended to concentrate on what seemed to be a social advantage in providing domiciliary rather than institutional care.

The honourable senator raises a matter which I regard as being of some complexity. I assure him that the report put out by the Social Welfare Research Centre funded by the Commonwealth is one which is receiving attention. Indeed, the whole area of care for the aged is receiving attention both from government, private organisations and the Parliament. At the moment there is an inquiry by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure into the general area of care for the aged. This Committee may pick up this particular area of inquiry. May I assure the Senate that we will look at this whole area with very great care.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question which is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy concerns the future of uranium mining in Australia. Has the Minister noted several recent Press reports from various parts of the world stating that the spot price of yellowcake or uranium oxide has fallen over the last two years from $43 to $25 per lb, that it is predicted that the price will fall as low as $20, that the world market is grossly oversupplied with this commodity and that this state of major oversupply can be expected to continue perhaps for some decades? Is the Minister aware that last month Number One ore body at Jabiluka which Pancontinental Mining Ltd proposes to mine for uranium was a metre under water and that these flood waters cleared only slowly through the East Alligator River, which passes through the Kakadu National Park, due to daily tidal backup in the river? In view of the state of the world uranium market and the environmental risks to the Kakadu National Park of contaminated water from underground mining will the Government take whatever steps are necessary to ensure that mining at Jabiluka does not proceed? If mining does proceed will Pancontinental be required to provide adequate bunding to keep back flood waters? Will the Government ensure that sufficient sums of money be deposited by the company in advance to ensure that in the event of its ceasing production or encountering financial difficulties funds are available for environmental rehabilitation of the mine areas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen a variety of reports regarding the variation in prices of yellowcake and uranium generally. What has happened has been the result of both waves of optimism and waves of pessimism. Perhaps neither of these reactions is right. Certainly, I doubt that the wave of pessimism at this moment will be justified by future events.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that in the energy crisis due to the oil shortage there has been a stand-off; nations have been slow to look towards alternative fuels, slow to make coal contracts and slower to move towards nuclear power generation. France is the exception because it will generate some 50 per cent of its electric power by 1985. It is my judgment, I believe supported by others in the community, that in the years and decades ahead the world outside will not be able to find its alternative energy in coal and gas; there will be a significant increase in the demand for uranium and enriched uranium and that in fact there will be markets for Australia in the decades ahead. That is a judgment that can be made only by individuals. It may well be that changes will take place.

It is certain that western Europe would want to go strongly towards the use of uranium. The shipping, logistics and the infrastructure of coal are so enormous as to make it almost prohibitive. The environmental damage including radioactivity increases, resulting from the huge increases of coal production, must be borne in mind. The pollution from coal will be such that this in itself will constitute very severe health problems.

Having said that I am well aware that the conjunction of the Alligator Rivers constitutes a flood plain. Indeed, the whole of the escarpment leading down from Mount Brockman has created alluvial leaching which has provided the uranium deposits. I am equally aware that over the millennia the waters have run over those deposits; that the Aboriginal people, animals, bird life and fish life have fed from those areas without harm.

I am also aware that the provisions under the law for the development of mining are such that each of the rivers and their run-off will be monitored daily by the Supervising Scientist and that there will be the strictest safeguards against contamination in the waters. Those safeguards will be insisted upon. Therefore, it is our aim to ensure that there will be no contamination of the beautiful and unique Kakadu National Park. Those sanctions apply to Pancontinental Mining Ltd in its development of Jabiluka and to all uranium mining. We will insist on the highest standards. The penalties are strong against any company that attempts in any way, wittingly or unwittingly, to breach these arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question.
