DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Button proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the national government to ensure that the Australian people adequately share in the ownership, employment and revenue associated with resource development.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last few weeks, and indeed months, the Senate both at Question Time and in debate has discussed a number of issues related to the so-called resources boom. In fact it was only a fortnight ago that Senator Carrick, I think, paid us the supreme and somewhat patronising compliment when he said that the discussion of a resources boom was healthy. If it was unhealthy I think we need not be here any more because that situation would be rather dangerous for us. It is healthy and it is in that context that we want to proceed with this matter of public importance and discuss the questions arising from the resources boom.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course we believe that one of the first things to do is to proceed from a basis of reality rather than fantasy. The fantasies have been in the minds of the Ministers such as Senator Carrick, who from time to time gets carried away, but who at other times deals with the problem with the utmost reality. There have also been fantasies in the minds of people such as the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch), when from time to time he has estimated the size of the resources boom for media purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you referring to the $33 billion as a fantasy?

—The figure varies depending on his mood of expansiveness, but we could take that figure today for the purposes of discussion. The factors which will bear on and determine the real figures are perhaps not capable of projection by Government Ministers with the same degree of confidence as has been shown in the past. Some of the factors which will determine the size of the real figures involved in the resources boom will depend on considerations such as the fact that some projects are mutually exclusive. For example, if one goes ahead it is likely that a competing one will not. Secondly, many projects are unlikely to eventuate until well after Sir Phillip Lynch's timetable because, for example, of long delays between approval and construction. Thirdly, with United States of America having a depressed economy at the moment and with Japan having a slower rate of growth, international growth rates do not look particularly promising. Fourthly, there will be as a limiting factor, one believes, an inability of the States to provide infrastructure and, notably, electricity.

SPEECH.PARA: In looking at how big the boom will really be we should look at a variety of views on this subject and try to reach some rational assessment-a health assessment, if I can use the Minister's terminology-of it. The Australian Industries Development Association, for example, stated that Mr Lynch's Department has 'considerably overstated the degree and pace of the impending boom'. In answer to the Minister's interjection of a minute ago, I say that the two factors-degree and pace-are very important in looking at the matter in a given period. Certainly, it is the view of the AIDC that the Minister has overstated the degree and pace of the impending boom.
The Government's own interdepartmental committee on economic strategy has commented on the forecasts of Mr Lynch's Department of Industry and Commerce as follows:
. . . a plausible assumption might be that investment in mining would grow at about three-quarters of the rate implied by current departmental estimates.

That committee is setting growth a little lower than, a little differently from, the overblown Mr Lynch. The other factor which I think is important is that caution should be exercised in estimating the scale of a boom, not in any sense out of carping or simply to expose the Government's exaggerations but for very real reasons. That is to say, caution is desperately important in planning, so that we can derive as much as possible in terms of employment and benefits to local manufacturing. Secondly, it is important in terms of the provision of infrastructure and planning. This will amount to as much as 18 per cent of the total investment projected in terms of the resources boom. Present tentative estimates are that public investment infrastructure for resource developments will amount to $2,500m between 1980 and 1985 alone. Once again, the Government is shown to be operating in an ad hoc manner with only a vague notion of long term planning in respect of infrastructure expenditure. We only place these notes of caution on record. We do not in any sense try to detract from the enormous significance and size of a resources boom. We just utter some words of caution in respect of some of the claims which have been made and point to some of the factors which may inhibit those most exaggerated claims.

Of course, the benefits to this country of a resource boom will be very considerable. First of all, there will be benefits in terms of income, provided there is an adequate distribution of income in this country. There will be benefits in terms of improved living standards. There will be benefits in terms of employment, although once again we argue that these are vastly over-estimated. The number of jobs that will be created from the mineral boom by the mid-1980s on what in our view are the best estimates, is about 60,000, according to the paper from the Department of Industry and Commerce. I am speaking of direct employment. That estimate has to be compared with the current unemployment figure of 420,000, according to Commonwealth Employment Service statistics, and an expected work force growth to the end of 1985 of 575,000. So some over-emphasis has been given to the benefits in terms of direct job creation. Such over-emphasis has been given during past election campaigns, for example, when the resources boom has been mooted as the answer to all the Liberal Party's prayers. It has been used to get it off the hook in relation to the sorts of things which it had undertaken to deal with. Perhaps we can now look at the matter more soberly.

I think it is fair to say that a large number of jobs will be created indirectly, but in our view that number is unlikely to exceed 150,000 and they will not be maximised under the policies of the present Government. I wish to explain why we believe that job maximisation, if I can call it that, will not occur under the policies of the present Government. The first factor is the lack of planning, which has been quite apparent. There has been a lack of planning and relationship between various arms of government policy. For example, there is an article in one of today's newspapers-I do not have it directly in front of me-about the undersupply of geophysicists in Australia. The undersupply is estimated to be something like 1,500, yet the resources boom has been foreshadowed for a significant period. Such a failure may be ascribed to the universities or the advanced education system. It is also the result of the failure of the Government to recognise, for example, the relationship between resource development and education policy, as well as the relationship between manpower policies generally and resource development.

We say that job maximisation will not occur, secondly, because of the excessive foreign ownership and control of resources in Australia. Profits will go overseas. There will be a leakage of funds, as it is called, on the purchase of equipment overseas. Thirdly, this Government is prone to use a credit squeeze to counteract the flood of foreign investment money. That course will dry up funds for business and put marginal firms out of business. Fourthly, there is a shortage of skilled tradesmen in Australia, which again relates very much to education and manpower policies-the sorts of things with which the Williams Committee was to deal and in respect of which little action had been taken. Fifthly, the continued appreciation of the exchange rate will affect the ability of Australian firms to compete. Sixthly, there is an inadequate investment in social infrastructure in Australia in such towns as Gladstone to which we have already referred in discussing the resources boom. Such investment would again be a very important source of job generation, quite apart from the important component of community development and equalisation of the benefits of resource developments. The balance of payments situation will, of course, be improved but the sad thing is that much of the infrastructure for the boom will be inherited. Many problems are associated with such a boom. I have stated some of the benefits, with qualifications, as we see them.

Among the many problems associated with resource booms are structural adjustment pressures. Again, there will be pressures for the exchange rate to appreciate, for the dollar to be worth more, making imports cheaper and also making it more difficult for Australian manufacturers to export. The Australian manufacturing industry sector is the largest provider of employment in this country. The competitive position of that sector will be undermined. The sad possibility is that those sectors of Australian industry which are least profitable will go to the wall. We cannot draw an exact parallel with the situation with which Great Britain is faced at present, but the pound is exceptionally strong as a result of North Sea oil exploration and that has had a disastrous effect on British exports. The response of the Thatcher Government to that situation has been to restrict the rest of the economy while the exchange rate of the pound has been allowed to shoot up. We fear and give warning that through lack of sensible and flexible economic management this country could get into the same situation. There is a concern to see that the economy get proper stimulation at the appropriate time.

I wish a little later to touch briefly on the question of foreign investment. In the meantime let me say that one of the potential problems is the fact that the Government has encouraged and allowed competitive bidding for projects between the States. There is no national strategy in Australia in relation to the resources boom. I wish to give some examples of that as it is related to the level of export prices. The Federal Government, in our view, must ensure that Australia's interests are protected. One can take the example of the Utah Development Co. which is a foreign company. In 1978 Utah undercut New South Wales producers who were negotiating for contracts with Japan. Last year Utah signed an 8-year contract for coal from Norwich Park at prices which were too low. It is conservatively estimated that it will cost us $250m a year in lost revenue. That is a loss to the whole of the Australian people, which should not be tolerated by a national government which purports to have any form of national strategy on this issue.

In connection with the area of potential problems again I just mention the matter of a resource tax. We in the Opposition believe that there should be a resource rental tax. There should be a review of the over-generous concessions given to the mining industry by the present Government-for example, the exemption from tax of gold mining and gold sales; the application of the investment allowance to the North West Shelf and the accelerated depreciation allowance for mining assets over five years. Another potential problem is the implication for the capital market, including the effect on other sectors of the economy, of drawing away investment into the mining industry. Lastly, another potential problem is the heightened demand for skilled labour.

I will dwell on that matter for just a minute. At the moment there is a lot of talk about the importance and the shortage of skilled labour in Australia. Because the Government is in such a state the whole country seems mesmerised about that matter. The demand for skilled labour will have a tremendous effect on the level of wages in this country. There is no apparent indication at all from this Government of how it will deal with that problem. Apprenticeship intakes collapsed during the first four years of the Fraser Government. The shortages in skilled labour markets could generate wage pressures which could spread to the rest of the economy and generate enormous inflation. That is a possibility which everybody knows about. There is not the slightest response by way of a planned suggestion from this Government as to how it proposes to deal with that issue.

I turn, in the brief time available to me, to two issues: Firstly, the creaming off of money by State taxes and, secondly, the dangers of uncontrolled foreign investment. The national Government of this country should be the principal beneficiary of resources development and not the governments of Queensland, Western Australia or any other State. The national Government of Australia should get the benefit of resources development. The conditions of the Winchester South lease in Queensland, the rail charges and so on, provide that State with its own taxes which rake off millions of dollars. A resource rent tax imposed at the national level would be fairer and would ensure that the whole of this country and all of its people benefit without sectional interests prevailing because of accidents of geography and geology. The difference between a mining company and other companies is that the nation awards a national asset to a mining company to develop a resource. It does not give a manufacturing industry a national asset to develop. Its profitability depends on the initiative of the company concerned and upon the development of resources by the company, not the granting of resources as is done with a mining company.

I come to the second matter of foreign investment. Only Canada exceeds Australia in having foreigners dominating the national economy. I am not being xenophobic about this. I am not saying that we do not need foreign capital in Australia; I am saying that the conditions under which we get it and the terms we lay down are craven and spineless. I refer to such things as infrastructure development, the technology which companies bring with them and no demands being made by the national Government of this country on matters of infrastructure development and technology transfer. Alcoa of Australia Ltd has announced that it will build a caravan park and some houses for the workers at Portland in Victoria and all that is regarded as a great exception. People are saying what a wonderful company Alcoa is because it is going to put a few million dollars into providing houses for workers and a caravan park. That has not happened elsewhere in Australia and it will never happen unless the Government does something about it.

Other countries do not find the same craven disabilities as the Fraser Government finds on the requirement of technology transfer and participation in infrastructure development for the mining industry. Foreign companies now control 55 per cent of our mining industry and 36 per cent of Australia's manufacturing industry. They control 48 per cent of the service sector. It is estimated that transnational corporations have control over 40 per cent to 50 per cent of the Australian corporate sector in its entirety. In some strategic sectors foreign companies control almost 100 per cent. The trend of foreign interest in buying existing Australian enterprises is growing rapidly. Successful Australian companies have been sold off. Foreign investors do not have to start from scratch in Australia. They take over existing enterprises and promptly start remitting profits overseas.

The Foreign Investment Review Board has a pathetic record. Since 1976 when it was established, to the credit of the Fraser Government, the Board has rejected only 45 out of 5,000 proposals which have come before it. More than 3,800 of these proposals were for takeovers of existing Australian companies. The Department of Trade and Resources, in an internal memorandum, warned of speculative capital inflow into Australia and said that this could have an important influence on the balance of payments. The inflow would be based on expectation of an appreciation of the exchange rate of Australian currency. The Australian dollar has already appreciated by 6 per cent in 12 months. So there is an urgent need for a coherent policy to control capital inflow at the moment and an urgent need to control it in the long term in the interests of technology transfer, infrastructure development and so on.

The leakage of funds overseas from Australia to import capital equipment for mining ventures is important. Thirty per cent of the projected sums to be spent in the mineral resources boom will be spent overseas and not in Australia. Fifty per cent of the money for aluminium developments in the Hunter Valley will be spent overseas and not in Australia. Fifty per cent of the North West Shelf moneys, $2,000m of the $4,000m, will be spent overseas and not in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The subject we are discussing is important. I welcome its being debated. We are dealing with the prospective resources boom in Australia and the motion before us reflects upon ownership, employment and revenue. The resources boom in Australia comes about for two reasons. Firstly, it is because of the unhappy circumstance of a world that is energy hungry. Fortunately for Australia it is, in most of its resources, energy rich. Secondly, and most importantly the resources boom comes about because Australia, in terms of its inflation and its general economic picture, is in a very favourable trading situation compared with the rest of the world. Our inflation rate is very significantly below that of our trading partners. Perhaps I can rely on help from two sources to describe the present situation. The first source is a comment by Mr Ross Gittins, the economics editor of the Sydney Morning Herald who, in an article appearing in the National Times of 15 February this year, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The economy is expanding quite strongly, with real incomes growing, consumer spending buoyant, and business investment booming. Unemployment is on the up and up and there are signs that unemployment is starting to drop a fraction.

That is what Mr Gittins said. In case that is regarded as partisan, I shall quote what the Minister for Industrial Development and Minister for Decentralisation in the Wran Labor Government, Mr Day, said in his Department's most recent publication entitled: 'Development Projects in New South Wales-Australia'. He said:
Despite continuing problems on the world economic scene, there is cause for an optimistic view of the future for Australia.
He goes on to quote, support and not deny, as does the Federal Labor Party, the findings of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. He continued:
Australia can look forward to a brighter 1981 than most major industrialised countries in the West, according to the . . . OECD.

The statements I have quoted come from two experienced persons. The resources boom has occurred because of a world outside that is hungry. We have a responsibility to develop our resources to meet that hunger so that living standards in the world outside will not fall and so that there will not be political instability. In developing these resources our primary objective is the uplifting of the living standards of the people of Australia consistent with the true conservation of our resources for the generations ahead.

I will continue to show-this has been diagnosed-that a most exciting time is ahead of us. The New South Wales Labor Government will act as a text en route to refute just about everything Senator Button has said in his description of fantasy. Every claim that this Government has made concerning future investments, participation and employment is multiplied very considerably by the claims of the Wran Government. That, I think, ought to be kept in perspective. I will deal with this aspect now and will turn to more important things later. Senator Button's original thesis was that the Government had talked in fantasies about the projected investment of $33 billion in Australia. He said that such investment would not come to pass. The booklet, over the signature of Mr Day, states:
The total value of investment projects reported in this booklet--
The booklet relates to New South Wales-
is in excess of $23,000m.

That figure is for New South Wales alone and is on parallel with investment of about $70 billion for Australia. The New South Wales Government publication does not mention the figure of 60,000 jobs in Australia to which Senator Button referred but states:
Employment opportunities expected to be created in relation to projects in the committed and final feasibility stages, where such information is available, total approximately 50,000 jobs.
That figure relates to New South Wales projects which are committed and in the final feasibility stage. Against a cautious figure of 60,000 jobs in Australia, Mr Day's publication continues:
Most of the employment opportunities reported are expected to occur between 1981 and 1985.
It then said:
These data relate to direct employment only and do not include the increased indirect employment likely to be generated in supplier industries, etc.

If one relates the ordinary multiplier for Australia to the figure of 50,000 jobs the projection, instead of a cautionary 60,000, is for about 170,000 jobs. The booklet, referring to major projects, then states:
In addition at least 22,000 jobs are represented by major projects which are in preliminary study or possible stages.

That statement not only destroys what Senator Button has said but also paints a picture which is stronger by far in every one of its categories than what has been put forward by this Government. I suggest that the Government has put forward modest figures. I stress that I am reading from a publication of the New South Wales Government which is produced over the Minister's signature.

Let me now take each situation as it comes. First of all, the matter of public importance relates to ownership. The Fraser Government and not the Labor Government which preceded it set up the Foreign Investment Review Board. The Labor Government did nothing in that regard at all. The Fraser Government said that particular guidelines should be set for certain projects. It said that for uranium, the aim should be an Australian investment of 75 per cent and that for other developments there should be a majority Australian equity. These guidelines were frontier work in Australia. We were laying down the principle that Australians should have the major equity in the development of Australia. We have proceeded along that course.

Let us look at the investment in Australia by ordinary Australians. Australia's reinvestment of its savings has been second only to that of Japan in past years. The great insurance companies, such as the Australian Mutual Provident Society and the Mutual Life and Citizens' Assurance Ltd are putting the premiums paid by their policy owners into development. The whole of their Australian equity is going into Australian development. A large percentage of the shareholdings in the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd are owned by superannuation funds and provident funds. The 5 million or 6 million shareholders in BHP, CSR Ltd and the other great companies of Australia can be demonstrated to be actively engaged in the development of Australia. I do not include fixed and multiple trusts that also create development in Australia. We are setting down ownership provisions that are quite clear. People should not be frightened of them.

Let me make some remarks about foreign capital coming into Australia. The United States of America was built out of foreign capital. Capital from Britain, France and Germany literally invaded the country in the past decades. The people of America said that they would be taken over by foreign capital. That is nonsense. Any strong government with a national sense of responsibility can ensure that the capital and know-how works for the people as it did for America. America became great because it searched the world not only for money but also for top technology. Along with foreign investment comes high technology. What nonsense-in fact, what gall-it is for Senator Button to say that we have done nothing about insisting upon arrangements for technology. Has he read of our most recent decision concerning National Semiconductor Incorporated and our insistence that if the company is to come to Australia it has to bring with it the highest technology and to share it with Australians? Yet, out of his mouth come gross errors. Of course along with the capital of the world comes absolutely high technology. When that capital comes great platforms will be built in Bass Strait and in the North West Shelf. The first platform in the North West Shelf will contain more steel than the Sydney Harbour Bridge. That steel cannot be taken away. It cannot be repatriated to the country from which the capital came.

The oil wells in Bass Strait are part of Australia. The aluminium smelters, the know-how and the technology are part of Australia. We will grow stronger as we take in these people and this technology. As we get higher technology a fundamental thing occurs. The more new plant, equipment and technology that is brought in the stronger will be our basic manufacturing industry. That manufacturing industry has to develop to service and to supply the needs of the projects. I think it was Senator Button who said that there would be an outflow. Let me quote again the New South Wales Government. It said:
It is apparent from these figures that there will be a high degree of local participation in supplying materials, plant and services to construct those types of development projects.
That is the $23 billion-worth. Let us keep that figure in mind, because that is what we are talking about. Mr Day's report went on:

Although the percentage of local and overseas content will vary for individual projects, it is likely that between 70 and 80 per cent of the total capital cost of projects planned in New South Wales will be spent locally.

There the responsible Minister in a government with the facts in front of it-not a dissident and embittered Opposition-is saying that we have $23 billion-worth of investment and that 70 per cent to 80 per cent of it will be spent locally. He went on to say:
Once projects begin production, further multiplier effects can be expected to be generated within the State and national economies from these planned developments.

The picture, as it now emerges, is of foreign capital coming in under the strictest of guidelines-with Australian management, Australian equity and majority Australian partnership-and bringing with it the highest of skills and technology and new opportunities for jobs for our young. As this document demonstrates, 70 per cent to 80 per cent of that capital will be spent in Australia. If we have to bring from abroad some new plant or equipment, what is wrong with that if it creates so many more jobs in Australia? The picture for Australia with regard to ownership is an exciting one of great Australian companies-the BHPs, the CSRs and the AMPs-growing greater in their skills and management, reaching out into the development of Australian resources and bringing great opportunities for Australia. So much for ownership.

I turn now to employment. Mr Day, the New South Wales Minister, says that 50,000 jobs will be directly created in the next four years in New South Wales alone, which means that 150,000 to 170,000 jobs will be created in Australia. Senator Button said that we were exaggerating when we were talking of 60,000 jobs. But Mr Day says that there will be many more than that because the indirect benefits and the multiplier effect will be so great. Where is this question of employment now? Where does the Labor Party's argument stand as a result of a government of its own kidney assessing the situation? When I became Minister for Education I found the technical and further education side of education run down and in a demoralised state, and with the pattern set for a complete scarcity of skilled tradesmen and technicians in Australia. It was the Fraser Government which lifted up technical and further education, gave it equality with universities and colleges, increased its spending massively and gave it a chance to expand its skills. Of course, there is a lead time. It was the Whitlam Government which in fact drove investment away from Australia-drove the rigs away from Australia-and forced people not to go into geology, into mining or into building and architecture. There has been a period in which recovery necessarily had to take place.

I turn to the benefit to Australians. First of all, I must stress that we have in life a major job to reach out to the world at large and to help it wherever we can with energy, whether it be short of coal, gas or uranium. If other countries cannot produce metal by smelting alumina because they are energy hungry, it is our job to provide them with the base metals so that they can maintain their living standards. In doing so we have a fundamental responsibility to Australians to see that the resources in the ground are not squandered, that there is proper conservation, that the environment is maintained, but that the true value of the resources, as they are developed, goes to the Australian people not only in jobs and skills but also in higher education, in a greater ability to provide health and social services and in better roads, houses and bridges. In other words, a tonne of bauxite at Weipa or Gove is as nothing, except in its conservation value, until it is taken out and processed, through alumina, into the metal itself and therefore, becomes of true value to Australia.

It is an instructive exercise to look at the number of people directly and indirectly employed and the number of local government charges and State taxes and charges that are paid along the way. We find that in any dollar of revenue to such companies, between 70c and 90c goes to the creation of jobs or to taxes or charges throughout Australia. It is, of course, the responsibility of government to ensure that excess profits are not shipped out of Australia. The excess profits that are being made by the Esso-BHP partnership in Bass Strait are being ploughed back into coal and shale developments in Australia as well as into the development of new oil wells. It is important to understand that the profits of today are the jobs of tomorrow. It is important that we understand something that the socialists will never understand-that unless there is a healthy profit which can be reinvested we cannot develop new industries and, therefore, we cannot provide more jobs.

It was suggested by Senator Button that we are not planning infrastructure development. He cited Gladstone and said there was no such planning there. I sat with the Gladstone people both in Gladstone and in Sydney and heard from each of the developers and entrepreneurs that they are building proper, fine, high quality and adequate houses with proper environments which they will sell at a moderate cost to their employees. So the development of that housing infrastructure will be of benefit to such people. Of course, mistakes are made. Of course, sometimes excess profits go off-shore and we need to amend our tax laws. I am not saying that everything is right. What I am saying is that with proper management, provided we can keep our inflation low and provided we orchestrate so that we do the right range of right things, we can help people overseas and we can build the kind of Australia which, industrially, in a defence context, in schools and in opportunities for our people, will be unique in the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me assure Senator Carrick that Senator Button has read the material relevant to the National Semiconductor Corporation project and that he has come to the same conclusion as academics, as most businessmen and as anyone who knows anything about high technology; that is, the Government's statement can be summed up as windy rhetoric designed to seduce the ignorant. As Senator Carrick has chosen to mention the increase in the rate of growth in the gross domestic product, which it looks as though we will record in this financial year and the quite significant increase in the absolute level of employment which has taken place in the last 18 months, he ought to be reminded of the reasons that has happened. The improved economic growth of the last year or so is in fact a product of the Fraser Government's repudiation of its own economic policies. The Fraser Government allowed the money supply to overrun substantially-to overrun by 3 per cent or 4 per cent in the last couple of years-its stated growth targets. Consumer spending has increased appreciably because wages have increased by 14 per cent in the last 12 months; and government spending, despite all the windy rhetoric to the contrary, in real terms is up 3 per cent this financial year on what it was in the previous year.

SPEECH.PARA: In all of these areas those policy changes have contributed the major part to the economic growth which has been recorded and in every case they comprise a repudiation of the long-standing policies of the Government. To the degree that the economy is improving, it is improving not because of the Government's stated policies but because in fact the Government has repudiated them. For how long that will continue, of course, remains a matter for conjection. It is also worth noting that the growth of which Senator Carrick boasts has taken place in a period of rising inflation, something which, according to the high tory dogma of the Government, could not happen.

I understand why Senator Carrick chose to quote so extensively from the material of another government on the likely magnitude of the so-called resources boom. He did that because if he had chosen to look at the material produced by his own Government what would have emerged would have been a picture of confusion and discord. Even on such fundamental matters as the level of committed and final feasibility investment we have divergences of almost a factor of two. According to Mr Lynch, $33 billion is involved in that category. According to Mr Anthony it is $19 billion. They, of course, had different objectives when presenting those figures. Mr Lynch, being a veteran of Stumpy Gully, has a penchant for and, on occasions perhaps, even a vested interest in inflating expectations. Mr Anthony, on the other hand, was anxious to soothe the misgivings of his agricultural constituency-that is, those farmers who realise that a large expansion in the export sector, regardless of the source of that expansion, will generate pressures for revaluation of the Australian dollar and lower prices for agricultural products. Mr Anthony said that this was nothing to be worried about because the rate of appreciation of the dollar would not exceed 1 per cent per annum for the next 10 years. Some of the farmers who listened to him no doubt were expected to believe that that meant a reduction of 10 per cent in farm incomes would happen. Of course, it meant no such thing.

Agricultural export prices, in the main, are determined by export parity, whether the product actually is sold abroad or at home. A 10 per cent reduction in gross income or return for the product is, of course, equal to a 25 per cent reduction in net farm income because over the long term net farm income runs at about 40 per cent of gross farm income or the value of production. Reduce the value of sales by 10 per cent and the net income is reduced by 25 per cent.

On the matter of ownership, to which the motion refers, the Government and its tory predecessors have adopted policies of dissipating domestic capital, the most recent and spectacular example of which was the 61 promises pulled out of the hat. Promises either to forgo revenue or to increase expenditure were pulled out of the hat on the eve of the last election. These promises involved projects so diverse as a $2m motor racing track for Canberra-that was made in the vain hope of saving Mr Haslem's seat-or a $500m railway for somewhere else which had no hope of ever paying its way. It firstly dissipates domestic capital in that way and then allows eccentric and authoritarian State governments secretly to hand over resources to companies which are not only foreign but also are owned by foreign governments.

We see such self-professed opponents of public ownership as the Premiers of Western Australia and Queensland gleefully handing over mineral deposits to consortiums of which the British Petroleum company is a member. Most recently, of course, there were the Winchester South and prior to that the North West Shelf projects in which BP again has a major equity. BP, ironically, is 46 per cent owned by the government of the United Kingdom. Sir Charles Court, at the same time as he was asserting that no investment authority established by an Australian government would be allowed to contribute equity or to participate in mining development projects in Western Australia, was welcoming a consortium which included BP which not only is foreign but also is owned by a foreign government. The attitude of these two eccentric premiers is that Australian government ownership or participation in resource development projects is forbidden but that foreign government ownership is welcomed.

One could speculate on whether, under the regime of one Ian Smith who was formerly admired by both of these premiers, that policy would amount to economic treason which, incidentally, was a crime in Rhodesia under the Smith regime. It was a regime greatly admired at that time by Mr Bjelke-Petersen and Sir Charles Court, although I should imagine that, given the uncertainty about the Commonwealth Games in Brisbane next year, Mr Bjelke-Petersen would be less eager to express publicly his admiration for the Smith regime than he was a few years ago.

I refer now to interest rates. It has recently become apparent from a wide variety of sources that the prevailing interest rate for overdrafts above $100,000 is 16.5 per cent. This is without precedent. In no previous credit squeeze have interest rates approached that level. It is not entirely due-indeed at this stage not very much of it at all is due-to the resources boom. The interest rate problem has been exacerbated by previous governmental manipulation of the money market to achieve political goals which were laid down by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), a task in which it was assisted by a disgracefully compliant Reserve Bank and now, of course, by the reapplication of crude monetarist dollar dogma.

The Government has got the country's money market into such a mess now, before the resources boom has even properly got under way, that interest rates have risen to unprecedented levels. The mind boggles at the prospects of what will happen in the future unless the Government can improve to a very substantial extent on its past record in this area. But the main point I wish to talk about is the reference in the motion moved by Senator Button to ensuring that the revenue associated with resource development is adequately shared by the Australian people. High tory dogma, and possibly the naked pecuniary interest of the National Country Party, has locked the Government into a ridiculous position, a position of unequivocal rejection of a resources rent tax. A resources rent tax is supported by such luminaries as John Stone, the Secretary to the Treasury, who is normally regarded as a high tory dogmatist himself. If John Stone is too progressive for the Government, where does that place the Government. He was supported implicitly only yesterday by a Japanese steel magnate, Mr Tanabe, who was reported in the Canberra Times yesterday, amongst other newspapers. Mr Stone was supported by and reported in the Melbourne Age of 30 March by Dr Susan Bambrick, once suspected by many people of being a mouth-piece for the mining interests. The article in the Age states:
An adviser to the Federal Government has predicted a special resources tax on foreign mining companies.

Dr Susan Bambrick said at the weekend that such a tax appeared inevitable and necessary because Australia did not have adequate control over certain aspects of the industry, such as foreign ownership and Tax avoidance.

Every academic economist in the country who is not actually a prisoner of corporate interests advocates a resources rent tax. Of course, a resources rent tax has long been advocated by the Australian Labor Party. A resources rent tax is supported by every numerate person who has ever taken the trouble to think about it. In the Government parties-I exclude from this consideration the bagmen in the Government parties-there are, among those who do not support it, the innumerates, for whom presumably there is no hope, and those who have not thought about the matter. For the benefit of those in the latter category I will explain why they should think about it and why they should support it. The Government's existing policy is doubly vulnerable. Firstly, absolute tax levels in some instances are demonstrably too low-I will say more about that later if I have time-and secondly, it applies the wrong type of tax to resource projects, whether they are Commonwealth or State taxes. All those who mine resources pay royalties to governments. Royalties are related to the quantity extracted.

A royalty is a tax on production and a resources rent tax is a tax on profit. The essential difference is that one taxes production and the other taxes profit. Quite independently, at the level of taxation which is applied, a resources rent tax is more efficient. The reason it is more efficient in economists' jargon is that under a resources rent tax by definition there is no tax on marginal production, and again that is regardless of the absolute level of taxation. But to put it in terms which are more readily understood I will cite an actual example. In round figures Australian crude oil is sold to refineres at $30 a barrel. Again in round figures, of that $30 about $8 is distributed to the producers and $22 goes in taxes to governments, overwhelmingly to the Federal Government. The average cost of producing that oil which is sold for $30 is something less than $2 but the price for oil from some individual fields is significantly higher and for all fields it will get higher as they approach the end of their production life. When the cost of producing from any of those fields rises above the $8 that is currently received by the producers production will cease. Oil producers are not philanthropists. There is no reason to expect that they will be. While they receive only $8 they will not produce oil that costs them more than $8 to extract. We will then be in the ridiculous situation in which oil which has a market value of $30 a barrel and a production cost of $9 a barrel will be left in Bass Strait, or wherever it happens to be lodged, because of this foolish taxation policy which the Government is applying.

In the few seconds remaining to me in this debate let me cite as another scandalous inadequacy of the Government's present policy, the situation at the Fortescue field from which under present Government policy Esso-BHP will pick up windfall gains in excess of $1 billion. There is an argument which can never be satisfactorily resolved about whether it is new or old oil. If we had a resources rent tax the argument about whether it is new or old oil would be completely irrelevant.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The resources boom current in Australia is due not only to the favourable natural resources that our country possesses but also to the extremely sound economic policies that are being pursued by the Fraser Government at this time. The framework in which inflation is actually coming down provides an environment in which sound investment decisions can be made. I emphasise the words 'sound investment decisions'. In addition, we have relatively stable exchange rates. These features are not common to other parts of the world which have natural resources. I think we must examine the reasons for the resources boom in the context of a deliberate and cultivated Government policy that is directed to maximising the economic welfare of Australia to the great benefit of Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the features of the resources development boom is that it is also taking place outside major metropolitan areas. It is taking place outside the traditional resources States of New South Wales and Victoria, the States which have benefited from most of the booms in the past. As the population and support industries have been centred largely in New South Wales and Victoria it does come as something of a shock to those States to find that there is now a degree of voluntary immigration to the resources rich States of Queensland and Western Australia. I think it appropriate that the Government reassess some of the financial arrangements. In the past New South Wales and Victoria have been regarded as standard States but as the increased revenue derived from the boom flows into the Treasury coffers of Western Australia and Queensland these arrangements may need to be re-examined. There are developments at Groote Eylandt, Gove, the North West Shelf and Weipa. As a consequence of the development of these sites and the movement of large numbers of people to these previously desolate areas there has been a tremendous improvement in communications and facilities. For strategic reasons I think this improvement in communications in what previously were non-populated areas is important for Australia.

The Opposition, which has proposed for discussion this matter of public importance, fails to recognise some of the Government's achievements in managing resource development. Let me refer to some of the safeguards which this Government has developed, such as the Foreign Investment Review Board guidelines, for example. I think all honourable senators are aware, ever since I became a member of this place, that I have been very conscious about the need for Australian equity in foreign operations in Australia not necessarily only in resource companies but also in companies which provide everyday foodstuffs to Australians. This Government does have a sound policy, as enunciated in the Foreign Investment Review Board guidelines, in that there must be at least 50 per cent Australian equity in any project involving investment expenditure exceeding $5m-other than in the uranium industry in which an Australian equity of 75 per cent is required. In respect of exploration companies, as Senator Carrick mentioned yesterday, these guidelines do not apply. But as soon as development starts, in other words when the field has been proved, these investment guidelines come into play. The Government does realise that in some circumstances it is not always possible to get the vast amount of money from financial institutions around Australia that is required to develop our resources and where the Government is satisfied that an investment project cannot attract 50 per cent Australian equity and provided it will substantially contribute to the economic stability of Australia, it may proceed. The main point in relation to foreign investment is that over time the Australian equity will increase. I think this is an important point. I think Australia is indeed a lucky country.

The boom, as I mentioned, is with us. We do not have to wait for two or three years. For example, in 1979-80 the number of foreign investment proposals submitted to the Government increased by 40 per cent and expenditure in approved natural resource development proposals rose from $716m in 1978-79 to $2,380m in 1979-80. This gives some indication that the boom is with us now and that Australia is benefiting very much from this interest in investment in Australia. But our Government is not interested in investment at any cost; we are concerned in such matters as environment, foreign ownership, pricing policies and taxation. It is true that the private sector will tend to benefit most from this investment boom. For example, surveys carried out on 14 January 1981 by the Department of Industry and Commerce list 306 projects which were at the committed or final feasibility stages. These projects totalled $33 billion. This figure is double that which appeared in a similar schedule submitted by that Department in October 1979. So it is the increasing trend of Australian investment in overseas corporations which are investing in Australia which is significant. In the black coal industry, for example, current foreign ownership is 40.3 per cent, and it is expected to fall to 35 per cent.

Let me take one example-I will use coal again-to show the significance and importance of what the investment boom is meaning to Australia. Federal and State governments do benefit very significantly from this revenue. For example, average mine workers in New South Wales earn about $400 a week as a result of coal exports from New South Wales. Most of this is spent in the local community in which the various miners live. State and Federal Treasuries benefit by about $9 per tonne from coal exported, or nearly 30 per cent of total export income. On top of this, a wide variety of charges are imposed by local and State authorities, including rail freights and loader hire facilities. So there is a heavy cost burden on these miners. In fact, it has been reported that seven of the 13 coal exporting companies actually incurred losses. There is a myth that all these companies are exploiting Australia and are making huge profits. We have to look not only at some of the losses incurred, say by the coal miners, but also at some of the modest profits by the large miners in relation to their invested capital.

A question was raised about royalties and resource rent taxes. I think we have to look at these two things together. We must be very careful in advocating high royalty rates that we do not actually drive out the more marginal type of operation. One of the problems experienced by Jamaica was that it set too high a royalty rate and the companies basically went elsewhere. I believe this is one of the problems being faced by my State of Tasmania at this time. The Government is not quite as sensitive in this area as I believe it could be and, as a result, certain feasibility studies that should be under way are not going on.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the State government, Senator?

—Yes, I meant the State Government. I think it is significant that there are projects that could proceed if we had a more realistic royalty-type basis. But there are problems with fixing royalty rates too high because different grades of ore or material are extracted. A uniform royalty rate essentially must be low; otherwise, more marginal operations are driven away and, I submit, these are probably the ones that we would like to try to develop because essentially they are in the more decentralised areas. We only have to look at Canada's experience where a combination of high royalty rates and resource rental taxes resulted in an almost complete exodus of many of the mining companies from that country. I submit that we must learn from the experience and wisdom of other countries.

SPEECH.PARA: People say that they advocate resource rental taxes. This tax may be okay if there is not also the imposition of a whole host of other taxes, such as company taxes, payroll taxes, export levies, royalties, lease permit fees, dividends and interest, withholding tax, et cetera.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you replace the lot with a resource rent tax?

—If we were to impose a resource rent tax as suggested by my colleague Senator Walsh, essentially that tax would have to go on to profits. Most of those who advocate resource rental tax refer to cash flows. Senator Walsh's analysis fails to recognise payments such as interest, royalties and the like which flow out. Had Senator Walsh examined this idea a little more closely he would apply his philosophy on resource rental tax not to profits but to cash flows as such. What he fails to recognise is that we cannot have this sort of tax imposed on an operation that is already heavily taxed by way of company taxes, sales tax, payroll taxes and so on. The other factor that the advocates of resource rental taxes fail to recognise is that these profits are not earned uniformly. We all know that prices are subject to major fluctuations in metal prices around the world and, because of this, mining companies have to build up adequate reserves in Australia. I submit that a lot of these profits are very modest by world standards.

SPEECH.PARA: What we in Australia have to do is to make sure that foreign companies that operate here pay tax on a realistic Australian base. If we get that right we need not worry about resource rental taxes. Evidence given to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, which was looking into this question, showed that some of these foreign companies are probably not paying the income tax that they should be paying. Whilst many of my colleagues on the Opposition benches deplore the profits that are earned by Alcoa of Australia Ltd, that company does not concern me. The companies that concern me are those which produce in Australia and sell to their operators overseas at cost, and possibly do not pay a true amount of tax. What are we doing about it? Our Federal Treasurer is updating section 136 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which deals with transfer pricing. Under the new provision I believe that ultimately many of these foreign companies will be paying very much more tax in Australia.

Foreign investment in Australia is contributing very substantially to our foreign exchanges. In fact, 74 respondents to an Australian Mining Industry Council survey-a very large coverage in the mining area-reported overseas earnings from Australian sources of $3,800m. The export sales represent 67 per cent of total sales and represent a tremendous increment to Australian revenue. Interest and dividends remitted equal 8 per cent of total sales. So these companies involved in the mining industry, I submit, are contributing a significant part in the overall economic development of Australia. They are conscious of environmental matters and our Government is conscious of environmental matters. Look at our intervention in relation to Fraser Island. I submit that overall our country is going to be very much better off, the standard of living for the bulk of our people will improve and equality will be achieved through a system of reimbursement grants from the richer States to the poorer States. By that method the benefits of the resources boom will be distributed evenly right throughout the whole of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with pleasure to support the matter of public importance raised by Senator John Button. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: the failure of the national government to ensure that the Australian people adequately share in the ownership, employment and revenue associated with resource development.

I give my support in the knowledge that the Australian Labor Party is not supporting some extreme stand. It does not call for anything more than the proper, clear sighted national advantage to be secured by such a management of this resources boom that business enterprises can operate profitably within Australia, but in a way which respects our economic sovereignty and does not imperil the rights of Australian people to share in the wealth and the employment that one hopes will be generated as these resource projects get under way. In the response of the Minister nothing to allay the concern of the Labor Party emerged. No strategy has been outlined whereby the national Government has indicated that it sees a need to co-ordinate this major resources development. There is no strategy for even some sort of supervisory or co-ordinating role, let alone direction or management concerning the time and pace of the development being undertaken by the national Government. We have nothing that would indicate that there is anything more going on in Australia than a very confused, competitive scramble between State and Territory governments to secure major investments, in many instances using foreign capital and technology. The Federal Government has a sort of craven attitude-if not craven, one of gratitude-toward all that is happening and a hope that the benefits will trickle through to the Australian people.

The Labor Party believes that the investment, employment and revenue sharing policies of the national Government are not adequate to ensure that these benefits really do accrue to all Australians wherever they might live. Senator Watson in his speech, which as usual was marked by clarity and integrity of thought, mentioned that there has been a move in Australia away from the old base of the south-east to the new resources rich States of Queensland and Western Australia-a move of wealth and consequent political power. What the honourable senator did not advert to and what the Minister and the Government refuse to advert to are the consequences of this. It is recognised by all Australians with any fair-minded ability to read newspapers that the premiers of those States and perhaps the ethos of those States are fundamentally opposed to national cohesion. A disintegrating influence is going on in which I believe those State economies are purposely being integrated more and more into the designs of multinational capital and overseas markets without a concern for the Australian nation as a whole. I do not believe one has to be ideologically pure nor does one have to be involved in some sort of jingoistic nationalism to make that sort of comment. I must say though that when one sees the golden fleece the symbol, par excellence, of Australia being overtaken by the Caltex star one has a symbolic representation of what is at the root of the concern of the Labor Party in raising the matter of public importance.

I will very briefly look at the areas of concern. To start with, I will deal with investment. Of course, the tremendous marshalling of capital necessary to ensure these projects develop on the huge scale required will demand a degree of foreign participation. Only in that way can we obtain the technology required and, indeed, the very access to overseas markets which is involved, for example, with the highly integrated aluminium industry. The Labor Party remains unconvinced that the Australian people through their corporations or public institutions are being given a fair enough share in these developments in supplement to foreign investment capital and overseas borrowings. We can see the situation. President Marcos of the Philippines described the situation back in December 1980. As reported in a newspaper article at that time, he said:
'Japan and the others' are beginning to control Australia's natural resources, . . .
'I don't care what excuses you give, the truth is that very soon you will lose control.'

That was a statement by President Marcos of the Philippines. Normally it would not give me any pleasure to quote from the President of such a regime. This is a perception of the Australian situation shared I believe, by many Australians; we are being overtaken by foreign capital. It seems to the Labor Party that certain simple steps need to be taken to ensure that the constant purchasing of Australian resource developments projects by overseas corporations with the consequent remitting of capital overseas should be lessened or modified.

I am speaking somewhat in the dark. I am doing so because, of course, the national Government has refused for three or four years to collect the necessary statistics to enable the Australian people to speak with any precision as to the penetration by foreign corporations into the Australian business, trading and commercial scene. It will be recalled that the special section set up in the Bureau of Statistics to monitor the penetration by overseas corporations of the Australian commercial and trading scene was disbanded some four years ago by the Treasurer (Mr Howard). One of the first tasks which the Labor Party will undertake when elected to government in 1983 to get a proper understanding of this area will be the re-instatement of the statistics section.

The work of the important Foreign Investment Review Board has already been commented on quite adequately by both Senators Button and Walsh. I wish to put something positive forward because I think this is as much the purpose of an Opposition as it is to point out the defects of government policy. We believe it is very important that ordinary Australian householders be given an opportunity to participate in the resources development projects taking place. It is not good enough that already well established major Australian enterprises such as CSR Ltd and the Broken Hill Proprietory Co. Ltd take their place in this particular development; it is not good enough even that the pension funds or the insurance companies, as was pointed out by Senator Carrick, marshal the moneys contributed by ordinary Australians to those funds. What is needed is some sort of unit trust whereby ordinary Australian householders can contribute their hundreds of dollars to a true investment in Australia's resource projects so that more money would be returned to them than they would get by merely holding their savings, for example, in ordinary banking accounts. Some sort of project, perhaps a resource development fund, needs to be developed.

I thought of the term 'Resource Australia' as a title whereby funds can be mobilised from small investors. This is not only so that Australian equity can be increased in the various resource projects under way but also to overcome what I believe to be very real political problems facing the country in that more and more Australians are becoming convinced that the economic destiny of our country and therefore to some extent our political destiny is being taken out of our hands with decisions being made by corporations whose interests are not necessarily identical with those of every Australian. The idea is that funds would be mobilised to enable the directors of the fund to purchase equity in these great resource extraction and processing projects. There would be no public subsidy of the fund and the only element of government financial support would be a loan guarantee on borrowings by the fund during its establishment period. As part of the Foreign Investment Review Board's program of vetting applications by foreign corporations to take part in resource development in Australia it may be that some 10 per cent of every such resource project ought to be offered to such a Resource Australia development fund. In that way the ordinary Australian householder could find some participation in these projects.

That is only one matter of concern to the Australian Labor Party. The other matters mentioned by Senator Button in the debate deal with the inadequate response of the Government to the employment problems generated by the resources boom. We have heard nothing from the Government which gives any guarantee that the skilled labour required by these projects will in fact be forthcoming from the presently unemployed, underemployed or unskilled sections of the Australian labour force. One would not want a situation to develop, as it appears it might well do, whereby the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee) becomes the Commonwealth employment service for the resource project developments we are contemplating. One does not want a situation where Australians living in cities find they have declining standards of living and employment opportunities while other Australians working on these resource projects enjoy not only employment but also employment at a very high wage structure creating a situation of divisions within our society. I believe that the gap between the employed haves working on these projects and receiving site allowances, extra overtime and penalty rates and so on, and the unemployed have nots will create serious tensions within our society. It does not seem that that problem has been addressed yet by the Government. Indeed one finds very little evidence that any consideration at all has been given to other ordinary manufacturing industries such as the metal fabrication industries, engineering industries, even industries within the Public Service where at the moment draftsmen are leaving in droves to go to resource projects. There seems to be no consideration or national strategy by the Government to ensure the continuation of employment opportunities in other areas throughout the Australian economy, given the bidding up of wages by the firms involved in the resources boom.

We also mention in our matter of public importance-I can mention it only in passing, although I must re-emphasise it-that we do not believe that the revenue raising by the Federal Government for the national Treasury so as to disburse the benefits of the resources boom to all Australians has been undertaken with sufficient vigour. Senator Watson contrasted the resources rent tax with the gathering of royalties. He thought that each may have a deleterious effect on investment decisions, particularly in marginal projects. But, of course, the fact is that royalties are particularly clumsy and likely to prevent the sort of investment decisions that Senator Watson speaks of, because they are geared to tonnages and production, whereas the whole merit of a resources rent tax-a merit recognised by the Department of the Treasury, by more and more corporations and certainly by every editorial comment that I have been able to read in the last few months-is that it only applies to profits actually gained. In other words, it is geared to high profitability, which undoubtedly occurs in some situations. If the national Government does not obtain for all Australian people a sufficient taxation return from the development of these projects, then not only will State governments move in-as Queensland has by imposing special rail freight charges and obtaining special funds from developers, as it has from the Winchester South consortium over the last few weeks-but also unions will move in order to obtain very high wages for their workers on these projects. I believe that the national Government, by failing through taxation to secure this wealth for the Australian people, is exacerbating the divisions, tensions and forces of disintegration which politically, I believe, are problems which need to be confronted and faced with a national strategy if we are to get for all Australians the full benefits of the impending resources boom.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maunsell Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: — I believe that the projected resources boom will provide a fascinating future for this country, as all booms have in the past, as long as we are able to take full advantage of it. There is no doubt that the reason why people are investing in this country is the free enterprise political climate that is provided here, our economic strategy and the fact that inflation is lower here than it is in countries that are and could be our competitors in resource development. I can recall the wool boom shortly after World War II and the meat boom in the early 1970s. I cannot recall the rest of Australia not receiving some advantage from increased overseas income resulting from those booms. The whole nation benefited from them, but once those industries suffered a decline the people who felt the effects were those associated with those industries and not the rest of the community.

SPEECH.PARA: Today honourable senators can go into the sheep areas and the beef cattle areas of Australia and find evidence of the many small businesses that have closed up. The declining population in these areas has an effect on the remaining businesses. Therefore, I always believe that the benefits that accrue from resource developments should be put back into the areas from which they came, so that these areas are able to diversify when a slump occurs. This does not happen on most occasions.

Because I am a federalist-not a centralist-I believe that the people of the States should get most of the benefits through money being ploughed back into development areas. I am not even satisfied with what happens in Queensland. A lot of the money that is gained from resource developments through special rail freight rates does not go back into the areas from which it comes. Most of it ends up in the south-east corner of the State, where the bulk of the population is. I believe that if that money was ploughed back through assistance to alternative industries, and improved communications, particularly roads, and other facilities then there would be some sense in this policy that we all subscribe to-the policy of decentralisation. At the moment we are not achieving anything. We have a great opportunity with the resources boom to achieve decentralisation of the Australian population.

I refer to some of the points made by other speakers. All the Australian Labor Party speakers referred to a resources rent tax. I agree that a resources rent tax has a part to play in our economy if, as Senator Walsh said, we could get rid of all the other taxes. I would go along with it too provided that a proportion of it was returned to the States concerned after the Commonwealth, acting as collector on behalf of the States, got its share.

Then we have the problem of who will decide what true profits are. We do not have so much difficulty determining the profits of companies supplying the Australian market but there is difficulty with a company supplying the overseas market especially if it is dealing through a parent company in another country, in which case no world price for the product can be truly calculated. Therefore, I think we have to have other safeguards to make sure that these companies contribute a fair share to the Australian community.

We could institute export controls. Indeed I believe they are absolutely necessary for the development of the aluminium industry. It is impossible for the Taxation Office to assess the price of material being sold by companies to their overseas interests. It does not have the ability to pin the companies down. If we apply export controls we can always say to these companies that unless they explain the position and give us the facts then we will not give them an export licence. Such controls have worked in industries where they have been applied.

I am not opposed to overseas companies investing in Australia when Australia is not able to supply the equity. Millions of dollars are involved in these projects. I agree with Senator Tate that we should encourage as much Australian investment as possible. But if we just do not have the money, I am not that much against overseas investment so long as we get our fair share of the profits and so long as it is controlled.

I have said in this place previously that I regard a nation as being similar to a family. Its standard of living is determined by the breadwinner. As far as this nation is concerned the breadwinner has been the export industries. While we have had export industries and export income coming into this country the standard of living has been high. When we have problems in selling our exports-we have experienced those problems at times-we have difficulties within this country. What we have to do is to ensure that the total amount of the family's income, whether there is one breadwinner or two, is distributed in such a way that everyone benefits. I believe that we should be giving our export industries a lot more encouragement than they are receiving at present. The discouragement is there. Encouragement has always been given to those industries which we set up to produce manufactured goods in particular. Quite a lot of publicity has been given in the last week or so to protected industries which have been given all the help in the world but which cannot compete overseas. They are creating situations which in the long run will be detrimental to the export industries which have to compete on world markets and which have to have a cost structure which enables them to make a profit.

Another angle which I wish to take up is the employment position in these industries. Many people say that they are not high employment generating industries but we usually find that although there may be only a few thousand miners in these mining towns, treble that number of people are required to service them. Then, of course, manufactured equipment is required for the infrastructure. That is not produced locally; it has to be produced elsewhere. That enables the whole of Australia to participate. Also, many of the employees at these mining centres have gone there for a purpose; that is, to make a lot of money in a short time in order to be able to get the requirements of life that they may not have been otherwise able to have for years to come. That money is not spent locally. The new cars, washing machines and other equipment which the employees would not otherwise have had for a few years is not produced locally at the mining site. They are produced in the manufacturing States of South Australia, Victoria and so on.

As I said at the commencement of my speech, we have to ensure that wherever mining developments take place, in remoter areas in particular, we transfer at least some of the benefits of the export income earned back into development in those areas. It would be quite interesting to see what would happen, for instance, if we had a mining venture on an Aboriginal land rights site. We know that the Labor Party's attitude to that would be that the Aboriginals should get the money. I believe the other Australians who live in the Northern Territory and the remote areas of Western Australia and Queensland should also receive benefits from mining ventures. I do not think there was anything in the remarks made by members of the Opposition to indicate that they are against the resources boom. They seem to be going along with it. They are a little concerned about what might happen. I can give the assurance that, the way I see it, this Government will ensure that the Australian people are adequately protected. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
