PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 March, on motion by Senator Carrick:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not intend to oppose the Australian Tourist Commission Amendment Bill. However, we wish to take the opportunity of discussing some of the Government's deficiencies in the area of tourism. No one, least of all a member of a rational party such as the Australian Labor Party, would argue against the need to increase the number of commissioners from nine to 10 or the need to increase the number of Territory resentatives from two to three. However, we would be looking to the Government to redress the imbalance that exists in the Australian Tourist Commission insofar as there are nine male commissioners and one female commissioner. This does not reflect adequately the number of females in the tourist industry, nor does it represent properly community participation in tourism. As long as that state of affairs exists tourism will be the poorer.

SPEECH.PARA: I come directly to the economics of tourism. The most recent and comprehensive report has been put out by the Bureau of Industry Economics. I refer to the fourth research report of that organisation entitled 'The Economic Signficance of Tourism in Australia in 1979'. There is very little doubt that tourism impacts dramatically on our economy. In 1973-74, for example, tourism contributed 2.6 per cent of gross domestic product. It employed 2.4 per cent of the work force and accounted for 3.2 per cent of indirect tax revenue. Those figures have been provided by the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch). They show that tourism is on a level comparable with the motor manufacturing industry and is just behind the mining industry. Whilst we have many debates and many concerns are expressed in the Parliament about the manufacturing industry, the motor industry and the mining industry, I believe as a parliament and as a nation we have failed to appreciate that tourism is a very significant industry in our country.

The Bureau predicts further that by 1985 overseas tourist spending in Australia will rise from the present level of 20 per cent to 40 per cent of total tourist spending. That is the amount contributed by overseas visitors to our country. By 1985, it also predicts, the percentage of people employed in the tourist industry will increase from 2.4 per cent to about 8 per cent of the work force and the industry will create about 60,000 new jobs. Therefore, its contribution to gross domestic product will rise by 80 per cent to about 4.5 per cent of our GDP. When we recognise the decline of the work force in rural Australia, the decline of our work force in manufacturing and the relative decline of the public sector, which this Government has brought about by attempting to reduce public sector employment, we see the tourist industry as one of the few possible growth areas. Consequently, of course, governments and parliaments ought to be concerning themselves with the tourist industry.

A great deal of informed and uninformed debate has taken place about the possible tourist boom. One thing that is certain is that tourism is a prime growth industry and as such Australia-if it is doing its job-ought to be capitalising on that expansion. The fact is, however, that we are quite clearly and dramatically missing the boat. The amount that is now spent in a year in international tourist areas by the millions of international travellers on tourist-related industries is reported to be the staggering figure of $325,000m. That is some six times the annual value of Australia's gross domestic product.

It is clear that we are not grasping the tremendous opportunities tourism offers from the point of view of GDP and employment. The sad fact is that despite that tremendous sum being spent internationally, Australia currently extracts much less than one per cent of all international tourist expenditure. In fact only about 0.3 per cent, a very tiny proportion of the tourist dollar, comes to Australia. The Opposition deplores this. It is an area in which the Opposition believes the Government is wholly deficient. Even in the Pacific area where I would have thought that Australia would be the leader, our share of tourism is dropping. In 1970 our share of tourism in this market was 4.7 per cent. By 1978 it had dropped to 3.8 per cent, showing just how rapidly we were losing out to other Asian-Pacific countries which are much more aware of tourism and which do much more to promote tourism as an industry than we do.

As a result of our failure to exploit the tourist potential of the Pacific area a great many off-shore venues for conventions, seminars, workshops and other events have become a great deal more attractive than Australia. Local tour operators, convention venue entrepreneurs, tourism support industries and the airlines face a great loss of business because of this. For example, we can compare what is offered in those venues with the position in Australia. Leaving from Sydney, a holiday for seven nights with all travel and accommodation expenses paid cost less than $360 in Fiji and less than $300 in New Zealand. But five nights' holiday all-in costs about $400 in Hobart and more than $700 in Darwin. That is about 30 per cent higher than, for example, what it costs to holiday in Singapore.

In the last Budget the Fraser Government set aside for tourism something less than $20m. It is interesting to note that this Fraser Government gets back $10m of that $20m every 12 months in gateway tax; that is, the $10 tax per head the Government collects from people leaving Australia. So the net contribution to tourism was a measly $10m. I mentioned previously that this industry contributes as much as the motor industry. When I look at the hundreds of millions of dollars expended in promoting that industry I wonder why this Government is failing to promote tourism as an industry. It claims it wants growth. Therefore, it has to be prepared to spend and to give a great deal more attention to tourism if it wants to see that growth.

I know that the argument is quite reasonable that without manufacturing industries we would not have as many people in work, we would not have as many people wanting holidays and perhaps tourism would suffer. But I think there is a great imbalance between the $10m that is allocated for tourism and the hundreds of millions of dollars expended in many manufacturing industries. In no way do I want it to be construed that I am criticising the assistance given to our manufacturing industries. I am saying that this Government is neglecting to foster an important industry. It lacks the imagination and the foresight necessary to capitalise on this growing industry. It fails to recognise the potential of the industry and the fact that this is, of course, an industry which can give great pleasure to our community.

Our Government's passive position is not helping to recognise the growth potential of that industry. The whole leisure industry is crying out for the type of leadership that I am referring to and which an entrepreneurial government could give. This Government, which claims to be concerned about private enterprise, is neglecting to take on board the very innovative steps taken by the Labor Government in the years 1972 to 1975. The Bill we are now debating is part of a new-found interest-it might be said by some-by the Fraser Government in the tourist business. But it might well be a case of too little too late. I ask the Government what it did in the tourism area in the years 1975 to 1978. It might be said by some that it was on holidays. If it was on holidays it was doing much better than many other people-the 400,000 people out of work-who could not even afford a holiday.

We constantly hear in this place the Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Carrick, referring to Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries and reports. But according to figures from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development growth in tourism in Australia fell last year. The increase in the number of overseas visitors to our country was 15.9 per cent compared with a growth rate of 25.9 per cent in the previous year. Revenue growth from those tourists also fell. In 1969 the figure was 27 per cent compared with 19 per cent last year. In the same OECD report there is a note of optimism that, as the world economy improves, interest in travel will pick up and so we will see a stronger growth rate in the tourist industry generally. That is in line with predictions previously quoted from the Bureau of Industry Economics report that by 1985 overseas tourist spending in Australia could rise from the present 20 per cent to 40 per cent of the total tourist expenditure.

Will we be geared up for this upsurge of interest in not just travel but the whole spectrum of the leisure industry? In 1972, under the Whitlam Government, the people of Australia saw the advent of the first Federal ministry for tourism and recreation under the direction of the late Frank Stewart and, with it, the recognition that there was a vital role for government to play in this industry. In that time the role of the Australian Tourist Commission was expanded and with it went a brief to step up the promotion of Australia abroad and on the domestic market through the program 'Australia-Land of things to see and do'. By 1975 some $2.34m had been provided in grants and loans for the development of man-made attractions such as Sovereign Hill, Old Sydney Town, Lachlan Vintage Village and Port Arthur.

To the purist, these man-made attractions might seem gauche and almost artificial but they are essential ingredients in any overall tourist strategy. Our heritage, the colonial frontier people that we were, is encapsulated in places such as Sovereign Hill and Old Sydney Town. These places give Australians of today as well as overseas visitors a dioramic view of our past. Of course it is preferable to visit these man-made attractions in conjunction with seeing the real thing. Nowhere is that more evident than in the city of Parramatta. In Parramatta some of Australia's real antiquity exists. Within a radius of half a mile of the city proper there exists a cottage that was built by John Macarthur in 1791. It is the oldest house in Australia. Surely these are matters of great tourist attraction.

I now return to the man-made tourist facilities. We may all rave about the grandeur and beauty of Australia's natural attractions, but the fact is that very few international tourists seek them out. I suspect, therefore, that the cost of domestic air fares, despite the protestations of the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) to the contrary, is the prime reason people are neglecting our far-flung natural attractions. I am supported in my claim that places such as Ayers Rock and the Great Barrier Reef are neglected by overseas visitors by a Qantas Airways Ltd survey conducted of foreign tourists in 1973. This survey revealed, quite disappointingly, that Ayers Rock was visited by a mere 2 per cent and the Great Barrier Reef by only 4 per cent of such visitors. Surely one does not have to stress the wonderful attraction of the Great Barrier Reef. Yet the fact is that we are not able, because of the lack of government promotion and encouragement, to attract the interest of overseas visitors to these very important areas of our Commonwealth.

Whilst it is true to say that the situation may have improved since 1973, it is still evident that most foreign tourists spend their time and money in the capital cities, with Sydney being the most visited. I do not blame them for that. Sydney is a beautiful city. It is one of the most important cities in the world. It is no wonder, therefore, that overseas visitors go there in droves. After all, Sydney has Kings Cross which, in itself, is an important attraction.

Who would deny the employment opportunities created by these man-made operations and the regional job opportunities for people in country areas where employment is at its worst? Also to be considered is the accommodation which springs up around these attractions and with it even more employment opportunities. Tourism and leisure activities filter right through the economic system. The report of the Bureau of Industry Economics concludes by stating:
Tourism is already of considerable significance to the Australian economy with direct or indirect effects on almost every industry.

It has been stated that tourism or leisure, or the two together, make a contribution to all 109 industry groups in Australia. Therefore any Australian government that ignores tourism does so at its peril. Given the evidence of all the economic indicators which show the value of tourism to the national economy, there is an overwhelming argument for the reinstatement of the Department of Tourism and Recreation. Certainly after 1983 when the Australian Labor Party is back in office it will be looking to do just that. By that time the leisure industry will have grown to such proportions that it will not be able to be ignored and, undoubtedly, the struggle of the trade union movement for a 35-hour week will have won a great deal more support in the Australian community.

Let me list some of the reasons why I believe nothing less than a fully operational Federal department is capable of effectively harnessing the existing potentials of the leisure industry. Quite naturally my top priority is employment. In an area of our lives which affects so many other industries a Federal government has a unique opportunity to stimulate the economy and create employment simply by investing in man-made attractions and other types of tourist facilities. Leisure is a very labour-intensive area. The BIE report points out that areas such as restaurants, hotels and clubs are very labour-intensive. I point out to anyone who is interested that the reason New South Wales has the lowest unemployment rate in Australia is, to a great extent, the leisure industry which has been built up. Presently there are 33,000 permanent employees in registered clubs in New South Wales and there are some 100,000 more temporary jobs. It is very unlikely that anybody will ever create a machine that will make beds or serve meals. The beauty of the leisure industry is that it is totally labour-intensive.

While I am on the subject of labour and the leisure industry, I mention the oft-quoted lament that penalty rates inhibit the industry. I will give one example to refute that assertion. A report produced by Roger Kirby, who was then manager of Travelodge Australia Ltd, pointed out that it is a total furphy to suggest that penalty rates are holding back the accommodation industry in Australia. It is wrong. No less a person than Professor Brian Johns, the Director of the BIE, has stated:
The report showed that the prices of tourist services in Australia are not significantly higher than in other developed countries.

Again I quote from a Press release issued by the Minister last year when he was in Tokyo. He cited figures from a world survey conducted by the Economic Research Department of the Union Bank of Switzerland which stated:

Our tourist industry can compete favourably with other alternative tourist destinations around the world . . . The general level of prices in Sydney was ranked lower than those in 33 of the 45 cities surveyed.

The important and most significant part of what I have been saying is that we can provide such competitive prices in the framework of a high living standard. There is absolutely no reason, except a lack of understanding and concern by the Fraser Government, why Australia cannot become a prime country in the whole tourist industry. There is absolutely no reason why Australian workers ought to lower their living standards to attract the tourist dollar. Consequently, there is no reason why any steps should be taken to abandon penalty rates. They were hard won. They are part of our heritage. They will not be lost. Let me conclude by saying that I love our sunburnt country and so would the rest of the world if only the Government would help visitors come and see it. To that extent the Opposition supports the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Gietzelt for giving me some time to speak before the sitting is suspended at 6 p.m. I compliment him on his speech. It was a very thoughtful contribution. The Australian Democrats disagree with him very vigorously in one area. I refer to the question of penalty rates in the leisure or hotel and accommodation industries. In the view of the Australian Democrats penalty rates are, in some cases, crippling the small operator in hotels and restaurants. I will say a bit more about that in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats, along with the Australian Labor Party, support the Australian Tourist Commission Amendment Bill. I feel impelled to speak to it as I had the great honour when I was the Minister-in-Charge of Tourist Activities in 1967 to establish the Australian Tourist Commission. This fairly simple Bill allows for the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory to be represented on the Commission on a rotational basis. We agree with that. After paying the Commission a compliment for doing in general terms a very good job, I may have to be critical. I have the Commission's report for the year 1979-80. The results on the board are quite impressive. For example, in 1978-79 visitors from New Zealand increased by 37.1 per cent, from continental Europe by 36.7 per cent, from the United Kingdom and Ireland by 28.5 per cent, from Japan by 22 per cent, from North America by 20 per cent and from South East Asia by 15.8 per cent. The figures are impressive. I compliment the Commission and I compliment the Government for supporting it. However, it does not mean to say that we could not do better. Tourism, as Senator Gietzelt said, contributes 2.6 per cent of our gross domestic product and is a significant earner of foreign exchange.

I want to make a very strong point about which the Government, advised by the academics in Treasury, seems to be quite myopic. I refer to the matter of refusing to grant a depreciation allowance on hotel buildings. If we really want to attract tourists we must have a first class tourist commission and first class promotional ventures overseas. What is the point of doing that and attracting people from North America and the wealthy parts of Europe if we do not have the proper standard and quantity of hotel accommodation? This is the first lesson to learn in promoting tourism. I am informed that today it costs between $90,000 and $100,000 a room to build a new hotel. The figures are massive. I am not talking about de luxe accommodation; I am talking about first class accommodation which costs $100,000 a room. Assuming that once the hotel is erected there is a 70 per cent occupancy rate, which is a reasonable assumption, and that the owner has borrowed the money to build at a 16 per cent interest rate, the room will cost the owner the staggering sum of $62 a day in interest payments alone before he has to pay wages, direct expenses and overheads. That indicates the massive cost today of building hotel accommodation.

On behalf of the Government, Sir Phillip Lynch has said: 'We have given the hotel industry a building allowance, and that helps tourism'. I dispute that and so does every person who is trying to build a new hotel in this country. The building allowance is only 2 1/2 per cent. If a hotel costs $1m to build, the building allowance is worth only $25,000 as a deduction from profits. Whoever heard of a hotel earning any profit at all in the first three or four years of its establishment? The building allowance to assist developers and builders is almost hopeless. The Democrats believe very strongly that the hotel building ought to be regarded as an integral part of the plant which is earning assessable income and therefore that depreciation on the building should be allowed at 10 per cent to 15 per cent per annum. The loss to the Treasury would be minimal because few hotels are being built at the moment. In any case, the building industry could be stimulated by this action.

After complimenting the Commission, let me now be critical of it. When I had the honour, as Minister, of establishing the Commission I said: 'Please, do not let the bureaucracy take over and spend this precious money the Government gives you in developing offices and high bureaucracies in Australia and around the world'. Unfortunately, I believe that has been allowed to occur. The Commission now employs 76 people on its staff-a rather surprising 45 people in the head office in Melbourne, two in Sydney, five in Los Angeles, six in New York, five in Frankfurt, five in London, four in Auckland, and four in Tokyo. It has offices in eight places throughout the world. One way of promoting tourism is to print shiny brochures and pretty booklets and post them to certain people overseas, to advertise in overseas newspapers, and so on. That does attract a certain market, but other countries have discovered that the only real way to attract tourists is to bring to their countries the wholesale operators from the various markets. Let us bring them here and give them a wonderful time, give them an opportunity to understand the fantastic tourist sights that Queensland, Tasmania and the other States have. Let them see the incredible things that Australia has to offer. Let the wholesale travel agents who market thousands of seats on planes to retail travel agents absorb the unique warmth and beauty that Australia has.

Other countries which have been successful in promoting tourism have used that technique. They have used an essential part of their budgets in that way and not in the production of shiny brochures. Let us imagine the hard-bitten wholesale or even retail travel agent on the West Coast of the United States. Every day in the post must come dozens of shiny brochures and advertising material from every country in the world, trying to attract the West Coast American tourist. How different it would be if in his mail he received an invitation to come to Austalia for a period of ten days, all expenses paid, to sample personally the standard of hotel and motel accommodation we have, the wonders of the world we can exhibit in Australia but, more particularly, to have a personal tour of Australia conducted by officers of the Australian Tourist Commission. I am sure that the various Australian State governments would provide ample assistance to the Australian Tourist Commission for such a promotion. For example, many years ago when I had a small opportunity to involve myself in this area, we said to the Queensland Government Tourist Bureau: 'We are bringing 24 travel agents to Australia. Will you help?' Of course, they jumped at the chance, and they showed the travel agents the things Queensland had to offer-Cairns, the Great Barrier Reef, the Gold Coast, and so on. I believe that the money now being spent by the Tourist Commission, instead of being spent on personnel or large shiny offices, would be better spent on personalising Australia in the way I have mentioned.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Australian Tourist Commission Amendment Bill, which is a simple Bill which neither the Australian Labor Party nor the Australian Democrats oppose. It proposes to add to the numbers on the Australian Tourist Commission, giving representation on the Commission on a rotational basis to both the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was discussing some aspects of tourism in which I have a particular interest, particularly as I was the Minister who, in 1967, brought down the original piece of legislation setting up the Australian Tourist Commission. I was praising the Commission for its success in many areas, particularly for increasing the number of tourists coming from overseas to Australia in the last few years. But then I was critical of the method of operation that it adopts.

SPEECH.PARA: When I was the responsible Minister I laid down guidelines that it would be better promotional activity to bring wholesale travel agents to Australia at the cost of the Commission to show them the magnificent tourist attractions that we have to show to the world market and that we should make that visit of those wholesale travel agents a warm and personal matter. I was putting the view that money is far better spent on that sort of personal treatment, in explaining and showing first-hand to the people who actually sell the travel, than on advertising in journals or on putting out shiny brochures, because the kinds of people who sell travel receive on their desks every day of their lives reams of paper from every country of the world advertising tourist wares. I suppose anything can be dollied up to look interesting in shiny and coloured brochures, but to show something in the flesh to a wholesale travel agent, with all expenses paid and with helpful and personal guidance, in my experience is the best way to sell tourism. I was expressing some disappointment that the Commission's bureaucracy had now grown to 76 fully paid people.

TALK.START.PARA: —That has come back from 110 or so.

—Yes, and I am glad that it has. Notwithstanding that, eight very costly offices are maintained throughout the world by the Commission. However, I commend the Commission for doing a fine job. I was also being critical of the Government, which does not seem to realise that if the Commission does a fantastic job and brings tourists to Australia, that flow of tourists, which is a significant earner of foreign exchange, will very soon dry up unless we have the kinds of hotels to cope with the demands of those tourists. One of the views of the Treasury which has never ceased to astonish me-it may be because most people in the heirarchy of the Treasury have never been outside Canberra or worked in the hurly-burly of business life-is that we can turn the flow of tourists on and off like a tap. Therefore, the approach of the Treasury to a Cabinet Minister who is putting forward a proposition for more funds to attract more tourists always seem to be: No, we must not subsidise the fun or the holidays of foreigners. That is a very short-sighted attitude, particularly when economists' dreams of a mineral boom will not solve all our balance of payment problems. The view of academics in the Treasury is that any time we want more tourists we can just pump a bit of money into the publicity machines and the tourist flow will begin again. That is rubbish, because it takes years to build up the good will and the atmosphere in which a country is talked about as a tourist attraction by potential foreign tourists. To think that we can just turn the flow of tourists on and off like a tap, I think, is folly.

SPEECH.PARA: If we want the kinds of hotels which can properly accommodate foreign tourists, we have to encourage people to build them. At the moment the depreciation of buildings is not an allowable deduction for tax purposes, so there is virtually no encouragement to people to build new hotels. To build a hotel now costs about $100,000 per room. If 16 per cent interest is paid on the money borrowed, and assuming a 70 per cent occupancy rate, the cost per room per day is $62 before even one dollar is paid in wages, direct expenses or overheads. The hotel owner has to recoup that amount from the person who stays in the hotel room before he can go any further. For that reason the Democrats very strongly advocate a depreciation allowance of between 10 per cent and 15 per cent on hotel buildings.

In conclusion, may I comment on the almost catastrophic muddle concerning both internal and external air fares in Australia. I know that it is not an easy problem and I do not want to make cheap political capital by criticising the Government and saying that the problem can be solved easily. But it is beyond my comprehension why the Government, quite properly and wisely, appointed the Holcroft committee to advise it on air fares and, before the commitee's inquiries were complete, dismissed it and then arbitrarily brought down its own findings. We will have more to say about that later in the evening when the Government's reaction to the Holcroft report is being debated in the Senate. Suffice it to say that the Government, without allowing a committee to look into it, has now said: 'We are going to sell Trans-Australia Airlines'.

On the program PM tonight Senator Rae could not enlighten me-he normally does-as to whom the Govenment will sell TAA and for how much. How many of the shares are to be sold? Will there be a 51 per cent public interest or a 49 per cent public interest? Is Qantas Airways Ltd to be brought into the deal? It seems to me to be a statement entirely appropriate to be made by a government on April Fools' Day.

Any discussion on tourism would be incomplete without talking about airline policy, but I will not infringe the guidelines of this debate on the Australian Tourist Commission, particularly as the airline policy will be discussed later this evening. I just say that surely consideration should be given to allowing Sir Freddie Laker or someone similar to open up a cut-price air service between London and Australia and between Europe and Australia. We know that Sir Freddie's skytrain service to New York has revolutionised the fare structure of transatlantic travel. Only two months ago both Laker and British Caledonian Airways said they wanted to slash up to 50 per cent off the existing London to Australia fares.

Let us contemplate for a moment the impact on tourism to Australia from Europe if the air fares were cut by 50 per cent. It would open up a whole new market for tourists to Australia. I hope that vigorous State Premiers, those Premiers who are fortunate enough to be the premier politicians in States with an abundance of tourist attractions-one thinks in a flash of Tasmania, Queensland and other States-can be more aggressive in putting their viewpoints to the Federal Government by saying: 'Is a monopoly or a duopoly to Qantas such a sacred cow that hundreds of thousands of tourists are to be denied access to Australia and to our States to spend their money?' British Caledonian has offered a one-way ticket from London to Perth for only $360. Yet we have a free enterprise government in the form of the Liberal-National Party Government saying: 'No, we will not let you do that. We will preserve at all costs the rights of a nationalised publicly owned airline, Qantas. We do not care about you Australians who want to go from Perth to London for $360. It is more important to preserve the sacred cow'. We have to bear in mind that each passenger costs the airline $250 for fuel alone, so the margins are extremely small. Some say they are disastrously small. But if we believe in a free enterprise system, which the Australian Democrats do, why not let the operators take their chances in the market? For many years Qantas and British Airways have had a cosy monopoly on the London-Australia route. Perhaps it is time they received some form of kick in the pants by being forced to compete on the open market.

The Australian Democrats congratulate the Commission on a job well done. We ask the eminent people on the Commission-Captain Ritchie, the Chairman and a very distinguished Australian, and his seven colleagues-to watch the growth of bureaucracy and to give consideration to spending the money, as the Democrats suggest, in the more personalised way of attracting tourists to Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is interesting that, at a time when the Senate has been almost struggling for the lack of business which has been put its way by the Government from the House of Representatives, the Senate has an opportunity to debate a Bill which is totally uncontroversial. Without exception, those who have spoken and those who have taken an interest in the subject have not objected to the substance of the Australian Tourist Commission Amendment Bill. Therefore, I join with those who say: 'Let us take the opportunity provided by this Bill being before the Parliament and before the Senate to talk about some of the wider issues in relation to tourism instead of limiting the debate to the subject of the Bill which is so obviously incontrovertibly uncontroversial. I suppose one could say that the subject matter starts from the fact that the purpose of the Bill is to amend the provisions in relation to the membership and constitution of the Australian Tourist Commission. As nobody wishes to debate that matter and as the reasons for the amendment were set out in detail in the second reading speech of the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick) I simply say that I support those concepts and I support the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I proceed now to discuss one or two of the matters which have been raised in the debate, and in particular by Senator Chipp. I well remember two things in relation to Senator Chipp. First of all, I remember that he was, as he has already indicated, the Minister in charge of tourism when it was a relatively embryonic Commonwealth activity back in the latter part of the 1960s when the Australian Tourist Commission was established. I acknowledge his continuing interest. In fact, I well remember that when the Liberal and National Country Party policy on tourism was being established in 1975-it has been followed ever since-one of its very strong supporters was Senator Chipp who was then a member of the shadow Ministry. That policy has continued and has developed in a way which is important to Australia and to the tourist industry in particular. So I approach the suggestions made by Senator Chipp in the light of that background.

I think we should have regard to the comments made by somebody who has taken a long-standing interest in the problem of an evergrowing bureaucracy instead of spending money on finding ways to make a buck. The Government's intervention in the tourist industry is related to endeavouring to ensure that one of the major growth areas of economic activity in the world is able to be participated in fully by Australians from an employment point of view, from an overseas exchange earnings point of view, a self-satisfaction point of view, a national prestige point of view and from the point of view of a huge variety of matters which come within and are encompassed by the term 'tourism'.

At times I feel a little concerned that perhaps the criticism made by Senator Chipp about the bureaucracy developing within the Australian Tourist Commission could be an accurate criticism. In contrast to that, I say that in this country we have a need to get some facts. Senator Chipp talked about Treasury's paranoia in relation to the tourist industry and the depreciation allowance. I shall come back to the depreciation allowance, but let me talk firstly about Treasury's paranoia. It took some statistics and some expert economic examination to be able to identify the fact that the tourist industry is worth more to Australia than the motor vehicle industry. It required some of the work which is being done by the boffins and by the bureaucracy to which Senator Chipp referred for that sort of recommendation to be made.

The most dramatic breakthrough in relation to the tourist industry was in the 1979 Commonwealth Budget. At a time when expenditure on various large areas of activity was being cut there was a recognition, as a result of the work of Professor Johns and others, that tourism was an industry of real significance to this nation. There was a recognition in real terms that the industry needed considerable assistance, encouragement and development.

In straight money terms, the amount of money provided in relation to tourism by the Commonwealth Government was doubled. But that is not the important point; the important point is that-let us not say it is a matter for credit for anybody in particular-for the first time ever a Commonwealth government said: 'We are interested in tourism because it is a major, important national industry which can change the nature of employment opportunities and the nature of economic activity in Australia, and it can be good for the nation in many ways'. I thought that 1979 was a very significant year in relation to tourism and the Australian Tourist Commission. Many honourable senators might recognise that I have not been renowned as the greatest lover of the growth of bureaucracies, statutory authorities and other organisations to fulfil functions when there is no system of checks and balances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mangoes and qangos.

—Thank you, Senator O'Byrne. The Australian Tourist Commission has been fined down; its composition was very much larger than it is now. It had to go through the necessary reconsideration of what is and what is not essential. It is fulfilling many important purposes at the moment in that it is starting to do some of the necessary research, definition and statistical preparation and compilation of programs. I would not wish to be taken as arguing for a massive increase in the composition of the Commission, nor would I wish to be taken as arguing against the proposition which Senator Chipp put, which I urge honourable senators and the Government to think about; that is, if you want to con somebody into believing that you have something to sell, bring it out and show it to them. That seems to me to be a fairly simple, fundamental thing.
—It works, too.

—It works well. I make the point that one can criticise the undue development of many bureaucracies in Australia, but I think the Australian Tourist Commission is, at least at the moment-maybe it needs review next year; most of them need review every year-fulfilling a very useful function in that it is trying to develop a very underdeveloped area in which one of the greatest problems was the lack of information. The most important task of the Commission, apart from just selling Australia overseas, is providing us with some of the information in relation to Australian tourism which has not been available over the years. The results have been dramatic. Australia is now starting to catch up from where it was losing out. We were having a percentage decline in our share of the Pacific tourist activity. We were having a percentage decline in the growth in the number of overseas visitors to this nation. As a result of a variety of measures and the activities of the Commission we have now seen one of the most dramatic growths that we have witnessed in any area of activity in this nation. In the last three years tourism has grown more than any other industry. I cannot think of nor have I heard of another industry that has grown so much.
—Tax avoidance is about equal.

—Senator Chipp makes the point that the growth in the tax avoidance industry is about equal. I had thought that growth in tax avoidance was probably of longer standing than growth in the tourist industry. The tourist industry depends upon a degree of tax avoidance inasmuch as many tourists are encouraged to travel to attend a convention or like activities because the taxpayer contributes through taxation deduction provisions relating to such travel. I do not want to go on to that.

SPEECH.PARA: The general recognition of the importance of the tourist industry is one of the dramatic features of this industry over the past few years. I acknowledge that one of the early battlers for the industry was Senator Chipp. But I do not think his criticism of the current situation is entirely fair. I think the industry has developed. The present Government did a great deal in 1979 to take it a stage further but the fact is that the industry has got itself together in a way which has meant that we have seen a huge and dramatic growth. The worst feature that is affecting the tourist industry is the aspect which affects my State of Tasmania. It will affect the whole of the Australian tourist industry if we are not careful. People did not go in droves to Tasmania this past summer. The reason they did not go was not that they did not wish to go but they were too frightened because industrial disturbances meant that the return voyage by air or by sea was uncertain. We had tremendous turmoil within the airline industry in particular. In Tasmania over the past summer cancellations in various areas reached 40 per cent to 60 per cent. There was a huge number of cancellations. That was a fairly dramatic situation. There is no justification for Australians sitting back, relaxing and saying: 'It will not happen to us as a nation and we do not really have to worry about Tasmania'. We should worry about the Tasmanian tourist industry. It is extremely important to that State. We also should worry about the Australian tourist industry and provide a reasonable degree of certainty that the people who visit us will not find themselves stranded, virtually hijacked, by industrial disputes when they arrive here. While not disagreeing with most of what Senator Chipp said, let me add that factor as a rather important consideration in any discussion about the tourist industry.

Having looked at my notes of what else was said in this discussion, I can only apologise that I failed dismally to explain in detail the restructuring of Trans-Australia Airlines when I was speaking in an area of the media earlier this evening.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was making no criticism of you. I was saying it was unclear what the Government had in mind.

—Thank you. I pose this question: Is it not better sometimes to take one step at a time? The first and most important step, if we want to have a debate on an effective domestic airline policy, is to look at structures and to get them organised so that we then have options. To me the first step that has been taken in restructuring TAA as a public company is a tremendously important step before we start to get on to the rest of the debate. I have views as to the direction to follow and many others also may have views. But at least by using the public company structure for this statutory authority we can say: 'All right, let us now start to see where the public debate goes as to what is the operating advantage to the whole of the Commonwealth by taking it one step or another toward deregulation'.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the sacred cow to which reference was made-that is, Qantas Airways Ltd-let me put in a word in defence of Qantas. Whilst I would like to see increasing deregulation in relation to international airlines, I do not recall that during the period Senator Chipp was involved in tourism as a Minister he was able to solve the problem. I am not sure that anyone in Australia will individually solve, by unilateral action within Australia, the problem of the international airlines. I think the position of Qantas as Australia's flag carrier has to be looked at from the point of view of what are the prevailing international air transport agreements and conditions and what we can do to change its position steadily. Again, without differing greatly on the objects that Senator Chipp was talking about-that is, it would be highly desirable to give Australians the opportunity to travel cheaply overseas and to give overseas people the opportunity to come to Australia as cheaply as possible-let us also bear in mind that it is essential that we have in Australia a regular, scheduled, reliable and safe airline service that is well run. I think for the time being we perhaps have to bear with Qantas more than we have to bear with some of the things over which we have greater control such as the domestic airline situation. It does not mean we should not, at the international level, be saying: 'Let us push for change'. But before we rush into it, let us have regard to retaining the opportunity to have dependable, regular transport to and from this country for the benefit of both the tourist industry and our total economic activity.

I am glad we have had an opportunity to talk very briefly about tourisim. I hope the Senate might consider it is a good idea to talk about tourism a little more. It is one of the growing industries which is becoming more and more important in Australia. I can only be encouraged by the fact that it seems to be receiving a little more attention now than it did in past years. The fears that Senator Chipp expressed about the Treasury attitude to what perhaps was regarded as a frivolous industry are no longer prevailing. Tourism is regarded as a major industry in this nation which can be a major contributor to providing, in particular, opportunities for employment. I just throw out without debate the suggestion that until such time as the problem of penalty rates in the tourist industry is overcome we will not have major development in the industry in the way that I think would be possible were we able to overcome this problem. I support the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to push the point too far, but just in some vain hope that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) will reply not only to a question about tourism but also to a debate that will follow later this evening on the statement of the Minister for Transport, Mr Hunt, in reaction to the Holcroft inquiry, I ask the Minister whether he has any indication or whether he can give the chamber any clue as to what government policy is regarding the sale of Trans-Australia Airlines. Will 51 per cent be held by the Government and 49 per cent by the public, or the other way round? For us to be faced with a statement, while debating a Bill on tourism, simply that TAA is going to be made a public company adds confusion on to confusion. If the Minister has any information on this matter from his colleague in the House of Representatives I would be grateful if the chamber could be informed at this stage.

—Further to Senator Chipp's question I would like to make a comment, and that is, that if the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) is not able to be more specific than the statement of the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) in the House of Representatives this afternoon, which is that the Government will move in a particular direction, is it not perhaps an excellent example that the best result can be achieved by saying 'This is what we would like to do. We would like to make a company structure come within the general conditions and provisions of the companies Act' and then leave it flexible as to whether it ought to be structured in one way or another? I hope that the Minister's answer will be that the matter is now, subject for discussion, debate and input as to how it ought to be structured. One of the things that I hope will happen is that the people who believe participation by employees is important in Australia will have their chance to say at this time: 'Let the employees have a cut of the cake. Give a lead'. I would hope that those who would say that Trans-Australia Airlines ought to be 100 per cent owned by the Government will have their opportunity to say why they believe that is so. I would hope that those who would say that whatever happens to it it should not be totally controlled or open to control by any of the existing major transport operators or by any foreign takeover will have their opportunity to make their input. What I hope and regard as highly desirable is that there should be, during the period which now appears to be available in which the Government has announced an intention without going into detail, some reasonable degree of debate and input from the various people who have an interest in this matter as to what ought to be the way in which the detail is worked out. The fact that TAA needed to be restructured as a public company is something on which I spent some half an hour speaking in this chamber on 10 March, one of the many times I have done so.
—Spare us again, Senator.

—Senator Evans no doubt well remembers those many times. But they were remarks about restructuring. I suggest that we now have a debate about the exact detail of the way in which it ought to be restructured. I hope that the Minister's answer to Senator Chipp's question will be that those are matters which are still open for imput.

—I thank Senator Rae for his contribution following the question raised by Senator Chipp. Obviously, if the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) had been in a position to go into more detail than he went into in his statement, he would have done so. I take it from Senator Chipp's remarks that he has seen the statement by the Minister for Transport. The position is broadly as indicated by Senator Rae-the Government has taken a decision in the broad. There are matters of detail which remain for further examination and obviously further decision. The opportunity for further suggestions from Senator Rae will no doubt be open to him. Bearing in mind the debate there has been over airline policy in Australia over the last six months and indeed longer, I have little doubt that many people will now avail themselves of the opportunity to make suggestions as to the way in which the Government ought to execute the statement it has made today, which is to change TAA to public company status.

—I will not detain the chamber for any length of time, but that statement by the Minister, that these matters of detail will be announced later, demands response. We have a situation whereby the Government has, rightly or wrongly, decided to sell TAA, to make it a public company.
—A restructuring.
—Why not Qantas?

—As Senator Harradine says, why not Qantas? Indeed, why not Qantas? This is the magnitude of the problem we are discussing here tonight. I asked the question: Did the Minister have any further information on how that sale would proceed? Would it be 51 per cent interest retained by the Government and 49 per cent sold to other people? That would be one situation because then the Government would maintain a controlling interest and we would have a two-airline policy essentially as we have it today. I also asked whether it would be the other way round-49 per cent retained by the Government and 51 per cent going to ordinary shareholders, employees or whoever? I further asked whether it meant that 100 per cent would be sold, put on the open market, which would then mean that TAA as we know it now would be at the mercy of predators of the like of the gentleman who sat in this Gallery 10 minutes ago and who was escorted around Parliament House tonight by four Liberal Ministers. Has the word got out already that TAA is up for grabs? I would think these are not matters of detail. These are matters of fundamental principle. For Senator Rae to say that it is simply restructuring--
—That is a first step.

—To say that it is a first step of restructuring, to me, totally begs the question. It adds confusion on to confusion. I conclude my remarks by saying that that kind of statement is a classic statement to be made on 1 April, no matter what year it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, like Senator Chipp, I do not wish to detain the chamber, but I am appalled that people cannot see the difference between the two questions. One is that it is important that we rectify structures and the other is that we come to conclusions about what we do with the structure we have created or recreated. The two questions are totally separable. One is related to efficiency and opportunity and the other is related to how best we then apply the opportunities which have been created. For anyone to suggest that the two have to be melded together and that it is inappropriate for the Government to have announced the first without announcing the detail of the second is to indicate that the idea of participatory democracy in this country is dead. I like to think of this as an example, which may have come about deliberately and which may not have come about deliberately, of how people, having seen the announcement of the first step to be taken-a step which can only be the first instance of simple restructuring as a public company instead of a statutory authority, and then having the Government own 100 per cent of the shares-have an opportunity to participate in the discussion as to what might happen thereafter. I hope that the debate will be--
—We know your views. You want to flog it off.
—It has been suggested that I want to flog it off. I would like to suggest that what I have said is that I would like to see TAA employees have a share.
—How much would they have to raise per employee?

—Order! I have allowed the Committee to range over a subject totally unrelated to the matter before the Committee. I suggest that Senator Rae direct his remarks to the clause of the Bill we are discussing. I suggest that the rest of the Committee observe what I have said and cease interjection on this matter.
—They are selling off a government enterprise and you don't want to say anything.
—Senator McLaren, I have made it quite clear that the discussion has been totally unrelated to the matter before the Chair. I suggest that we get back to the Committee discussion.

—In the light of your ruling, Mr Temporary Chairman, I find it rather hard to do what I would like to do, which is to reply to one or two of the interjections. I wonder whether we could endeavour to have a debate on this matter at the earliest opportunity. Within the limits of your ruling, I suggest that in relation to the Australian Tourist Commission it is important that we have two or more airlines operating in Australia. It is important that our domestic airlines be efficient. It is important to give some thought to whether the airline operator structures are effective for the purpose. One aspect I would have thought of as important was whether the employees, the people engaged in the operations, feel involved and are participating in the general development of the nation. Presumably the airline industry will have the opportunity to develop along with the rest of the nation. I would like to think that the employees of one at least of our airlines have the most direct opportunity to participate in the purchase of shares in the airline.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many plans, including one put by Mr Louis Kelso of the United States, which have provided means by which employees can obtain a shareholding in a company without having to provide capital directly out of their own savings but rather by taking out loans to be repaid out of future dividends. This is a complicated system which I will not go into because it may not be relevant to the debate. There are ample opportunities for being able to achieve the objective to which I refer which will make more efficient the provision of an airline system in Australia and which will make more effective the opportunities for development of the Australian tourist industry. Mr Temporary Chairman, I guess I cannot go much further.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Minister replies I would like to remind him of what I said earlier. The matter under discussion has no relevance to what is before the Chair. Within those limitations, I call the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, this is the first time that I have been reminded of relevance before I have actually said anything. I want to say, and I trust this is relevant, that if Senator Chipp listened carefully to the first half of Senator Rae's speech he has had more than an adequate answer to his questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments made by the House of Representatives be agreed to.

Clause 18 in the Schedule of the Bill fixes maximum amounts payable in respect of costs certificates granted pursuant to the Bill. During the second reading debate on the Bill on 3 December 1980 a question was raised by Senator Evans as to the effect of these limits in the case of retrials. The Government has examined this question further and has come to the view that in the case of retrial special considerations apply. For example, when a trial cannot be completed because of the death of a judge it is not appropriate that the amount available pursuant to a cost certificate granted in respect of that trial should be subject to normal limits. Similar considerations apply when an appellant court considers a new trial in criminal proceedings.

The effect of the amendments made in the other place is to remove the limits on the amounts payable for cost certificates granted in respect of aborted or discontinued proceedings and in respect of new trials in criminal proceedings. These amendments are based upon the provisions of the New South Wales legislation. The costing in relation to this measure was based on the New South Wales experience. Although all other States do not have the particular provisions that are now proposed in these amendments, nevertheless in the Government's view it is appropriate that our legislation should approximate the New South Wales situation. I trust that the amendments which have been made in another place and which are now proposed in this chamber are agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Federal Proceedings (Costs) Bill 1980, which has been returned to the Senate, concerns the payment of costs in certain Federal Court cases where those costs are incurred as a result of circumstances beyond the control of any individual litigant. The basic limits which the Schedule to the Bill sets on the costs thus payable are as follows: For the High Court of Australia, $5,000; the Federal Court, $3,000; the Family Court, $2,000; the Supreme Court of a Territory, $3,000, and any other court of a Territory, $1,000. The effect of the amendments which come before us tonight is, as the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) says, to remove those prescribed maximum limits in two circumstances. The first circumstance is where a retrial is ordered following a successful appeal in a criminal matter and the second is where the proceedings in question are rendered abortive by reason of the death or illness of the judge. Costs incurred up to the time that the trial is so disrupted must be reincurred. Those costs can, of course, be quite significant in a particular case.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition welcomes and supports this amendment which, as the Attorney-General says, goes a long way towards picking up some points made by us when the Bill was first before the chamber last December. It gives us a small measure of satisfaction to know that some of the criticisms and suggestions that we make in this place from time to time are taken seriously and that some of them at least result in amendments being brought forward. It does not happen often enough to make the so-called legislative process in this Parliament other than a charade most of the time, but it is a pleasant surprise when it does.

However, there are a couple of questions that I raise for the Attorney's attention and to which the Opposition would appreciate answers. The first question is: In the case of a retrial why is the amendment limited to criminal cases only? From time to time there can be an order for retrial in a civil case and, although this is likely to be rarer than in the criminal context, a civil trial, thus reordered, can be a pretty expensive business too. The other question is: Why is there any ceiling at all in respect of the costs of other sorts of hearings covered by this Bill-namely, the appeals-when those costs are incurred, again through no fault of the individual litigant in question?

This matter was raised by the Law Council of Australia in its letter of 28 January to the Attorney, subsequently made public, and to the effect that the appellant court costs are very high and that the figures which I have mentioned and which are set out in the Schedule to the Bill may be unrealistically low, not just for the classes of cases that are covered in this amendment but for all classes of cases. Secondly, I refer to the extent to which there is some control over the costs that can thus be paid out through the requirement that they be taxed; that is to say, vetted. That arguably would seem to be a sufficient limitation to ensure that public moneys were not unnecessarily squandered. This question was raised in the original debate very specifically, if not by me in this place certainly by Mr Bowen in the other place, and it is a question that was not very satisfactorily answered. Perhaps the Attorney can take this opportunity tonight to indicate why ceilings have been set at all.

The remaining matter that the Opposition wishes to mention at this time is the continued absence from the explicit terms of this Bill of a provision to enable the recovery of costs where new proceedings are ordered in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. No doubt the Attorney will recall that this was another matter raised by me in this place last December and was one to which the Attorney said he would give further consideration. Having had four months to consider that question and to contemplate the injustices that might be rort to an individual litigant where he goes down on a point of law on appeal and a new proceeding is ordered in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, can he indicate why he has brought forward no amendment to cover that contingency?

I repeat that I and the Opposition welcome at least the limited flexibility and sensitivity which has been shown by the Government on this occasion. I am sorry if the Attorney-General thinks my praise for this legislative initiative is still rather less fulsome, but being the gentleman he undoubtedly is, no doubt he will acknowledge that that kind of praise is better than no praise at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am thankful for even the faintest praise from Senator Evans. I have been in politics long enough not to live on any form of praise, faint or otherwise; one tries to do things as best one can in all the difficult circumstances of ones life. I think the matters raised by Senator Evans are substantial ones. If we lived in a world in which we did not have to worry about the costs involved and the liabilities that governments are assuming, I think I would not have much difficulty in agreeing that it would be desirable that these matters be covered in legislation of this kind. As I have said previously, the Government took decisions in regard to this measure which is, I think, a valuable extension of the rights which litigants have in State courts and which have not been available to them in Federal courts. In cases of aborted trials or where new trials have been ordered in criminal cases, the costs will be met out of the public purse and will not be an additional cost for the litigant in circumstances where he was not responsible for the cost being incurred; for example, because the judge died or a rehearing was ordered through no fault of the litigant.

SPEECH.PARA: In deciding to apply these provisions which are, as I have said, available in State and Federal courts, the Commonwealth was concerned, first of all, with what the cost of the measure would be. After looking at the various costs incurred in the State area, we estimated the cost on the basis of the New South Wales legislation and the costs that have been incurred in that State. Of course we are not sure whether these costs will be mirrored in the Federal courts but we thought that that was a fair method of comparison. The further consideration which the Government gave to the Bill after the Senate debate indicated that it was more restrictive than the New South Wales legislation. These amendments have been designed to bring it up to the standard of the New South Wales legislation. I think it covers the most important situations. Admittedly it does not cover, as Senator Evans says, the costs incurred by a retrial in civil proceedings, and of course civil proceedings are ordered from time to time.

However, as we know, in civil proceedings costs are awarded on the basis of the outcome, or costs follow the event as lawyers say. Although there would be additional costs as a result of a retrial, total costs likely to be incurred in proceedings are difficult to estimate and litigants who embark upon civil proceedings must take these matters into account. That is one of the chances that they take when embarking on civil litigation. I do not think anything like the sort of injustice that may arise in the case of a retrial in civil proceedings would arise in criminal proceedings where the accused, unless he obtains legal aid, is obliged to meet the costs. In the cases that we envisage here he would be liable for the costs twice over. That is the explanation of that situation.

I believe all States have ceilings on costs in appeal cases. Certainly New South Wales has them. Therefore, if we were to embark upon a scheme of this kind without ceilings we may incur expenditure which is in excess of the estimated expenditure. We have provided in the Bill for the ceilings to be changed by regulation. If they prove to be too low, too restrictive, then the means are clearly available for us to change them.

As far as the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is concerned, there is no ready comparison with the New South Wales situation. As I pointed out earlier, a section of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act enables a litigant in that Tribunal, who is liable to pay only his own costs and not those of the other side, and who is suffering hardship, to apply to the Attorney-General for a certificate. Certainly, it will be possible to accommodate the hardship cases in the AAT under that provision. I say again that we would like to see how the legislation works in practice. If people suffer hardships or injustices in the course of the experience we have with this legislation, naturally we will be prepared to look at it again.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
