TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take the opportunity of congratulating the Treasurer (Mr Howard) on his statement to the House of Representatives explaining in detail the Government's reasons for not proceeding with a broad-based indirect tax. This statement has afforded the Parliament the opportunity of debating tax issues of our day. I doubt whether such a debate could bring about a general consensus within this Parliament. It is true that we all seek a degree of tax reform but the direction in which that tax reform is to go, I believe, is a point of major difference. For example, some years ago our Government rightly eliminated gift and death duties but I believe that in so doing it has created a gap within our tax system which can be filled only by some form of capital gains tax. I believe that this gap remains fairly significant in the context of formulating measures to counter tax avoidance. I think it is true, however, that to derive any credible amount of revenue from any sort of capital gains tax the rates would have to be pitched fairly high. I think this is one of the main reasons why successive governments have not proceeded on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Our tax code nowadays is not only cumbersome but is also very bulky in content. It represents many years of attempts by governments not only to widen the scope of the receipts that come within the ambit of income tax but also to cover up loopholes which have been discovered by astute tax evaders and avoiders and their advisers. It is unfortunate that the tax avoidance and tax evasion industries-I distinguished between the two-have become quite rampant. There is a general feeling in the community that people on very high incomes are now being placed in a situation in which, because of the advice that can be offered to them by astute taxation accountants, the amount of tax they pay is really an option which is open to them, rather than being a certain amount according to the Act.

One of the most disconcerting features of the tax avoidance and tax evasion industries nowadays is the degree to which some people will go to evade or to avoid tax. For this reason last year we introduced severe penalties under the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act-$50,000 and up to five years gaol-for tax evaders and their advisers who prevent the collection of lawfully payable tax. The Senate may recall such abhorrent schemes as the bottom of the harbour type schemes under which books were literally destroyed. The Government has been very active in attempting to cover up many of the loopholes. For example, since 1977 John Howard has introduced nine Bills which cover something like 24 legislative measures to counter tax avoidance. In addition he has had amendments made to the Sales Tax Acts to cover loopholes which also have been discovered by these so-called taxation accountants.

TALK.START.PARA: —More than the Labor Party ever did.

—That is true. This is not the end of the matter. John Howard intends to go even further. I believe that shortly legislation will be introduced into this chamber to deal with certain problems of transfer pricing. I understand that John Howard intends to amend section 136 of the Income Tax Assessment Act to deal with transfer pricing. I think the community can appreciate the problem of transfer pricing. It can be used very readily by international companies that operate in Australia. They take out at cost certain raw materials in proportion to their share of equity capital. They are then taken to a tax haven where they are introduced into a new company at a very much higher cost. I think we are all familiar with the problems incurred by the Icelandic Government. It is believed that there was a discrepancy of approximately $47m over a number of years between the price paid for material being taken out of Australia and the price paid upon entry to Iceland.

SPEECH.PARA: Not only is the Government to amend section 136 to deal with transfer pricing but also there is to be a complete rewriting of section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act to cover the overall catch-all situation whereby schemes which are designed to avoid tax shall be rendered null and void in the view of the Commissioners. I think we all look forward to the early introduction into the Parliament of legislation to that effect. Not only is the Government to amend section 136 and section 260 but it will also legislate following the profits made by the Bell group of companies through its using the technique of buying into the Elder Smith company through a shelf company, lending that shelf company money and then selling the shelf company. Of course, the shares would not be sold within 12 months and even the company may not be sold within 12 months because, after all, it is a shelf company.

TALK.START.PARA: —It still may be caught under section 26A.

—The point that Senator Messner rightly makes-he has beaten me to it-is that there is a strong view within the Australian Taxation Office that section 26A should catch this practice. After all, I think the intentions are clear. It was not the first such occasion. Intentions are often manifested by subsequent actions. There has been a repetition of this sort of technique. It think there have been something like four such actions. The Senate will be interested to learn that on the last occasion a profit of something like $16m was made. It is in the interests of the Commonwealth to catch up on this sort of activity. I can foresee changes to section 26A, and possibly to section 25, to clear any possible shadow of doubt there may be about the activities of these sorts of operators who try to exploit loopholes and to deny ordinary citizens-ordinary wage earners-an opportunity of securing reasonable relief from the fairly high marginal tax rates that they are paying at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I must admit that I am a little disappointed that the Government has not seen fit to give itself the opportunity of embarking on a program of tax reform by the introduction of a broad-based indirect tax. I am not referring to a value added tax; I am not referring to a retail turnover tax. I think there could have been an opportunity for the Government to improve the whole taxation system by extending this tax to cover certain service areas. After all, Australia places a fairly high reliance on the collection of personal income tax. Such heavy reliance is not good in bringing about an environment which would provide people with an incentive to earn. I think that is important as we have a growing economy in Australia. We must try to create an environment in which the small investors of Australia will be prepared to invest in the resources of this country. For example, the present system of double taxation of dividends does not encourage any investor, let alone the small investor, to put his money into some of these projects and companies which are operating in Australia and which are seeking money so that funds can remain in Australia for the great benefit of Australians.

We must, in our income tax system, encourage people to save. Unfortunately for this current generation, with its emphasis on hire purchase and the consumer orientated society, we have got away from the idea of thrift and the values and moralities that thrift tends to generate in the community. I suggest that rather than moving initially on this issue of trying to eliminate double taxation of dividends-I would like to see that come about a little further along the road-as a first step we try to encourage the small man. We should encourage the small man by exempting from income tax the first $2,000 of dividend and interest income.

Just think what such a measure would do to solve some of the heartache and heartburn of the pensioners of Australia. Those are the people who suddenly discover that by investing astutely or by getting a little higher interest rate as a result of what is going on at the moment they have come into a category where their pension is suddenly cut back. They are advised that because of their extra $100 income their pension will suddenly go down. Even worse still are the poor people who suddenly discover they are no longer entitled to fringe benefits. Sometimes the fringe benefits are worth far more to pensioners than the possible reduction in pension. Not only would such an exemption help the pensioners but also it would encourage the young. It would encourage all people in the community to invest in Australia. More importantly, it would encourage a degree of thrift and less reliance on this syndrome of spending up today because tomorrow will look after itself. If we could encourage this idea of personal thrift, et cetera, I believe our country would be certainly very much more stable than it is at the moment.

By forgoing an opportunity of moving into a form of indirect tax I believe we have forgone an opportunity of saving the family situation in Australia. I have talked about the small person who wants to save, but the person with a young family finds it increasingly difficult to balance his budget nowadays. I think there is now room for an increase in the spouse allowance. We have talked about taxing the family unit, but I think it would be better to increase the spouse rebate from $800 to at least $1,200 and, at the same time, to do something about family allowances. In Australia we want Australian families to be encouraged to raise their own families. We have to recognise that we have responsibilities in the wider world because of refugees. We have to take our share of people. We should realise what is happening in some centres of England where 20 per cent or even 30 per cent of new births are of coloured people.

Inevitably this situation will arise in Australia because of the greater migration of people from the East and elsewhere. While the traditional settlers of Australia are tending to limit their families, some of these newer people are tending to have larger families. If we wish to retain our Australian character for a longer period I believe we also have to take into consideration the provision of an appropriate allowance to Australian families so that the mother can be at home to assist where possible in raising the children. I recognise that in many circumstances the wife has to go to work. Taxing the family as a unit does not recognise the situation that many family groups are outside the traditional marriage state. There is a very heavy bias against the single parent family.

Let me come back to the aspect I was discussing. Australia does very well in the field of taxation when compared with the rest of the world. Do not let my recent statements counter the recognition of that fact. If we look at the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development figures in respect of 1978, the latest year for which figures are available, we find that total tax at all levels by governments as a percentage of gross domestic product in the 22 OECD countries that were under examination averaged something like 35.8 per cent. This is the percentage of total taxes to GDP. In Australia the figure was only 28.8 per cent. In fact, as we have been reminded, only four countries have a lower overall tax burden than Australia.

Our Government was also instrumental in reducing the impact of tax quite severely. It reduced from seven steps to three the progressive rate in tax scales. I notice that my colleague, Senator Flo Bjelke-Petersen, is not in the chamber. I think she would advocate a reduction to one step. If we had a flat tax of 20 per cent that would fail to recognise two very important principles of taxation. They are principles of equity. In fact, there has to be a horizontal equity and a vertical equity. The horizontal principle recognises that people on the same amount of income pay the same amount of tax. We know that in Australia that does not apply. We also have to recognise that people on a higher income have a greater ability to pay tax. Therefore, we must also have a vertical equity. I believe this factor was lost sight of in the recent campaign in Queensland.

At the same time, I think we must acknowledge that Australia raises 43.7 per cent of its tax through personal income tax. In this we can be compared with the OECD average of 38.5 per cent. Australia's heavy reliance on personal income tax can be further seen when we examine figures for the last 20 years. We have come to rely very heavily on this personal direct tax. In 1959-60 personal and company taxes accounted for 54 per cent of Commonwealth taxation revenue. Personal taxation revenue was then 35.6 per cent. Estimated figures for 1980-81 show almost 60 per cent for personal and company taxes and 35.6 per cent for personal income tax. Had it not been for the crude oil levy, which has risen fairly sharply in recent years to yield an estimated 10.6 per cent of total Commonwealth revenues at this point in time, those figures would have been very much higher. I realise that the community is not anxious to have introduced new taxes. In fact, its reluctance is fairly evident when one speaks to the ordinary wage earner or businessman. He says that the Government should make sure that other elements of taxation are cut out before it starts introducing new taxes. History has shown that it is very easy to introduce a new tax but it is very hard to take away an old one.

I certainly would like to see a committee of this Parliament investigate avenues of taxation reform on a non-party basis. I realise that obtaining a consensus will be very difficult, but I think the information that could be provided could give a few pearls of wisdom and somehow we may be able to unscramble the very difficult and thick Income Tax Assessment Act which we have at present. The Income Tax Assessment Act is becoming so technical in many areas that only the most astute of tax accountants are able to understand it. I think that is bad. We should seek simplicity as well as equity in our Act. An Act that is understood easily by people is very much respected. These are the directions we should be aiming for in the future. I commend John Howard's initiative in presenting this paper to the Parliament and allowing us the opportunity to discuss such matters in an endeavour to bring about a taxation reform to the greater benefit of the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — As I am not on the list of speakers for this debate and as honourable senators are well aware of the attitude I have adopted over a long period on the question of reforms in taxation and also support of the family, I do not intend to keep the Senate very long. Many of the points raised by Senator Watson get very much to the bone of the matter. I wish, in the very short time that I have set myself, to refer to the part of the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) which compares the tax payable by single-income families with the tax payable by two-income families. As an example, the Treasurer pointed out that on an income of $10,000 the single-income family pays $1,107 in tax and the dual-income family pays $614-a difference of $493. On an income of $20,000, the single-income family pays $4,693 in tax and the dual-income family pays $3,814. The single-income family pays $879 more tax than the dual-income family.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that all families have been seen off. As Senator Watson has pointed out, the proportion of tax paid by pay-as-you-earn taxpayers-the individuals-to the total revenue has increased over the year and the proportion paid by companies has decreased. I simply mention that I believe it is time that the Government honoured its promise given some days before the last election to do something in support of the family. I will now quote from the latest bulletin of the Australian Industries Development Association of March 1981, which dealt very briefly with assistance to families. It stated:

Until the 1975 (Hayden) Budget, taxpayers were permitted to claim a concessional deduction from their income in respect of children. This enabled a higher effective rebate to higher income earners. In the Hayden Budget these deductions were converted to rebates, and within a year (in May 1976) the Government achieved a social reform by making the payments for children allowances directly to women and removing the assistance from the tax or rebate system entirely.

In one sense, there is an artificial growth in this component of Government expenditure-some part of the outlays were previously disguised as a tax rebate or concessional deduction. But at least the nominal rates of payment have remained fixed over the last five years, and the underlying population of children and student dependants has remained relatively fixed or has even slightly declined. This is a rarity within the social welfare field where, through the 1970s, all the other categories have grown rapidly.

The family allowance scheme is the subject of substantial political discussion. There are strong pressures to go further in this direction arising from the erosion in the value of these family allowances, and from the pressures on single earner households. Peculiarities of the Australian taxation system impose a substantial burden on single income households or those which have not yet found the way of splitting incomes. In addition there are pressures because the rates of payments have not been increased for such a long period.

The Australian Industries Development Association has also joined in the demand that the Government take some action. It is all very well to say that these matters should be determined in a budgetary context. That would be okay if families were caught with higher prices only once a year, but even the Government's decision in respect of the bond rate interest will presumably have an effect on mortgage payments for home owners. On 15 October 1980, days before the Federal election, Mr Fraser made a promise, in Launceston, Tasmania, about supporting the families. News of that promise was spread throughout the length and breadth of Australia. It was made in the context of debate on the Government's oil pricing policies. An article appearing in the Australian of 16 October was headed 'Fraser pledges to give back petrol price rises as rebates or family allowances: OPEC increases will fund tax cuts: Prime Minister says priority to return money to the people'. It read:

In a dramatic bid to counter the vote-winning Labor pledge of cheap petrol the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, last night promised to return revenue from increased petrol prices next year to the public in the shape of tax cuts or higher family allowances.

The Treasurer's statement obviously precludes at this point any tax cuts. The Government should immediately honour its promise. As I understood it, that promise, boiled down, was that increases in the crude oil levy from 1 January 1981 would be returned in the fashion mentioned. Those increases will return to the Government, on the Treasurer's own figures, $170m this half year. That figure means that from 1 January 1981 the Government would have been able to increase family allowances by about 38 per cent. The money is flowing in the back door. It should be flowing now out the front door in accordance with those promises.

As I said before, the Senate is perfectly well aware of my position. I have spoken upon this matter many times. I have discussed the matter with the Government and urged it to do something about it immediately.

In the Budget it can then turn its attentions to the other proposals for income splitting and increasing the spouse rebate. However, one thing is certain, and I think it is generally agreed by all honourable senators on both sides of the Parliament. Something needs to be done urgently in support of the family, and I commend that action to the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is significant that tonight the only speakers on this matter have been from the non-Labor parties.
—Cut it out. That is a terrible statement.

—It is significant that no remarks have been made about the various taxation issues that the Labor Party raised in other places, particularly before the last election. However, one or two matters that were mentioned tonight I think are important, and certainly Senator Watson and Senator Harradine have referred to them. The first relates to the anti-avoidance provisions the Government has introduced in recent times, and it is significant to note that those issues have received a lot of attention in the media. Indeed, from time to time the various abuses of the system have been drawn to the Government's attention by the media as well as by members of the Government parties and, I believe, by members of the Opposition. I certainly do not claim that members of the Opposition have no interest in pursuing the tax avoidance question.
—What was the statement all about?

—This is one aspect of the statement, and I believe it to be a very important one. It was an issue in the last election, and I think Senator Grimes's party drew particular attention to the matter. The Government can rightly claim credit for having taken action when the matters were brought to its attention. In respect of the anti-avoidance provisions, Senator Watson raised numerous matters, and I might refer to one or two of them. In particular, I recall the action taken back in 1978 in regard to the Curran case. At that stage of the game a very virulent form of tax avoidance was being undertaken in the community, costing literally hundreds of millions of dollars. The Government had support from all sides of the Parliament in taking action on what was a significant issue. The action involved a degree of retrospectivity, which was a very significant breakthrough at that time. Obviously, it is in the interests of the taxpayer generally to ensure that those people who are paying tax through the pay-as-you-earn system receive the greatest amount of credit.

SPEECH.PARA: One other matter mentioned-certainly it was made clear by Senator Watson in his remarks-was the question of whether there ought to be a change to a greater emphasis on indirect taxation in our system. Senator Watson sought to make the point that in this country indirect taxes produce a lower proportion of total revenues to the Commonwealth Government than do direct forms of taxation. It is well known that in some countries-I instance France and, for that matter, the United States-there is a very high reliance on indirect taxation. In the United Kingdom the rate of value-added tax is as high as 15 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fifteen per cent?

—It is 15 per cent on all goods and services sold in the community. In France the rate is somewhat different but, on the average, it is of the order of 10 per cent to 12 per cent. However, a more complex system is employed in that country. Nevertheless, the fact remains that in those countries there is less reliance on personal income tax and far heavier reliance on indirect taxes in the form of value-added taxes in particular. Countries such as the United States have more complex arrangements involving the States at the local level, particularly with regard to retail turnover tax arrangements, and again I think Senator Watson mentioned that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Limiting the effect of indirect taxation increases upon the inflation rate is probably one of the most significant problems our economy will face in the next few years, and that has been referred to by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in his statement and from time to time by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and other Ministers. In recent months there has been a very significant change in the inflation picture in this country compared with that for the rest of the world. It seems that at present the United Kingdom and the United States have rapidly declining rates of inflation. That must not be met with an increasing rate of inflation in this country if we are to maintain the growth in our economy that is starting to show up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where?
—Some 220,000 jobs were created last year, which if by Senator Melzer's standards does not measure anything--
—You are talking about part time jobs at MacDonald's hamburger joints. Why don't you talk about real jobs?

—I am afraid that Senator Melzer would not appreciate that, whatever it is, a job is a job is a job. Having created that opportunity in the community as a result of very significant changes, we are setting the base for future development in the economy. Looking particularly at resource developments in the next few years, there will be a changed emphasis in particular areas. Senator Harradine mentioned the very important aspect of support for the family, and the Government is very firmly committed to that. This commitment was evident in the 1980 Budget, when we increased the spouse allowance from $597 a year to $800 a year.
—Big deal.
—Senator Melzer again comments that that is a big deal, but in terms of ultimate dollars of the order of $600m, it was a very big deal for the Australian taxpayer.
—Spread out across what?
—Senator Melzer claims to be one of those people who stand for women's lib.
—Don't you say what I stand for.
—Perhaps Senator Melzer has been misrepresented, but that is the impression we have gained. However, she is now claiming that the spouse allowance should be higher.
—Hear, hear!

—Senator Harradine agrees with that, and certainly the Government has a disposition in favour of that point of view. It is a matter of being able to work within the system and being able to afford these things, which the Whitlam Government was not able to do during its period of office. In any case, it was interesting to hear Senator Harradine's remarks, and I note them. I thank all honourable senators who spoke in the debate for their contributions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had no intention of speaking in the debate on this statement, nor will I detain the Senate for very long, but I must speak in view of Senator Messner's words, which I believe were most unfortunate. I point out that Senator Messner was not the Minister who introduced this statement. He was not in the chamber when the statement was read, and one could claim equally that he had no interest in the subject because of that. He implied quite clearly tonight that because there were no speakers from the Labor side of the House we were not interested. There were no speakers from this side because Senator Walsh, our spokesman in this House on these matters, spoke when the statement was put down. A speakers' list was arranged tonight between the Whips. Senator Harradine asked both sides whether he could make a contribution and both sides agreed that he could. Therefore, Senator Messner's remarks were quite uncalled for.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask Senator Messner to take back to his colleague Mr Howard the thoughts given tonight in this chamber by Senator Watson. Firstly, he said that Australia is not a highly taxed country. In fact only four countries in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development are taxed less than Australia. Secondly, he advocated increases in the family allowance to support families with children because parenthood quite frequently causes economic strife in families in this country, particularly low income families and families on benefits and pensions. Thirdly, he advocated other increases in expenditure such as an increase in the spouse allowance. I suggest that if the Treasurer considers whether we are such a highly taxed country, as Senator Messner and his colleagues have been trying to tell us for the last five years, and whether he can at the same time advocate increased government expenditure without doing something about those taxes, he may find himself in somewhat of a dilemma in view of the rhetoric that he has used in the last five years. I entered this debate merely to point out that the reason there were no Opposition speakers tonight on this matter was an arrangement with the Government to suit the Government's legislative program. Remarks such as those which Senator Messner made, when he knew he was on the air and thought he could score a few cheap points, are quite unworthy of him.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STAGING OF B52s THROUGH AUSTRALIA FOR SEA SURVEILLANCE IN THE INDIAN OCEAN AND FOR NAVIGATION TRAINING

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 March, on motion by Senator Carrick:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 March last week I spoke for two minutes in support of the Government with regard to the B52 agreement, the provisions of which are that the United States Air Force will be allowed to stage a certain number of aircraft through Darwin for surveillance purposes over the Indian Ocean. I said that I welcomed that agreement. I outlined what it provided. I felt it necessary to do that in some detail because I realised, after listening to the contributions of Opposition speakers to the debate, that either they had not read the agreement or they failed to comprehend what was in it. I was talking about sub-paragraph (V) and sub-paragraph (VI) when the debate was interrupted. Sub-paragraph (V) provides:

SPEECH.PARA: Irrespective of financial arrangements agreed between the two Governments, RAAF Base Darwin shall remain an Australian facility under Australian control.
Sub-paragraph (VI) provides:

No circumstances arising from this Agreement shall affect the title of the Government of Australia to the relevant land, or the pre-existing authority of the Government of Australia in the use of RAAF Base Darwin.

I think that is a very important point in the agreement because I see the alliance with the United States as a partnership between Australia and the United States. I do not see it in terms of dominant and subservient roles. I see it as a partnership between two free and equal partners. As I hold that belief, it becomes very important to me that we retain Australian sovereignty over those bases. That is why we should pay for the developments. I think it most unwise to follow the Opposition's suggestion that the Americans pay for the base facilities that they use in this country. They are Australian property and it is very much in our interests to maintain our sovereignty, particularly in a commercial way.

When the verbiage is stripped away from the Opposition's case, we find that it is making two central points of criticism about the agreement. The first point the Opposition makes is that either Australia or Darwin has become a nuclear target overnight by virtue of the agreement. Its second point of concern is that the United States Air Force will load the B52 aircraft with ordnance, presumably nuclear ordnance, when they go through Darwin. I find both these points unacceptable. Let me deal, first of all, with the point that Darwin has suddenly become a nuclear target. The previous speaker, Senator Mason from the Australian Democrats, made much of this point. The charges he made were quite untrue. I quote verbatim from his speech. He said:
It was very much a burning question in Darwin last week; everybody was talking about it.

Madam Acting Deputy President, you and I were in Darwin at the same time as Senator Mason, as were Senator Townley and Senator Jessop from this side of the chamber. Senator Mason's statement is nonsensical and blatantly untrue. In all the time I spent in Darwin during that week no one raised the matter with me, let alone commented on it. I think it quite unjustifiable for Senator Mason to fabricate sheer political propaganda in the way he did in his speech last week. The truth is that Darwin is no more at risk today, after the agreement has been signed, than it was before. Now that we have signed this agreement to allow B52s to stage through Darwin, there is no greater liability of an attack on Australia than there was previously under the commitments we had under the ANZUS pact. Let us be perfectly clear about this. We have a liability of attack by virtue of the ANZUS agreement. Inevitably responsibilities are involved in that treaty commitment, and they are responsibilities that we as Australians are prepared to honour because the advantages we gain from the commitment far outweigh the risks.

What do we gain from the ANZUS treaty with the United States? We gain in three broad categories of value to Australia. First of all, we gain the great value of deterrence that the treaty provides. The fact that Australia is bound to the United States in a mutual defence treaty means that other people who might have aggressive intentions towards this country have to take that treaty into account and will be deterred to some degree by its existence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who?

—The effect of that deterrent cannot be measured in mere words, Senator Grimes. The second great advantage that the ANZUS treaty provides for Australia is the transfer of intelligence information. Australia is a small country with limited resources, but by being a partner to the ANZUS agreement we gain a great deal of intelligence information from United States sources that would not normally be available to us. The third value to us of the ANZUS treaty is technical information with regard to armaments and weapons systems. Again this information would not be available to us through our own resources.

SPEECH.PARA: Unquestionably the Australian public have supported the ANZUS treaty since its inception. There has never been any significant Australian opposition to that treaty, I am proud to say. Yet the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats have set out to destroy the treaty by the air of mistrust that they have shown towards this agreement. They have consistently doubted the integrity of the American position with respect to this agreement. I think the Press reports at the weekend, in which the United States Government was reported to be saying publicly that it found the position of the Labor Party and of the Australian Democrats unacceptable, are witness to the danger to the alliance of their position.

I point out that all alliances have risks. In 1939 we were allied with Britain and were at risk from Germany as a consequence. Only a few years later, in 1942, a very real risk was imposed on this country when Darwin was bombed and the Japanese were involved with us because of our alliance with Britain and the United States. But that was a risk that we were prepared to bear without rancour.

Even if we had no alliances, we would still be at risk. We would be at risk as an isolated and relatively undefended country. There is no respite from being at risk. Life involves risks. I believe the risks accruing to this country as a consequence of the ANZUS treaty are acceptable risks for the people of Australia who have shown that acceptance by supporting us consistently through the ballot box.

Let us deal with the question of Darwin being at risk. Without exception, all the Opposition speakers lack an understanding of modern armaments and weapons systems. Senator Mason's geography as well as his knowledge of weapons systems, seem to be woefully inadequate. He told us that the Royal Australian Air Force base at Learmonth was on the North West Shelf. We must be operating flying boats off it and not B52s. He repeatedly asked the questions: Why was Darwin selected? Why were the good people of Darwin placed at risk of instant assassination by nuclear bombs and rockets falling out of the sky? Why did the Australian Government select Darwin over Learmonth on the North West Shelf for the staging of the B52 bombers? Really, if Senator Mason knew anything about the B52s he would know that Darwin is the only airport in the northern part of Australia which can accept the B52s. It is the only one with taxiways wide enough to accept them with their outriggers. It is as simple as that and there is nothing more complex to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —But we were told the United States picked it.

—Maybe the United States had the wit to go to Transport Australia to buy an aerodrome chart to find out the dimensions of the runways and the taxiways to work out, in the air conditioned comfort of a Washington office, why Darwin was the base that would accept B52s. No other would.

SPEECH.PARA: The second interesting problem raised by the Opposition relates to the ordnance load carried by the aircraft. There are two points of importance. The first one is that the agreement forbids the Americans, except in certain conditions which are clearly outlined in the agreement, to carry any ordnance at all. The Government and I are prepared to accept that the United States will honour this agreement. It is very much a part of the Opposition's argument that the American word on this is repudiated, but I have said enough on that point already. The second important point is that it is just not common practice in the air forces of the Western world to carry ordnance on training flights except when there is a bombing exercise or something like that involved, particularly in relation to the operation of the B52s out of Darwin. If an aircraft carries a bomb load, its fuel load is reduced. The pay load of the aircraft is a finite factor. If they are loaded with weapons they can take less fuel. For an aircraft which is operating out of Darwin on a surveillance operation in the Indian Ocean, when one is clawing for the limits of range, even with air refuelling, it just is not a practical move to load those aircraft with ordnance. There are secondary factors involved, too. Nuclear weapons, or even conventional ordnance, are expensive. One does not subject them unnecessarily to the degradation of being winched into bomb bays and flown around with the possibility of accidental damage. They are an asset, and they are kept in air conditioned bomb shelters and bomb dumps so that they are kept in good shape.

The final point in this absurd argument is what the devil would one use the bombs for in aircraft staging out of Darwin? As somebody in the Press stated, what will the Americans do? Will they bomb whales or Russian submarines? It is just no strike target for them. If the B52s are to be used in a bombing role they will operate against Russian strategic targets on the mainland. All the strategic air command bases are in North America, Europe or in the northern part of the Pacific. That makes sense because all the strategic targets which they are interested in are in the Northern Hemisphere. One would not dispatch aircraft from Darwin to strike targets in the Urals or anywhere else on mainland Russia. It is just not common sense.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you would into the Middle East, which is the obvious channel.

—No, you would not. Is Senator Robertson suggesting that we are to put a nuclear strike in against the Middle East? Come, come! The Opposition's position is part of the continuing saga of mistrust and criticism of the United States which so characterises the socialist parties, the Labor Party and the Democrats in this chamber. Honourable senators should look at the history of this country from 1969 onwards and at the North-West Cape agreement. What has happened to every alliance and every treaty which we have had with the United States? They are prepared to trust the Russian word but they are not prepared to trust the Americans at all. Look at the legendary attacks of Dr Cairns and Mr Uren in 1973. They are a matter of record in the Hansard of the House of Representatives. There was attack after attack on our ally. To the present time the practical support for the alliance has never come from the Labor Party or from the Democrats. Let me deal with the purpose of the agreement. Why are those aircraft staging through Darwin?
—So that they can get to the Middle East and can fly through open country.

—No, not for that reason. They are staging there for the tasks which are designated-for sea surveillance and for crew training. Let us look at sea surveillance first of all. That is primarily an intelligence gathering operation. Two points emerge from this. The first point is to demonstrate a military presence in the region and, secondly, to get the intelligence to know what the Russians are up to. Russia intruded into the region of the Indian Ocean.
—You have the choice of those two. What is it to be?

—Senator Robertson has probably forgotten the invasion of Afghanistan, but I can assure him that it is still going on and people are still being murdered there. We cannot leave a vacuum in the Indian Ocean area.

SPEECH.PARA: The B52 has a very long range and it is a very good platform for surveillance purposes. It may well need to be modified from its bombing role, but that is technically quite feasible. It is quite feasible to install the equipment either in the fuselage or on the wing stations in pod installations to provide what we want. The virtues of this aircraft are, firstly, that it has a very long range and, secondly, that it has relatively unlimited space in it. A whole range of stores and crews can be placed in its fuselage because it is so large. The larger an aircraft is the volume increases in proportion to the cube of the length. There is plenty of electrical power. There are all the requirements for long range surveillance, long range space and power in the aircraft. The three common methods of surveillance-I am presuming here; I do not know what these aircraft have-are electromagnetic, electro-optical and optical facilities. The electromagnetic facilities of radar and elint-electronic intelligence gathering-can be fitted. The electro-optical, the infra-red sensors and the photographic optical sensors are all possible fits for this aircraft. I refuse to comment or to speculate further on what these aircraft might have in them, but I assert that they have the potential to provide a complete surveillance capacity for the task which they are declared to follow.

One of the great defence experts on the Labor side of the House is Senator Evans and he kept asking the question, in the form of interjection, as to why the B52s. I will tell him why the B52s. It is simply because it is all the United States has that is spare for this capacity. The United States operates P3s as long-range maritime patrol aircraft. If Senator Evans could read the papers he would see in the popular Press from time to time pictures of the airport at Diego Garcia with P3s on the runway. The United States Navy, as the operating authority for P3s, is short of them. It will be years before they come up to the operational strength which the United States Navy wants. The United States has the B52s of which they have a relative-I stress the word 'relative'-surplus, so they are tasked for this job.

The second point which was raised in the agreement was that they will be used for navigational training. That is a most important requirement because air crews must fly to maintain their proficiency. Another important point is that the United States Air Force has negligible operational experience in the Indian Ocean. It is not a theatre in which it has had much experience because it has had no bases in the region. It is important to know the meteorological conditions and the geography and to develop a familiarity with the region operationally. That is an entirely justifiable purpose.

In conclusion I turn to the most important point of all and that is the Russian superiority in numbers-not in technology but in numbers of conventional arms and of nuclear capacity. That capacity must be matched by the Western world. We cannot leave a vacuum there. It is not for the obvious reason that we might become involved in an armed conflict. It is for the directly contrary reason. If we do not provide a presence in the Indian Ocean we will allow the Russians to threaten, to exercise pressure on and in fact to blackmail the nations in the region both politically and economically, that is, to conquer without open conflict. Then we will lose our liberty and our freedom. That is the real significance of what the supporters of the Australian Labor Party and the Democrats are doing. They are putting at risk the ultimate freedoms of Australia by refusing to support this agreement. For ideological reasons and for cheap meretricious political point scoring they are denying the support that they should be giving to this alliance. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to take this opportunity to advise honourable senators of Government decisions on a number of matters on domestic air transport, including the Government's initial response to the Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares. The Government commissioned this inquiry into domestic air fares early in 1980 and the inquiry reported on 16 February 1981. The report was tabled in the Parliament shortly thereafter. The inquiry's report is an extensive one and contributes a great deal of valuable work towards expanding the knowledge of airline costs and revenues. However, the inquiry recognised a considerable amount of detailed work would still be necessary to derive and verify the most appropriate fare setting formula based on current costs. The report at page 277 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Verification . . . various matters associated with determining an air fare pricing policy, derived by way of a formula, will be an exacting task for the regulatory authority.

The Government will be arranging further substantial discussions with the airlines immediately so this task can be completed by July 1981. In undertaking this task, the Government will, as necessary, draw upon independent advice. At this stage, the Government has accepted the following principles contained in the inquiry's recommendations: First, we will adopt a cost based, nationally consistent approach by use of an air fare formula comprising a flagfall and a distance rate for the national jet network. We endorse the inquiry's view on the approach to be taken to discount fares. The Government supports as wide a range of discount fares as possible without increasing the burden on the full fare paying passenger. Discounts for the aged and provision of tour basing fares are to be considered further with the airlines. The Government is concerned that special innovative discounts which are negotiated by the airlines on the basis of their commercial viability must stand the test of public scrutiny. The Government decided that an independent tribunal should be established with powers to hear and make decisions upon proposals for changes to air fares. The powers, structure and scope of the tribunal are under consideration.

As I stated earlier, the report is extensive and further investigation is necessary because, although the broad principles contained in the recommendations are acceptable to the Government, the cost allocation methodology requires detailed analysis. I am concerned also that further consideration must be given to the question of the pricing of the F27 services of Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans-Australia Airlines. In addition, the reports recommendations advocating the adoption of a profit target must be more fully examined. The Government has also decided in principle to establish TAA as a public company. The Government has under consideration the nature and structure of such a company. Such an arrangement should enable TAA to compete more effectively in a more commercial environment.

In March, the Government deferred consideration of tariff increases sought by the airlines until it completed its initial review of the inquiry's recommendations. It has now been decided to approve increases in fares using a new formula which meets the thrust of the inquiry's recommendations. The Government was concerned that the delay in this tariff approval is costing the airlines about $1.2m per week. To delay approval of this increase further in an attempt to achieve greater refinements is inappropriate as the lost revenue would ultimately lead to higher fares in order to recoup that revenue. Already the delay has meant that the level of justified increase is now at 8.9 per cent.

The level of the economy fare increase has been offset by variations in other fare types. Overall, an 8.9 per cent increase in revenue for the airlines was justified and this will be achieved by, firstly, an increase in the first class differential to 1.45 times the economy fares. After allowing for some diversion from first to economy class travel this adjustment will achieve a reduction in economy fares. Secondly, the increase will be achieved by a withdrawal of the 20 per cent APEX fare-the advance purchase excursion fare-the first class night coach, first class tertiary discount fares and off peak fares and a reduction in the level of discounts for APEX fares from 40 per cent to 35 per cent and standby fares from 30 per cent to 25 per cent. The adjustments to discount fares will achieve a reduction in economy fares of 1.1 per cent.

I must emphasise that these variations in fares are entirely consistent with the inquiry's recommendations. They enable the level of increase in the economy jet fares to be kept to an average of 7.4 per cent. The new economy jet formula is to be $40 plus 6.848c per kilometre with a second distance rate of 5.821c per kilometre for travel over 2,200 kilometres between Perth and Melbourne or Sydney and Darwin and Adelaide or Brisbane. Recognising the major increases in fares that this formula would bring on routes operated by Ansett and TAA between Melbourne and Tasmania and that alternative land-based modes are not available, the Government has set fares on these routes at 90 per cent of the formula and, in accordance with the approach recommended by the inquiry, the loss in revenue will be met by the Government. This subsidy is expected to cost $5m per annum at the new fare levels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the eyes of the Opposition, this statement of the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) is one of the most disgusting statements on transport ever presented to the national Parliament. It dramatically alters the two-airline agreement. In 42 small words-or 42 pieces of silver-we have sold out a public enterprise to a new breed of millionaires as part of a pay back for the support that that group of millionaires has given in recent times to the Liberal and National Country parties. We have succumbed to the pressure of Ansett Transport Industries Ltd and in the adoption of this statement, in the processes of the legislation ultimately, we will have destroyed one of the finest public instrumentalities that this country has seen operating in the post-war years. It will be the birth of a one-airline agreement. Clearly, 'Do as you want as long as you give us good Press' is the principle by which the Fraser Administration operates the assets of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The Fraser Administration has no mandate for the sale of Trans-Australia Airlines. It has no mandate to float it as a public company and, in fact, this statement repudiates an election promise made by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and by the Minister for Transport before and during the 1980 general election that TAA would not be sold. As I say, in 42 small words this statement, without any explanation, without any excuse, without any reason, simply states the bald facts-that TAA is to be auctioned off as a public enterprise. This is the latest piece of capitulation to Ansett Transport Industries by a government which refused to help Sir Reginald Ansett, the founder of the original company, when he was fighting off the raiders on the stock exchange a year or so ago and by a government which now takes the next extraordinary step of agreeing to the submission by that organisation to the recent Holcroft inquiry. Let it be clearly understood by the Australian people that it will not be a publicly-owned enterprise, a public company, as suggested in this statement, but the big corporations that will be buying up either the majority or minority shareholding of the publicly-formed TAA company. It will be another example of how the big corporations exert their influence upon the actions of this Government. It will be a further example of the way in which these backroom deals are arranged to suit the corporations which are rapidly buying out all of the smaller companies or even major companies in our country.

It is a preposterous statement because nowhere does it justify the rejection of the Holcroft inquiry's recommendations and nowhere does it satisfy the Opposition that the decision to change the financial structure of TAA will result in any savings as far as the travelling public is concerned. Nowhere in the statement is there any justification of the Government's belief that by taking this dramatic step of altering the functions of our public instrumentality this will affect the fare structure of TAA or the services provided by it in the whole of the post-war years.

This decision will be fought by the Opposition and, I would hope, by the Australian community, until such time as the instrumentality known as TAA is returned to public ownership. Changing the form of ownership of TAA cannot in any way improve the service. It cannot in any way put into effect the so-called philosophy of the Fraser Government that competition is an essential part of the way in which our airlines should operate. Whilst it is conceded that there are some financial disabilities from which TAA suffers in comparison with Ansett, that is precisely because Ansett has always enjoyed a superiority in its relationships with the airline industry. TAA has always been in a position subordinate to Ansett as a direct result of the policies pursued by the conservative governments over the last couple of decades.

Let it be remembered that invariably the airline agreements have been entered into in the dying days of conservative administrations just as they were, for example, in 1972 and again in 1979 and 1980 when matters affecting the airlines were decided by a government facing the electors for re-election. That prevented in 1972 any consideration by a new government of minimising the effect of policy decisions that had been made by a government that clearly was going to be defeated at the polls. The sale of TAA to private enterprise will transfer ownership of a valuable public transport asset to wealthy investors and stock exchange manipulators and speculators. We have seen so much evidence of this in recent times. One finds it inconceivable that any government worth its salt, any government calling itself an Australian government representing the interests of Australia, would put forward such a proposition, in such a document, and in such a cursory and superficial fashion.

Let us look at some of the other factors included in the statement. The statement completely demolishes the recommendations made by the Holcroft report in respect of the fare formula. Despite the substance of the membership of the Holcroft committee, the stature of the people involved in that inquiry who sat and considered the submissions of those involved in the airline industry, the recommendations and conclusions of those people were just put aside without any explanation. Indeed, the whole of this statement completely ignores the recommendations of the Holcroft inquiry.

When we look at the statement in more detail-Madam Acting Deputy President, you will appreciate that I am acting under some constraints in this debate insofar as I am required to complete my remarks in 15 minutes-we find a number of irregularities in it. It says that the Government will be arranging substantial discussions with the airlines. It has already had those discussions with Ansett and it is now proposing to change the structure so far as TAA is concerned. The Government then says it will draw upon independent advice. Who are to be the independent advisers? The Government has had such advisers and rejected their advice.

In the statement the Government says that it will adopt a cost-based nationally consistent approach for the air fare formula. One can only say that the Government has had the opportunity of considering those matters in respect of the Holcroft inquiry and has completly dismissed them. In fact, the Government has almost substantially taken on board the Ansett Airlines of Australia submission to the Holcroft inquiry and ignored the comments made by the inquiry in respect of the Ansett submission. Of course, the Government has made some suggestions about changing the fares but one is entitled to ask why is it that the Department of Transport said only four weeks ago that air fares in Australia would rise by 7.9 per cent and why just four weeks later this has been amended to a rise of 8.9 per cent. This is a difference amounting to a 1.1 per cent increase in exactly four weeks. If that were to be translated in general consumer price index terms it would mean an increase of 13 per cent on an annual basis.

The Government also discussed a first class differential. Nothing in the statement indicates how that conclusion was reached. On page 3 of the statement the Government speaks of the establishment of an independent tribunal, at a time when it has freely canvassed that independent tribunals such as the Prices Justification Tribunal and the Trade Practices Commission are also due for the axe, to be disbanded as part of the razor gang's operations. What sort of independent tribunal will be established with powers to hear and make decisions on proposals for changes to air fares? This represents a pandering to free trade fanatics, to that group of economists who believe that all the problems will be solved if we sell off our public enterprise.

I remind the Senate of one of the grievous mistakes made by conservative governments in the immediate post-war years when Commonwealth Oil Refineries was sold off. It would have been a very valuable asset to this country if it had been operated as a public instrumentality in these latter years. Look at what the Government has done to airline charges for passenger movements throughout Australia. Tasmania is to be subsidised at last. When members of the Labor Party in August last year went to Tasmania to meet with representatives of the Tasmanian Government to try to overcome the disadvantages to air travellers because of the isolation of Tasmania and decided to take on board the recommendation of the Tasmanian Government for some subsidisation of air fares we were accused by Mr Malcolm Fraser and by his lackeys among the Tasmanian representatives in the national Parliament of pandering to the electorate and of being interested only in getting votes. What has this Government done? In fact, it has done what it so often does; that is, take on board a Labor Party initiative and then claim it as a significant concession-in this case for the air travellers of Tasmania. We have one small step for Western Australia-taking into consideration the criticism mounting in the Government benches about the Holcroft inquiry and the discontent that exists there-and we have had one great leapfrog for Tasmania. That is good news for Tasmania. It puts into effect one of the initiatives the Labor Party suggested when recognising the disadvantages of Tasmanian people in travelling to the mainland.

In no way can we say that the report is satisfactory. In fact, it is a monstrous report that seeks to change the basis of airline travel which has operated to the advantage and satisfaction of air travellers for a considerable number of years. It is another example of the cynicism of the Fraser Government that in just a short few months since the last election when it made a definite statement to the electorate to the effect that there would be no interference with the operation of Trans-Australia Airlines that it has come out now to take steps to change that very important instrumentality. It is another example of the cynicism of the Fraser Government when three Ministers have resigned from the Fraser administration and there have been three by-elections within three months of the Federal election. These facts indicate the way in which the Government treats its responsibilites to the Australian people.

I give an assurance on behalf of the Opposition, on behalf of the Australian Labor Party, and I hope on behalf of the Australian community, that we will resist to the utmost the changes proposed by the Government. We will use every resource at our disposal to fight the decision of the Fraser administration to dispose of the very wonderful instrumentality known as TAA. We will fight to the limit any attempt to interfere with the other Government airline, Qantas Airways Ltd. We throw down that challenge to the Government and state that we will not rest until such time as TAA again becomes a public instrumentality wholly owned by the Australian people. We warn those corporations which want to get their dirty, greasy fingers on TAA that they will suffer as a result of their pressures that will change the structure of TAA as a public instrumentality.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very interested while listening to Senator Gietzelt's remarks. First of all he complained about constraints of time. Indeed, in this debate by agreement we have limited ourselves to 15 minutes each. I have no argument with that. Having made that complaint Senator Gietzelt spent at least half of his speech talking about the Government's proposal to sell Trans-Australia Airlines. Nowhere in the Minister's statement did I see anything in regard to selling TAA. The report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has also decided in principle to establish TAA as a public company.

That is a far cry from selling TAA. I would not myself be a party to selling TAA though admittedly some of my colleagues would be and have said so in this chamber in times past. Currently, that is not the Government's intention. Unfortunately, Senator Gietzelt's statement will undoubtedly be taken up by the fourth estate in banner headlines tomorrow stating 'Government intending to sell TAA'. I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that Qantas Airways Ltd is a public company registered in Queensland. The mere fact that the Government owns 100 per cent of the shares does not appear to enter into the argument. As I said, it is not the Government's intention to sell the airline. Sir Robert Law-Smith, the Chairman of the Australian National Airlines Commission has welcomed the change in status of TAA to that of a public company. The Government can quite rightly maintain a 100 per cent shareholding in it. Will it do so? I do not know. The Government can. Certainly it is not going to sell the airline. I would have no objection myself to the Government's selling some shares to the staff, if possible, with the Government maintaining a majority interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you give a guarantee that you won't change your mind?

—Certainly I can give Senator Gietzelt a guarantee. I will do all I can to see that TAA remains in Government hands at least with a very big majority holding because I fear the things the honourable senator fears. I think that if we completely sold TAA it would not be too long before a duopoly became a monopoly to the detriment of the travelling public of Australia. The Government has not said in this statement that it is going to sell the airline but that it will look at the options. SPEECH.PARA: Senator Gietzelt also mentioned that the Government was setting up a tribunal. Nowhere in the Holcroft report did it say that this should happen. As I read through all the recommendations I see one constant theme about a regulatory authority. The Holcroft report was rather critical of the role that had been played by the Department of Transport as it saw fit to pass judgment on proposed fare increases. In that criticism the report recognised that Transport Australia probably operated under some difficulty and recommended a regulatory authority, a body apart from Transport Australia or departmental offices. The Holcroft report frequently refers in its recommendations to the regulatory authority.

I suppose once again the headlines will banner wrongly that the Government intends to sell TAA. The proposal could mean a departure from the norm as far as air fares go. Australia has gone along with most of the other airlines which are signatories to International Air Transport Association agreements in that Australia has a basic formula by which air fares are worked out. A flagfall consists of so many components and a distance component consists of other charges. The Holcroft report has gone into that matter thoroughly and has justified all that has been done, but it has departed from the norm. The Government has seen fit to take that matter up. I am a little concerned because, whereas until today the formula gave us an idea where we stood as far as the other airlines of the world are concerned, we will now be a pacesetter and we will not be able to draw that comparison quite as easily. As I have said the Holcroft report has made this recommendation, with justification. I will instance one or two examples.

It has always been normal procedure for the cost of fuel to be added to the distance component. The Holcroft report quite rightly points out that a certain amount of fuel is used for taxi-ing, takeoff and climb-out and so it considers that that portion should come off the distance component and be added to the flagfall component. It has always been the procedure that the cost of flight attendants, as against flight crews, be considered in the flagfall component. That has never made much sense to me. The report quite rightly states that that should be considered in the distance component. Flight crew costs have always been considered part of the distance component and the Holcroft report has indicated that the flight crew spend part of their time on the ground when they prepare their flight plan, check their aircraft, start up, taxi out and climb-out so those components should also be split up. As I have said it is a departure from what has been the accepted norm around the world, but there was a good reason for making these changes. They mean that we will depart from the norm. I cannot imagine that Australia will be a pacesetter. I do not see world airlines falling over themselves to follow us in this matter. It will be a little harder to draw comparisons with the efficiency of our airlines. We are now able to compare the core fare or the standard economy fare of our airlines with overseas airlines to see how we shape up. It has not been the best method of comparison, but it has been one whereby lay people, who travel around the world, have been able to see how we shape up.

This situation is a departure from the norm and Australia, with this new formula, will be a world leader. Because of the new formula we have had the predictable results. I have said previously in this chamber that long-haul passengers have been disadvantaged and the Independant Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares picked up that fact. Since then the Government, quite rightly, has recognised this fact and has increased the flagfall component more than the distance component, with the result that the long-haul fares have gone up at a slower rate than short-haul fares. Basically in one fell swoop we have probably righted the wrong. We have seen a small reduction in the long-haul fares-I will not quote examples because the paper is before honourable senators-and a fare increase on some of the short hauls. Of course, this is not without its problems because if we increase short-haul fares to any great extent we will turn many passengers to bus and rail transport.

I have only one argument with that. It is generally recognised, throughout the airline network, that about 60 per cent of the people who travel by air are Mr and Mrs Smith who are on ordinary holidays or visiting relatives, and only 40 per cent are business or government passengers who do not worry too much about the fare. If we see a decline in the number of those passengers, the bottom line that the airlines look at in their financial returns will be altered, with the result that air fares overall would have to go up again. So we have a problem. We cannot go too much further than we have done currently, otherwise we will lose some of our short-haul passengers.

TALK.START.PARA: —You might use the arrangements to make sure that people who have to take long-haul flights do get them at convenient times.

—I wish it were as simple as that, but it is not. I think part of the problem that the honourable senator raised could be overcome if we lifted a few curfews around the place, but we had better not start that argument in a 15-minute debate. I will wait until Senator Mulvihill is out of the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Another recommendation that the Holcroft report made is that whereas we have had three basic fares to now-the economy fare, the first class fare and the standard fare which is for F27s-we should settle on one basic core fare and let the companies make their own arrangements about commercial discounts. I think everybody welcomes the situation where we have one core fare and other discounts are made using commercial judgment. Until now, discounts almost ran riot, and full-fare-paying passengers basically paid for the discounts. I do not think anybody saw any injustice in that. The Holcroft report pointed that situation out and said that there should be commercial discounts but not at the expense of full-fare-paying passengers.

Once again if we have too many discount fares we could run into a problem. When discounts in the United States ran riot there were so many fares that nobody really knew what the fares were. A person would ring to make a booking. He asked the cheapest fare and stated what route he wanted to use. At times it would take half an hour to an hour to get the proper fare formula. Finally the reservations were getting so far behind that the airlines had to employ more staff, their base costs went up and the whole thing started to become counter-productive. At one stage the American airlines withdrew from discounting. I think the Australian airlines at that stage had more discount fares than the American airlines did. I think we are one of the few countries in the world which have student discount fares, just to name one example.

The Holcroft report recognised the situation in Tasmania and the Government has picked up that point. I understand that the $5m subsidy which the Government has announced is a once only subsidy so that this time the increase to Tasmania will be 90 per cent of the overall increase. This recognises the fact which the Holcroft report picked up, that Tasmania does have a particular difficulty. Sometimes we shy away from subsidies, but we would all like to have them in our back yard for a particular project. But there is a general recognition in the Holcroft report that people in Tasmania do not have an alternative. They cannot hop on a bus or a train to get to the mainland. I just make the observation that the Holcroft inquiry picked up that point.

The Holcroft inquiry, as I recall, said that the F27 routes were substantially cross-subsidised and that on its examination the flagfall was less than half what it should be. Of course, taken to its conclusion, that means that the flagfall on the F27 runs ultimately will be twice what it is now. If the air fare for the F27 route is to be doubled it will create problems. To compound the problem, apart from the HS748 aircraft, which is about the same size as the F27 but does not operate commercially in Australia, the Bandeirante Nomad and Metro types of aircraft, there is not really an alternative to the F27 which is immediately available. The nearest that I can ascertain from my investigations is either the de Havilland Dash 8 or the Saab Fairchild, which will not be available until 1985-86.
