If we are to provide air transport for all Australians, and particularly for those in remote areas-indeed, they have an entitlement-we are faced with a dilemma in that there is to be a fairly hefty fare increase and no suitable alternative aircraft is available. As I have said, there are smaller aircraft which can do the job reasonably well, but the Dash 8 or Saab Fairchild will be better propositions when they become available. I support the Government's initiatives in what it has done and the recommendations it has taken up from the Holcroft report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats also view with grave concern the statement on airline policy by the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt). We believe that fundamental decisions have been made without the proper information. We regard this statement as thoroughly inadequate, which is all that could be expected in view of the Government's decision to truncate the Holcroft inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: The Holcroft inquiry would not mean much to many Australians, but to Western Australians and Tasmanians I would have thought that it was very significant. Let me go very briefly into its history. Early in 1980 several Western Australian Liberal senators became quite worried about the activities of the Fair Air Fare Campaign in Western Australia in relation to cross-subsidisation. They very properly and courageously went to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and stated: 'We believe that Western Australians are paying something like $20m to subsidise the air fares of eastern passengers. Let us have an inquiry'. In response to that request the Government appointed Mr Warwick Holcroft, Dr Harold F. Bell, O.B.E. and Professor Warren Hogan to the Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares. After the election was over-after the Government had won-when there was no need for a political inquiry, the Government, quite extraordinarily, said to these three distinguished Australians: 'Your work is over. Instead of finishing the inquiry properly by mid-1981 you will finish it by January 1981'. In other words, it truncated the inquiry to such an extent that it could not possibly conclude its work.

Why did the Government truncate the work of this inquiry before it could report properly? I think some of the clues are given in the report. These are very disturbing. We must remember that this report could shortly form a basis for information of this Senate when it is asked to ratify a new two-airline agreement which will tie up civil aviation in this country for 10 years. I now give notice that the Australian Democrats will be voting against ratification of that agreement if the Government tries to rush the legislation through this Senate before 30 June. I have authority from Senator Button to say that Labor Party senators will also be voting against ratification unless and until a Senate select committee takes up and completes the work that the Holcroft committee was prevented from doing. Tonight I challenge the six West Australian Liberal senators-Senator Thomas, Senator Withers, Senator Martyr, Senator Sim, the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney)-to stand up now, after they have won the election, and to vote in favour of a Senate select committee to complete the work of the Holcroft inquiry into domestic air fares. There is time for it to be done. Similarly, I challenge Liberal Tasmanian senators to do the same.

Although Tasmanians have been handed something in this statement in that they will pay only 90 per cent of the formula, how does Senator Watson know that 90 per cent is a fair figure? How does he know that 75 per cent of the formula would not be fairer? He does not know. He could not know. The Government could not know because it did not give the Holcroft committee time to complete its inquiry. I ask Liberal West Australian and Tasmanian senators to agree to a Senate select committee to complete the work of the Holcroft committee. I do not think that is an unreasonable request. The results of this very bad decision emerge again and again in the Minister's statement. On the very first page the Minister states:
The Inquiry recognised a considerable amount of detailed work would still be necessary to derive and verify the most appropriate fare-setting formula based on current costs.

The Minister has the effrontery to put that sentence in his statement. Yet he was the one who disbanded the Holcroft committee prematurely. Let us look at some of the remarks of the Holcroft committee. They are at least apt to cause great concern among people who, like the members of the Senate, are to be asked to endorse the new 10-year two-airline agreement. The report stated:
The contribution from Ansett however proved far from spontaneous and the delay in settling the basis of agreement to supply information hampered the Inquiry's operations.
It then went on to make detailed criticism of Ansett Airlines of Australia. It stated:

It seemed to the Inquiry that Ansett was failing to recognise that the Inquiry was established by the Government as an independent public one with the express aim of clarifying in the public arena certain matters impinging upon air fares.
The committee made devastating remarks about the Department of Transport. It stated:

These delays in the supply of data were more than matched by the failure of the Department of Transport to make a written submission to the Inquiry until 10 December 1980, some two weeks after the Inquiry had been informed by the Minister for Transport that it was required to report by 31 January 1981.

It then commented on the two-airline policy. This is the whole basis upon which this Senate is to be asked to ratify a new two-airline agreement for 10 years. Yet the Holcroft inquiry specifically stated this about the two-airline policy:
Yet the evidence today--
That is, in relation to the two-airline policy-

is strongly against this belief in economies of scale and decreasing unit costs of providing a service. Thus the main presumption underlying the inauguration of the Two-Airlines Policy is not now applicable if it ever was.
They are devastating remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, dreadful.

—Senator Sim, at 10.50 on this night,when the proceedings are being broadcast, makes these inane stupid remarks-they are not remarks but noises-but he will have his moment. He will be asked to cross this floor to vote in favour of a Senate select committee before we endorse the two-airline agreement for another 10 years. Senator Sim, along with the other West Australian senators and the Tasmanian senators, will be asked whether they will put West Australian travellers into hock to the extent of millions of dollars each year as outlined by the Holcroft inquiry which Senator Sim voted to have truncated.
—I'll vote all right, my friend.

—I am sorry that I did not hear Senator Sim's interjection. If he said that he will vote against the agreement I thank him for his interjection and admire his courage and independence. I place that on the record. I am sorry that I did not hear what Senator Sim said. Why did the Government abort the inquiry if, as it now admits, a 'considerable amount of detailed work' was still necessary for it to be able to draw rational conclusions about its main term of reference, namely, how to set domestic air fares.

SPEECH.PARA: On the second page of the statement the Government says that it will 'draw upon independent advice' in its future inquiries into air fare determinations. The Government had independent advice-the Holcroft committee-but it sacked the committee which was giving it independent advice. The question still remains, and I ask any Government senator to tell the Senate the answer: Why did the Government sack the Holcroft committee before it was time for it to report? On page 2 of the statement we see that the Government will be arranging 'further substantial discussions with the airlines' on air fares. I ask: Which airlines? There are more than two airlines in Australia. East-West Airlines Ltd is one. If the Government means to stick blindly to the two-airline policy why does it not say: 'Trans-Australia Airlines and Ansett' instead of 'the airlines'? There is something significant in that statement which is delightfully vague.

The statement says that the fare structure will be completed by July 1981. One should tie that statement in with what Holcroft says on page 277 of his report. He says that it will be completed by July 1981 because the financial year of Ansett and TAA begins on 1 July each year. From that statement I judge that the Government will have the discussions with the airlines on fares, will make its decision and will ram the two-airline policy through both Houses of this Parliament well before the Senate rises at the end of May this year. I ask all honourable senators to be conscious of that timing schedule. It is highly significant.

On page 3 of the statement the Government says that an 'independent tribunal' will be established with power over changes in air fares. We welcome that. We give it a cautious welcome, however, because we note that 'the powers, structure and scope of the tribunal' are still under consideration. Is this not a strange way in which to establish a national civil aviation airlines policy for the next 10 years? One would have thought that those things would have already been contemplated, discussed and announced in one hit instead of coming to the Senate in bits and pieces in an incoherent form. I agree with the Minister when he says that the cost allocation methodology of the Holcroft committee is something to be looked at. I do not accept the figures as they are given because, to use a famous expression, they seem rubbery. But was not that another reason why the Holcroft committee should have been allowed to complete its report? Again the question arises: Why did the Government guillotine the work on this most valuable inquiry? But the central point of the statement, as I understand it, is this:
The Government has decided in principle to establish TAA as a public company.

I admire Senator Collard for his views on civil aviation. He said it will be over his dead body, or words to that effect, that the Government sells off a majority shareholding in TAA. But why did not the Minister say that? The Minister already has raised this monster that TAA will be sold off. I do not draw conclusions from the fact that one of the great private enterprise predators in this country, a distinguished West Australian by the name of Mr Holmes a'Court, was in Parliament tonight dining with three Ministers and two prominent Liberal back benchers. I am not drawing any sinister conclusions from that meeting. I am saying that if the Government is going to structure TAA as a public company and make a majority of its shareholding available to the public or for private purposes, it is wide open for predators such as Mr Holmes a'Court to purchase TAA.

Senator Rae went to some trouble to assure me that this is only the first step in structuring. I accept that. But what about the confusion upon confusion that a statement such as this will throw into the civil aviation industry? It would have been a very simple matter to add to the statement that the Government will be structuring TAA as a public company-we commend that-'but it will not be sold off to private enterprise'. Senator Collard was prepared to say that. This is an area that leads to very great concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are lost for words.

—Some smart-Alick has interrupted. Who was the smart-Alick who said that I am lost for words? Will he identify himself? Look at the courageous people on the other side of the chamber. I was trying to do the Government Whip a favour because the Government has some legislation to bring on now. I am not lost for words. I was to adjourn the debate now but, as the courageous gentleman on the other side will not identify himself, to co-operate with the Government, I now seek leave to continue my remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill will provide legislative authority for the entry into force of comprehensive double taxation agreements with Malaysia and Sweden. The agreements, which were signed on 20 August 1980 and 14 January 1981 respectively, deal with all substantial forms of income flowing between Australia and the other two countries. Neither of the agreements can enter into force until all necessary constitutional processes are completed both by Australia and the other country. For Australia, this Bill will, when assented to, complete the processes required of us.

Double taxation agreements have two principal functions-the elimination of international double taxation and the prevention of fiscal evasion. The former involves the apportionment, by one means or another, of the relevant taxation revenue between the contracting countries. There are various ways of doing this. For example, some income is taxed only in the country of residence while other income is taxed only in the country where it has its source. The country of source may agree to limit its tax on some items of income and, where it is agreed that both countries may tax particular income, the country of residence of the taxpayer agrees to allow relief against its tax in recognition of the payment of tax to the other country. Such taxation revenue as is forgone by one country or the other has to be seen in the light of the favourable impact that these agreements have on trade and investment flows, and on the improvement of more general relationships between countries. And it is often overlooked that, where a country in which income originates agrees to reduce its rate of tax on income, the taxpayer's country of residence will also be levying tax on the income with credit for the reduced tax of the country of origin.

Each of the new agreements accords in essential respects with the position that Australian governments have taken over the years in relation to double taxation agreements. Both of the new comprehensive agreements provide for the country of source to limit its withholding tax on dividends. Under both agreements, Australia is to reduce its withholding tax on dividends flowing to the other country from 30 per cent to 15 per cent of the amount of the dividends. In converse circumstances, Sweden will reduce its rate of dividend withholding tax from 30 per cent to 15 per cent while Malaysia, which does not at present impose a tax on dividends paid to residents of Australia in addition to the Malaysian tax on company profits out of which the dividends are paid, agrees that if it should subsequently impose a tax on dividends it will be limited to 15 per cent in the case of dividends paid to Australian residents. Both agreements specify a limit on each country's tax on interest and royalties paid to residents of the other.

Under the Malaysian agreement the general limit is to be 15 per cent for both interest and royalties. This is the rate at which, under Malaysian law, withholding tax is payable on interest and royalties paid to non-residents. However, as an incentive measure, Malaysia will exempt from tax interest on approved loans or long term loans, and 'approved industrial royalties', as defined in the relevant Malaysian incentives legislation, paid from Malaysia to Australian residents. Australia's withholding tax rate on interest is 10 per cent and will not, therefore, be affected by these arrangements. We do not have a withholding rate for royalties paid overseas. These are taxed on the ordinary assessment basis. The limit on the tax on royalties will affect Australian tax on royalties paid to Malaysia only where our tax on the ordinary assessment basis on the profit element in the royalties would have been greater than 15 per cent of the gross royalties.

If nothing were done to avoid the situation, the action of Malaysia in providing an 'incentive' exemption from its tax on certain interest and royalties would simply result in Australia not having to give credit for Malaysian tax against its tax on the relevant interest and royalties. In other words, Australia would pick up the tax forgone by Malaysia, thus nullifying the incentive. To avoid that result, Australia, as a 'tax sparing' measure, is to tax Australian recipients of the relevant interest and royalties, and allow credit against its tax, as if Malaysian tax of 10 per cent of the interest or royalties had been paid. These special arrangements are appropriate in an agreement with a developing country, such as Malaysia, in a sector of the world in which Australia has vital interests of more than one kind.

The rules under the Swedish agreement are more conventional. The tax of the country of source is to be limited to 10 per cent for both interest and royalties. This will not affect Australia's tax on interest flowing to Sweden nor, since Sweden does not tax interest paid to non-residents unless the interest is classified as business income, will it affect Sweden's tax on interest flowing to Australia. However, were Sweden to tax such income in the future the limit of 10 per cent would apply. As in Australia, royalties are taxed in Sweden on an assessment basis, so that the limit on the tax on royalties under the agreement will only affect Australian tax on royalties paid to Sweden, or Sweden's tax on royalties paid to Australia, where tax on the ordinary assessment basis on the profit element in the royalties would have been greater than the agreed limit. Both agreements contain measures for the formal relief of double taxation of income that may be taxed by both countries. The country of residence of the taxpayer is obliged to provide the necessary relief. So far as Australian residents are concerned, income in respect of which a limit is imposed by the agreements on the tax of the country of source-dividends, interest and royalties-will be taxed here with credit being allowed for the tax of the country of source, apart from dividends received from abroad by Australian companies, which are effectively tax-free here. Other income that is taxed in full in the country of source will be exempt from our tax.
A memorandum containing more detailed explanations of technical aspects of the Bill and of the agreements is being made available to honourable senators. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The speech read as follows-

The main purpose of this Bill is to amend the Commonwealth Banks Act 1959 to give effect, with respect to the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, to the Government's policy on voluntary early retirement, and management-initiated redeployment and retirement. The Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act 1979, referred to as the CE(RR) Act, which was proclaimed to come into operation on 6 February 1981, makes provision with respect to the redeployment and retirement of Commonwealth employees, including those of prescribed Commonwealth authorities. It is open to any Commonwealth authority, such as the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, to seek to become a prescribed Commonwealth authority for the purposes of that Act. This would bring the authority within the scope of the redeployment provisions of the Act, and the provisions for management-initiated retirement and for voluntary retirement by officers who have attained the age of 55 years.

The Commonwealth Banking Corporation does not wish to avail itself of this option. This is in the light of its role as an integral part of the competitive banking and finance industry. It is considered that the Corporation already has, within its existing staffing policies and practices, effective internal redeployment arrangements that are consistent with the spirit of the redeployment provisions of the CE(RR) Act. In fact, the Commonwealth banks have always been conscious of the need to ensure, to the greatest extent that is practicable, that they operate in such a manner as to make efficient and economical use of their staff resources and, since their inception, have practised redeployment of staff in the interests of providing efficient service to their customers.

In addition, in the light of the sensitive and confidential nature of banking business, it is felt important by the Corporation that the Commonwealth banks maintain an image of independence in the eyes of their customers, including those with international affiliations. However, the Corporation, with the support of the Commonwealth Bank Officers Association, sought the Government's agreement to introduce voluntary early retirement from age 55 years for male officers of the Corporation by appropriate amendments to the Commonwealth Banks Act. Female officers in the Corporation already have this right.

Accordingly, after consideration, the Government decided to introduce amendments to the Commonwealth Banks Act to provide for age 55 retirement for all Corporation staff on the basis that, as appropriate, the Act also be amended to bring it into line with relevant provisions of the CE(RR) Act. This Bill implements that decision. The nature of the proposed amendments has been discussed with the Commonwealth Banking Corporation and the Commonwealth Bank Officers Association and both parties fully accept the approach taken. The opportunity is also being taken with this Bill to amend section 24 of the Commonwealth Banks Act relating to disclosure of interests by board members and to effect certain other minor amendments.

I now outline the main provisions of the Bill. Clause 6 will amend section 102 of the principal Act to provide for a minimum retiring age of 55 years and a maximum retiring age of 65 years for all officers of the Corporation. Currently the minimum and maximum retiring ages are 60 and 65 years respectively for male officers, and 55 and 60 years respectively for female officers. The amendment will remove the present differences between retiring ages for male and female officers and bring the provisions of the Commonwealth Banks Act into line with the provisions of the CE(RR) Act with respect to voluntary early age retirement.

Sub-section 102 (2) of the principal Act provides that, where a male officer continues in the Corporation's service after the age of 60 years, the officer may at any time before attaining the age of 65 years be retired by the Corporation from the service. The corresponding ages for female officers are 55 and 60 years respectively. Clause 6 will replace existing sub-section 102 (2) with a new provision that will apply to an officer who has reached the minimum retiring age of 55 years. Under the new provision, the Corporation will cease to have the right to retire an officer simply because he has reached the minimum retiring age. Apart from retaining the standard provision for retirement on health grounds, the new sub-section 102 (2) will provide for the redeployment of an officer who is, for any other reason, no longer performing the duties of his position in such a manner as to permit the Corporation to make efficient and economical use of his services. This is somewhat broader than the corresponding provision in clause 9 applicable to officers under age 55 that I will explain later. The Corporation considers that this broader provision is desirable in the commercial environment in which it operates as it will enable the Corporation to redeploy or retire an officer who has attained the age of 55 years and who is no longer carrying out his duties in such a way as to enable the Corporation to use his services efficiently and economically. Where, in such a case, it is not reasonable or practicable to redeploy the officer, the Corporation may retire him from the service. The provision is in accord with the broad objectives of the CE (RR) Act and it is fully acceptable to the Commonwealth Bank Officers Association.

Clause 9 will effect a restatement of sub-section 106 (1) of the principal Act which, broadly speaking, currently provides that, if an officer appears to the Corporation to be inefficient or incompetent or unfit to discharge his duties, the Corporation may retire him from the Corporation service or redeploy him within the service. The main effect of clause 9 will be to apply the revised sub-section 106 (1) only to officers under the age of 55 years and to require the Corporation to explore all the options for redeployment and the like before action is taken to retire an officer from the Corporation service. This is in keeping with the intentions of the CE (RR) Act.

Clause 12 will amend sub-section 108 (1) of the principal Act to provide for rights of appeal against action taken by the Corporation to redeploy or retire an officer under revised sub-section 102 (2) or to retire an excess officer under sub-section 103 (2). The existing rights of appeal under revised section 106 and sub-section 107 (1) will be preserved. Hitherto, an officer has not had a right to appeal against action taken to retire him after reaching the minimum retiring age or as an excess officer.

Clause 13 provides that the present Disciplinary Appeal Board will continue in existence under the name Tenure and Disciplinary Appeal Board. In addition to the powers of the existing Appeal Board, the reconstituted Board will have the power to hear appeals against action taken under the Corporation's new powers to redeploy or retire officers.

Clause 14 will provide for a new section 110A to be inserted in the Commonwealth Banks Act to authorise the making of regulations to provide for the payment, in such circumstances as are prescribed, of a benefit to an officer who is retired from the service under proposed paragraph 102 (2) (b) or sub-section 103 (2) of the Act. In the case of an officer between the ages of 55 and 60 years, who is retired under sub-section 102 (2) (b), that is, on other than health grounds, it is intended to provide in the regulations for the payment of a lump sum benefit corresponding to the benefit payable to an officer retired from the Australian Public Service under the relevant provision of the CE (RR) Act. Consideration is being given to the nature of any benefit that may be payable in the case of an excess officer retired under sub-section 103 (2) of the principal Act.
I am circulating an explanatory memorandum that explains in detail the individual provisions of the Bill. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Northern Territory Legislative Assembly By-Election: Aboriginal Land Rights-Amnesty International: Report on El Salvador

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: — This morning in Question Time I asked a question of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) who is represented in this place by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume. I think the matter I raised this morning should be a matter of grave concern not only to me as an Aborigine but also to the Senate and the nation of Australia as it concerned the matter of elections to the Senate. I had the opportunity of visiting the Northern Territory and campaigning for the Country Liberal Party candidate, Mrs Rosie Kunoth-Monks.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of travelling around a number of the Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory I tried to tell the people that it was important that an Aboriginal person represent the seat of Macdonnell in the Northern Territory. The electorate was represented by an Aborigine named Neville Perkins prior to his resignation to take up a post with a section of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. During the course of travelling around and talking to people at Papunya I was informed that Mr Gough Whitlam, a former Prime Minister of this nation, was on that community as well. I found that he had been in consultation with a number of people. While travelling around communities such as Papunya, Jap Creek, Haasts Bluff, Santa Teresa and Hermannsburg I learned, to my dismay, that the former Prime Minister was telling the Aboriginal people, through an interpreter, that he was the person who gave land rights to the people in the Northern Territory.

Mr President, you and I know that although land rights legislation was introduced during the term of the Whitlam Government it did not come to fruition during that term. Land rights legislation was introduced into this Parliament and carried with the consent of all sides during the term of the Fraser Government. I, as an Aborigine very concerned with land rights for Aboriginal people throughout this nation, supported the legislation that was proposed by the Fraser Government and which was carried by the Parliament and later enacted. I am concerned that the former Prime Minister of this country went into those Aboriginal communities and, through an interpreter, told the Aboriginal people that he was the Prime Minister responsible for giving land rights to the Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —He introduced it and you voted against it.
—That is an outright untruth. It is an absolute untruth. Mr Gough Whitlam, when Prime Minister, did not introduce and have carried in this Parliament land rights legislation.
—Of course he did.

—He did not introduce that legislation. The Fraser Government introduced the legislation which was carried and which was implemented in the Northern Territory. I was the Chairman of the Joint Select Committee on Aboriginal Land Rights in the Northern Territory. The Committee brought in a report that was unanimous among all parties-Liberal Party, National Country Party and Labor Party. The facts are there for all to see. The former Prime Minister went into the Northern Territory during the by-election for the seat of Macdonnell and told the Aboriginal people that he was the Prime Minister that gave land rights to the Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory. He said also that if Aboriginal people in the Macdonnell electorate voted for Rosie Kunoth-Monks, the candidate for the Country Liberal Party in the Northern Territory, the Northern Territory Government would take away their land rights. Land rights for the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory were introduced by this Federal Parliament. There is no way in the world that the Northern Territory Government could take away those land rights from the Northern Territory Aboriginal people. Mr Gough Whitlam told an absolute untruth. He deceived the Aboriginal people in the Macdonnell electorate in the Northern Territory. He deceived them when, through an Aboriginal interpreter, he said to the people in that electorate that if they elected a very competent, decent and worthwhile Aboriginal person they would lose their land rights. She could represent the electorate of Macdonnell in the Northern Territory far better than any non-Aboriginal person.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth noting that a former member for the Macdonnell electorate said that that electorate, which has a 90 per cent Aboriginal constituency, should be represented by an Aboriginal. The Australian Labor Party which claims to be the champion of the Aboriginal people put up a non-Aboriginal candidate. That candidate got 60 per cent of the vote in that electorate because a former Prime Minister of this nation, Mr Gough Whitlam, told an absolute untruth. He said that if Rosie Kunoth-Monks were elected the Northern Territory Government would take away the land rights of the people of that electorate. Mr President, both you and I know that this is not possible because the land rights legislation in the Northern Territory was introduced in and carried by this Parliament. It is an enactment of the Federal Parliament of this nation, not an enactment of the Northern Territory Government. The Northern Territory Government does not have the power to revoke land rights legislation that was introduced in this Federal Parliament and supported by all parties. It is an absolute indictment of the Labor Party that it should use Aboriginal people in this shocking way to try to deceive our very--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are insulting the Aborigines.

—I am an Aborigine. You are not an Aborigine. I am an Aborigine and I am proud of the fact. Whenever I have stood up in this Parliament I have never been ashamed to admit that I was an Aborigine. I have spoken up on behalf of the Aboriginal people. How dare you, a non-Aborigine, challenge me, an Aborigine. You would not know what it is all about. You have never lived as an Aborigine. You have never known what it is to be discriminated against. You would not know what it is all about. How could you know? You are a non-Aborigine. You would not know what it is all about, but I do because I am an Aborigine. I was born under the lantana bushes. I grew up in an area where Aborigines were considered to be worth less than the household pet. How would you know what that is like? Of course you would not know. You use Aboriginal people for political advantage, and that is what you did in the Northern Territory.
—Order! Direct your remarks through the Chair.
—They are not worth answering.

—That is right, they are not worth answering. They do not know the kinds of things I know about. It is a shocking indictment of a former Prime Minister of this country that he could go into an electorate and tell the Aboriginal people that he was the man who gave land rights to the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory. That is an absolute untruth. It was the Liberal National Country parties which gave land rights to the people in the Northern Territory. It was the Fraser Government which introduced that legislation and made sure that Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory had rights to their land. For someone to go into those electorates and say to the Aboriginal people, through Aboriginal interpreters, that if a Country Liberal Party candidate were elected, the Country Liberal Party Government of the Northern Territory would take away land rights from the Aboriginal people is a shocking indictment of the Labor Party and its tactics in using Aboriginal people for its own political gain. I find it absolutely abhorrent, and I cannot find words to describe my feelings and those of the Aboriginal people about those who would stoop to such low tactics to win a by-election.

SPEECH.PARA: Rosie Kunoth-Monks, the person proposed by the Country Liberal Party in the Northern Territory, is a very fine lady with tremendous capabilities. I am sure that she would have represented not only the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory but all the people of the Northern Territory, because that is the calibre of the woman. She is a great lady, a lady for whom I have the greatest affection and respect. I am sure that the people of Alice Springs would have the same respect and admiration for that lady, who has endeavoured throughout her life to promote the Aboriginal people and to promote in the Northern Territory the togetherness of all people. Surely we should all be about promoting the togetherness of people, whether in the Northern Territory, Queensland or any other State of the Commonwealth, and that is what this lady is all about. A former Prime Minister of this country went into those areas and convinced the people that he was the man who gave land rights to the Aboriginal people. He was not the person who gave land rights to the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory, it was the Fraser Government which did that. He told an absolute untruth. I believe we should condemn what was perpetrated against the people, and the Aboriginal people particularly, in the electorate of Macdonnell in the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to correct the record following the remarks made by Senator Bonner about the development of land rights in the Northern Territory. I simply place on record the fact that before 1972 there were no land rights for Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory or in any other part of Australia. When the Whitlam Labor Government was elected to office in 1972, it immediately set about fulfilling its election promise of providing land rights for Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory. In order to do this, it set up a commission to inquire into the appropriate machinery and legislation for this purpose under Mr Justice Woodward. After the Woodward Commission reported, the Labor Government accepted the recommendations of that report and drafted legislation to give land rights to Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: That legislation came into this Parliament. It passed through the House of Representatives. On 11 November 1975, it was scheduled for discussion in this Senate. I will not waste the time of honourable senators this evening by rehearsing the reasons why the Aboriginal land rights legislation was not proceeded with on 11 November 1975 in this Senate. Suffice it to say, it was no doing of any Australian Labor Party representative in this place that land rights were not given to Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory in November 1975. The reasons were quite different and the causes are to be found on the other side of this chamber.

I make some comments also about the relevance of the attitude of the Northern Territory Government regarding land rights in the Northern Territory because, after all, the election to which Senator Bonner has drawn our attention tonight was in fact a by-election in the seat of Macdonnell for the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly. I think it is quite pertinent to ask: What is the attitude of the current Northern Territory Government to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act? Only yesterday in this place, I tabled a document which was a submission by the Northern Territory Government in the name of Mr Paul Everingham, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory Government, which set out very clearly and unambiguously the attitude of that Government to the Federal Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. I will not go over what I said yesterday, as the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) will be very well aware of what I said.

The Government of the Northern Territory, under the leadership of Mr Paul Everingham, is quite hostile to the land rights legislation which Senator Bonner was attempting to defend tonight. It recommended that no further land rights be granted and that no further claims be heard. It was extremely critical of the decisions taken by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner, Mr Justice Toohey. I simply place these matters on the record. I am really only adverting to my action yesterday in tabling that submission because it will be available to all honourable senators to read.

The Labor Government initiated the work which culminated in land rights for the Northern Territory and the reason Labor legislation was not passed was as a result of the actions of Liberal-National Country Party senators in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Including Senator Bonner.

—Including Senator Bonner. I believe it was quite proper for anybody campaigning in the Macdonnell by-election, and certainly for somebody who is so intimately aware of the development of land rights legislation in this country as Mr Gough Whitlam, to point to the dangers presented by Everingham's Government to the land rights legislation in the Northern Territory. I place all of those matters on the record because they are, unlike the remarks of Senator Bonner, matters of fact.

SPEECH.PARA: I will conclude by stating an opinion, Mr President. It is my opinion that the campaigning of former Prime Minister Gough Whitlam in the Macdonnell by-election was crucial to the outcome. The reason, in my opinion is that Aboriginal people throughout Australia and Aboriginal people in the Macdonnell area of central Australia recognise and acknowledge the achievements of former Prime Minister Gough Whitlam for Aboriginal people over a vast range of matters. Is it not apparent that former Prime Minister Gough Whitlam clearly had the confidence and gratitude of Aboriginal people and that they were prepared to vote for the party of which he is still so notable a member? Is it not an irony that Senator Bonner brought into the Senate, in such a hostile and critical way, the fact that former Prime Minister Gough Whitlam campaigned in the Macdonnell by-election, whereas many people would say that his making himself available to campaign in that by-election for quite a lengthy period is simply further confirmation of that man's total commitment to the Aboriginal cause?

SPEECH.PARA: I want to speak for a few minutes on a problem which has occurred, to me anyway, in that it is very difficult for me to obtain balanced reporting from one of the trouble spots in the world. I refer to El Salvador. Tonight I attended a meeting of the parliamentary group of Amnesty International at which concern was expressed about the lack of balanced reporting of what is happening in that country. I had sent to me by the New South Wales and Queensland branches of Amnesty International a copy of the March report. It arrived on my desk in the Parliament today. It is terribly important, I think, that honourable senators be aware of the contents of this document regarding El Salvador.

It would appear to me and, I presume, to the majority of people throughout Australia and the free-thinking world that the people of El Salvador are no better off under President Duarte than they were under the junta which operated in that country until December of last year. I say that in the knowledge of the contents of this report because people who were arrested prior to President Duarte's taking office are being executed following his election. The March edition of the Amnesty International newsletter states:

The human rights situation in El Salvador has deteriorated sharply in recent months. Amnesty International is seriously concerned and fears a further increase in summary execution, torture and abduction by government forces as civil conflict continues between guerrillas and the government. Of some 8,000 Salvadorians estimated to have been killed during the past year, many are known to have been the victims of extrajudicial execution by the armed forces. Peasants and young people appear to be particular targets. Sources in the country say that nearly 3,300 peasants were among those killed for political reasons in 1980.

Despite government claims that those killed by its forces are guerrillas and guerrilla sympathisers, many victims of torture and death at the hands of the security forces were not generally shown to have any direct involvement in armed guerrilla activity.

International attention was captured by the killing on 3 December 1980 of three nuns and a woman missionary, all United States nationals, reported to have been abducted by security forces the previous day. However, in the week after those killings, from 6 to 12 December, according to sources in El Salvador, 144 people were killed, 66 of them by uniformed members of the security forces.

On 17 December 1980, members of the National Guard raided the town of Cojutepeque in the department of San Salvador and killed eight leaders of the Central Campesina Salvadorena (Salvadorian Peasants Organization) who were meeting to discuss plans for participation in the government's agrarian reform program. There have been similar attacks in the past.

There is evidence that young people are singled out because of their youth. On 10 January 1981, troops took 22 teenagers from Mejicanos; all where later found dead, with marks showing that they had been tortured. An army spokesman said they died of bullet wounds in a confrontation with troops; but a doctor who examined 17 of the bodies said they had all been shot after dying. Five of the young women were unidentifiable because their faces had been erased.

AI has received reports that Salvadorian paramilitary squads regularly cross the border into Honduras to attack Salvadorian refugee camps. Inside El Salvador, church sources report that refugees have been taken from camps and killed. On 31 December 1980 soldiers from San Carlos garrison searched the Domus Mariae refugee centre in Mejicanos and took away Marcial Cruz, aged 18. He was later seen at the garrison, and on 9 January was found dead.

Red Cross clinics have been attacked: on 12 January, troops broke into a clinic in Chalatenango. They killed wounded people being treated there and abducted five young women aged from 14 to 22. On the same day, three men, members of the Baptist Church, were seized by security forces in San Salvador as they delivered provisions to the Red Cross. The whereabouts of all the people abducted in these two incidents are unknown.

Killings and 'disappearances' of foreign journalists, including journalist John Sullivan, United States citizen, who was abducted on 28 December, have been widely reported in the international media; but Salvadorian journalists have also been victims of the armed forces. On 15 January 1981, nine staff members of the newspaper El Independiente, including journalists Vida Cuadra and Francisco Ramirez Avila, were taken from the newspaper's offices by troops. The authorities deny that they are in detention. (On 25 January, the newspaper closed down and its director Jorge Pinto took refuge in the Mexican Embassy.)

Members of the Roman Catholic Church and others helping refugees and victims of the civil fighting have been hampered in their work by the security forces. The Archbishopric of San Salvador reported in mid-December that it had been forced to close its legal aid office (Socorro Juridico) because it had been raided 17 times in the previous week by the National Police. Even government offices have been subject to army raids. On 9 January, the publications department of the Education Ministry was raided by troops while it was printing leaflets with instructions for refugees; eight staff members, including the director of the department, were seized. Their whereabouts are unknown. Members of the El Salvador Human Rights Commission who witnessed the seizures have denied army allegations that subversive literature was found on the premises.

On 25 January, a leading member of the El Salvador Human Rights Commission, Victor Medrano, aged 29, was abducted from his home by plainclothes members of the National Police. Although he has been seen in the barracks of the National Police in San Salvador, authorities deny that he is in detention and there is very serious concern for his safety. Two other members of the same commission have been killed since the beginning of October last year. One was Maria Magdalena Enriquez, its press secretary who was found dead in a shallow grave about 20 miles from the capital. She was abducted on 3 October 1980 while shopping and appears to have been killed the day after her abduction. Witnesses confirmed that two of the heavily armed men who detained Sra. Enriquez were uniformed members of the National Police. Representatives of the Junta (that headed the government of El Salvador until December 1980) however denied that police carried out the detention and stated that the government 'was not implicated' in the matter. The other member of the commission killed was Ramon Valladares Perez, who was shot dead on 26 October while driving a car in the capital. The El Salvador Human Rights Commission is an independent human rights monitoring group that provides both assistance to victims of human rights abuse and publicises their cases. The Commission's offices have been destroyed by bombings three times last year in the presence of the permanent police guard on the premises. The Commission had reportedly been accused by the president of El Salvador, Ing. Jose Napoleon Duarte, of being 'anti-patriotic' a few days before the abduction of Victor Medrano. The offices of the Commission were again surrounded by troops on 18 January and the Commission has seen itself forced to close down.

People have been killed because of their association, or presumed association with peasant, labour or religious organisations, or with political parties or other organisations which do not actively support the present government. Although these killings took place against a background of conflict between government forces and guerrilla organisations, evidence reaching AI shows that many civilians not involved in guerrilla activity are being tortured and killed by the security forces. Most of the deaths have occurred after people were seized at their homes or places of work.

During 1980 the government of El Salvador repeatedly claimed that independent 'anti-communist' assassination squads beyond government control were responsible for these abductions and murders. However, evidence collated by AI from hundreds of individual cases proves the responsibility of the regular security forces for serious violations of human rights. By attributing detentions, torture and killings to groups beyond government control, the government of El Salvador seems to have sought a means of evading accountability for the extra-legal measures carried out by its own security forces.

AI fears that the current wave of extrajudicial killings and 'disappearances' will continue to escalate as the Salvadorian security forces use the cover of civil warfare to carry out large-scale killings of young people, peasants and others not shown to be involved in guerrilla activities.

I raise this matter with the Parliament tonight on the adjournment debate because I am a member of the excecutive committee of the Parliamentary group of Amnesty International. It has expressed its concern through its international organisation, as I am sure will all members of this organisation who are bipartisan in their political approach to human rights, and members of the Senate and of the other place. We are vitally concerned at massacres which appear to be occurring on a regular basis in El Salvador. We are concerned that perhaps the Government is not doing as much as it should be doing. With the recent ratification by Australia of the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, it appears to me to be an opportune time for the Australian Government to express its concern in a public way so that the Government of El Salvador knows of the concern of the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is that, on the information available to me, I cannot test, confirm, deny or in any other way work through the matter of what was or was not said by any person through an interpreter. I think any former Prime Minister, taking part in a campaign in those circumstances, would have an obligation on him to ensure that any contribution he makes is impeccably correct in fact-that it is correct in every detail. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Senator Coleman raised a matter which is of concern to her and, I think, to many people-El Salvador. She mentioned the concern of Amnesty International. Perhaps I could say, in brief response, that there are clearly two important aspects to the situation in El Salvador and urgent and effective action must be taken in regard to both of them to remove the threat that El Salvador now offers to peace and stability in the American sphere.

SPEECH.PARA: El Salvador has become an issue in East-West relations and there is now clear evidence of external support for left wing guerilla movements operating in El Salvador. The United States has a genuine and long-acknowledged interest in the region, and the Australian Government considers that the United States is entirely right in seeking to cut off a source of disturbance and revolution in Latin America. At the same time, however-I think this is the point which was made by Senator Coleman-many people are properly concerned about human rights violations in that country. The Australian Government shares this concern and has made its views known at this year's meeting in Geneva of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights.

In particular, the Government recognises the need to support economic and social reform in El Salvador as an essential step towards solving the human rights problems. During a meeting attended by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Street, in Washington on 5 March, the Vice-President of the United States of America, Mr Bush, made it clear to the Minister that the United States shares that view. Senator Coleman raised a number of matters of detail in her speech this evening. I undertake to refer them to the Minister. If there is a response further to the general comments I have made on behalf of the Minister I will see that it is given to Senator Coleman.
